original: 1. Aādayo titālīsa vaṇṇā.🔽Akārādayo niggahītantā tecattālīsa-kkharā vaṇṇā nāma honti. A ā i ī u ū e e o o,
analyzed: a ādayaḥ titālīsa vaṇṇā  akāra ādayaḥ niggahī tantā vaṇṇāḥ nāma honti
translated: . A and the others are the thirty-two vowels.

original: ka kha ga gha ṅa ca cha ja jha ñña, ṭa ṭha ḍa ḍha ṇa, ta tha da dha na, pa pha ba🔽bha ma, ya ra la va sa ha ḷa aṃ. Tena kvattho? “E o na mavaṇṇe” 1. 37. Titālīsābhi
analyzed: ka kha ga gha ṅa ca cha ja jha ñña ṭa ṭha ḍa ḍha ṇa ta tha da dha na pa pha ba 🔽bha ma ya ra la va sa ha ḷa am tena kvatthaḥ e o na ma vaṇṇe
translated: The consonants beginning with a, ā, i, ī, u, ū, e, ai, o, au, k, kh, g, gh, ṅ, c, ch, j, jh, ñ, ṭ, ṭh, ḍ, ḍh, ṇ, t, th, d, dh, n, p, ph, b, bh, m, y, r, l, v, s, s, h, ḷ, aṃ, are called the forty-three consonants. By what means? “E, o, na, ma, and the vowels” . The thirty-two vowels🔽. A, ā, i, ī, u, ū, e, ai, o, au, k, kh, g, gh, ṅ, c, ch, j, jh, ñ, ṭ, ṭh, ḍ, ḍh, ṇ, t, th, d, dh, n, p, ph, b, bh, m, y, r, l, v, s, s, h, ḷ, aṃ, are called the thirty-two vowels.

original: vacanaṃ katthaci vaṇṇalopaṃ ñāpeti. Tena ‘paṭisaṅkhā yoniso’tiādi siddhaṃ.
analyzed: vacanam katthaci vaṇṇa lopam ñāpeti tena paṭisaṅkhā yoniso ti ādi siddham
translated: The word is sometimes given in the form in which a syllable is lost. Therefore “wisely reflecting” is established.

original: 2. Dasādo sarā.
analyzed: sarā
translated: . Dasādo sarā.

original: Tatthādimhi dasa vaṇṇā sarā nāma honti. Tena kvattho? “Saro lopo sare” 1, 26 iccādi.
analyzed: tattha ādimhi dasa vaṇṇāḥ sarāḥ nāma honti tena kvatthaḥ saraḥ lopaḥ sare iccādi
translated: Herein, the ten vowels are called “sars” . Therefore “kvattho”? “Saro lopo sare” ,  etc.

original: 3. Dvedve savaṇṇā. Tesu dvedve sarā savaṇṇā nāma honti. Tena kvattho? “Vaṇṇaparena savaṇṇopi” 1, 24.
analyzed: dve dve savaṇṇā tesu dve dve sarā savaṇṇāḥ nāma honti tena kvatthaḥ vaṇṇa parena savaṇṇaḥ api
translated: . Dvedve savaṇṇā. In these two, the two are called “savaṇṇā” . Therefore “kvattho”? “Vaṇṇaparena savaṇṇopi” , .

original: 4. Pubbo rasso.
analyzed: pubbaḥ rassaḥ
translated: . Pubbo rasso.

original: Tesu dvīsu yo yo pubbo, so so rassasañño hoti. Tesu e.o.saṃyogato pubbāva dissanti. Tena kvattho? “Rasso vā” 2,62 iccādi.
analyzed: tesu dvīsu yaḥ yaḥ pubbaḥ saḥ saḥ rassa sañño hoti tesu e o saṃyogato pubbā ava dissanti tena kvattho rassaḥ vā iccādi
translated: In these two, whichever is first is called “short” . In these, e.o.saṃyogato pubbāva dissanti. Therefore “kvattho”? “Rasso vā” ,  etc.

original: 5. Paro dīgho.
analyzed: paraḥ dīghaḥ
translated: . Paro dīgho.

original: Te sveva dvīsuyo yo paro, so so dīghasañño hoti. Tena kvattho? “Yo lo panisu dīgho” 2,88 iccādi.
analyzed: te su eva yaḥ paraḥ saḥ so dīgha sañño hoti tena kvatthaḥ yaḥ laḥ panisu dīghaḥ iccādi
translated: In these two, whichever is last is called “long” . Therefore “kvattho”? “Yo lo panisu dīgho” ,  etc.

original: 6. Kādayo byañjanā.
analyzed: ka ādayaḥ byañjanā
translated: . Kādayo byañjanā.

original: Kakārādayo vaṇṇā niggahītapariyantā byañjanasaññāhonti. Tena kvattho? “Byañjane dīgharassā” 1,33 iccādi.
analyzed: kakāra ādayaḥ vaṇṇāḥ niggahīta pariyantāḥ byañjana saññā honti tena kvatthaḥ byañjane dīgha rassā iccādi
translated: The vowels beginning with ka and ending with the cerebrals are called “bhyañjana” . Therefore “kvattho”? “Byañjane dīgharassā” ,  etc.

original: 7. Pañca pañcakā vaggā.
analyzed: pañca pañcakā vaggā
translated: . Pañca pañcakā vaggā.

original: Kādayo pañca pañcakā vagga, nāma honti. Tena kvattho? “Vagge vagganto” 1,41 iccādi.
analyzed: ka ādayaḥ pañca pañcakāḥ vagga nāma honti tena kvatthaḥ vagge vagga antaḥ iccādi
translated: The five beginning with ka are called the group of five. What is the meaning of that? “In the group, in the group” , etc.

original: 8. Bindu niggahītaṃ.
analyzed: bindu niggahītam
translated: . The dot is the sign of the stop.

original: Yvāyaṃ vaṇṇo bindumatto, so niggahītasañño hoti. Tena kvattho? “Niggahītaṃ” 1,38 icādi. Garusaññākaraṇaṃ anvatthasaññatthaṃ.
analyzed: yvā ayam vaṇṇaḥ bindu matto saḥ niggahīta saññaḥ hoti tena kvatthaḥ niggahītam i c ādi garu saññā karaṇam anvattha saññattham
translated: The letter which is the size of a dot is the sign of the stop. What is the meaning of that? “The stop” , etc. The making of the sign of the heavy is for the purpose of the sign of the following.

original: 9. Iyuvaṇṇā jhalā nāmassante.
analyzed: iyu vaṇṇāḥ jha lāḥ nāmassante
translated: . The i vowel is the sign of the jhala at the end of a name.

original: Nāmaṃ pāṭipadikaṃ, tassaante vattamānā ivaṇṇuvaṇṇā jhalasaññā honti yathākkamaṃ. Tena kvattho? “Jhalā vā” 2,111 iccādi.
analyzed: nāmam pāṭipadikam tassa ante vattamānāḥ jha l a saññāḥ honti yathākkamam tena ku atthaḥ jha lāḥ vā iccādi
translated: The name is the first word, and the i vowel and u vowel which occur at the end of that are the signs of the jhala in order. What is the meaning of that? “The jhala” , etc.

original: 10. Pitthiyaṃ.
analyzed: pitthiyam
translated: . The back is the sign of the pas.

original: Itthiyaṃ vattamānassa nāmassa-nte vattamānā ivaṇṇuvaṇṇā pasaññā honti. Tena kvattho? Ye passivaṇṇassa” 2,116 iccādi.
analyzed: itthiyam vattamānassa vattamānāḥ ivaṇṇuvaṇṇāḥ pasaññāḥ honti tena kvatthaḥ ye iccādi
translated: The sign of the pas is the i vowel and u vowel which occur at the end of a name occurring in a feminine. What is the meaning of that? “The sign of the pas” , etc.

original: 11. Ghā.
analyzed: ghā
translated: . The gh is the sign of the ga.

original: Itthiyaṃ vattamānassa nāmassa-nte vatthamāno ākāro ghasañño hoti. Tena kvattho? “Ghabrahmādite” 2,60 iccādi.
analyzed: itthiyam vattamānassa nāma ssa ante vatthamānaḥ ākāraḥ gha saññaḥ hoti tena kvatthaḥ gha brahma ādite iccādi
translated: The sign of the ga is the sign of the shape which occurs at the end of a name occurring in a feminine. What is the meaning of that? “The ga, the brahma, etc.” , etc.

original: 12. Go syālapane.
analyzed: goḥ syā ā lapane
translated: . The go is the sign of the syallapane.

original: Ālapane si gasañño hoti.
analyzed: ālapane si ga saññaḥ hoti
translated: The sign of the syallapane is the sign of the ga.

original: Tena kvattho? “Gevā” 2,65 iccādi.
analyzed: tena kvatthaḥ gevā i ccādi
translated: What is the meaning of that? “The ga only” , etc.🔽(The signs)

original: (Saññā)
analyzed: saññā
translated: (perception)🔽🔽

original: 13. Vidhibbisesanantassa.
analyzed: vidhip bisesana antassa
translated: 13. The rule for the end of the preceding

original: Yaṃ visesanaṃ, tadantassa vidhi ñātabbo “ato yonaṃ ṭāṭe” 2,41 narānare.
analyzed: yam visesanam tad antassa vidhi ñātabbaḥ atas ya ūnam ṭa āṭe nara anare
translated: The distinction is to be known as the rule for the end of the preceding, “from this the river’s bank,” men and women.

original: 14. Sattamiyaṃ pubbassa.
analyzed: sattamiyam pubbassa
translated: . The seventh is of the preceding

original: Sattamīniddese pubbasseva kāriyaṃ ñātabbaṃ “saro lopo sare” 1,26 veḷaggaṃ. ‘Tamaha’ntīdha kasmā na hoti?, Saretopasilesikādhāro tatthetāva vuccate ‘pubbasseva hoti na parassā’ti.
analyzed: sattamī niddese pubbassa iva kāriyam ñātabbam saraḥ lopaḥ sare veḷaggam tam ahanti idha kasmā na hoti tattha iti ava vuccate pubbassa iva hoti na parassa ati
translated: In the seventh case the function of the preceding is to be known, “the river’s bank,” the tip of the reed. Why is it not “that” here? The base of the inflections of the preposition is said to be just this much: “It is of the preceding, not of the following.”

original: 15. Pañcamiyaṃ parassa.
analyzed: pañcamiyam parassa
translated: . The fifth is of the following

original: Pañcamīniddese parassa kāriyaṃ ñātabbaṃ “atoyonaṃ ṭāṭe” 2,41 narānare. Idha na hotaṃ ‘jantuho anattā’. Idha kasmā na hoti? Osakhyo, anantare katatthatāya na byavahitassa kāriyaṃ.
analyzed: pañcamī niddese parassa kāriyam ñātabbam a taḥ yaḥ ūnam ṭāṭe nara anare idha na hotam jantu haḥ anattā idha kasmā na hoti anantare katatthatāya na byavahitassa kāriyam
translated: In the fifth case the function of the following is to be known, “from this the river’s bank,” men and women. Here it is not “the creature is insubstantial.” Why is it not here? The preposition is not the function of the separated, because it is done in the next.

original: 16. Ādissa.
analyzed: ādissa
translated: . The preceding

original: Parassa ssissamānaṃ kāriyamādivaṇṇassa ñātabbaṃ “ra saṅkhyāto vā” 3,103 terasa.
analyzed: parassa ssissamānam kāriyam ādi vaṇṇassa ñātabbam ra saṅkhyātaḥ vā terasa
translated: The function of the preceding is to be known as the colour of the case-ending that is being inflected, “ra from a numeral,” thirteen.

original: 17. Chaṭṭhiyantassa.
analyzed: chaṭṭhiyantassa
translated: . The sixth is of the preceding

original: Chaṭṭhīniddiṭṭhassa yaṃ kāriyaṃ, tadantassa vaṇṇassa viññeyyaṃ “rājassi nāmhi” 2,23 rājinā.
analyzed: chaṭṭhī niddiṭṭhassa yam kāriyam tad antassa vaṇṇassa viññeyyam rājassi nāmhi rājinā
translated: The function of the sixth case-ending is to be known as the colour of the preceding, “I am a king,” by the king.

original: 18. Ṅānubandho.
analyzed: ṅānubandhaḥ
translated: 18. The affix ṅa.

original: Ṅakāro anubandho yassa, so antassa hoti “gossā vaṅa” 1,32 gavāssaṃ.
analyzed: ṅakāraḥ anubandhaḥ yassa saḥ antassa hoti gossā gavāssam
translated: The affix ṅa is added to the end of a word, as in gossā vaṅa, gavāssaṃ.

original: 19. Ṭānubandhānekavaṇṇā sabbassa.
analyzed: ṭa anubandhā aneka vaṇṇā sabbassa
translated: . Ṭa is the affix of many-colored, all.

original: Ṭakāro-nubandho yassa, so-nekakkharo cādeso sabbassa hoti “imassānitthiyaṃ ṭe” 2,128 esu, “nāmha-nimi” 2,126 anena.
analyzed: ṭakāraḥ anubandhaḥ yassa saḥ neka kkharaḥ ca ādesaḥ sabbassa hoti imassa anitthiyam ṭe esu anena
translated: The affix ṭa is added to the end of a word, as in imassānitthiyaṃ ṭe, esu, nāmha-nimi, anena.

original: 20. Ñakānubandhādyantā.
analyzed: ñaka anubandha ādi antā
translated: . Ṇa is the affix of beginning and end.

original: Chaṭṭhīniddiṭṭhassa ñānubandhakānubandhā ādyantā honti “brūto tissīña” 6,36 bravīti, “bhūssa vuka” 6,17 babhūva.
analyzed: chaṭṭhī niddiṭṭhassa ña anubandhaka anubandhāḥ ādi antāḥ honti brūto bravīti bhūssa babhūva
translated: The affix ṇ is added to the end of a word that is indicated by the sixth case, as in brūto tissīña, bravīti, bhūssa vuka, babhūva.

original: 21. Mānubandho sarānamantā paro.
analyzed: mā anubandho paraḥ
translated: . Ma is the affix of the end of a word, the other is the end.

original: Makāro-nubandho yassa, so sarā namantā sarā paro hoti “mañca rudhādīnaṃ” 5-19 rundhati.
analyzed: makāraḥ anubandhaḥ yassa saḥ sarā namantā sarā paras hoti rudhā ādīnam rundhati
translated: The affix ma is added to the end of a word, as in mañca rudhādīnaṃ, rundhati.

original: 22. Vippaṭisedhe.
analyzed: vippaṭisedhe
translated: . In the prohibition.

original: Dvinnaṃ sāvakāsānamekatthappasaṅge paro hoti. Yathā dvinnaṃ tiṇṇaṃ vāpurisānaṃ sahappattiyaṃ
analyzed: dvinnam sa avakāsānam ekattha ppasaṅge paras hoti yathā dvinnam tiṇṇam vāpurisānam sahappattiyam
translated: The other is added when two sāvakās are combined into one meaning. As when two or three men meet together,

original: paro, so ca (gacchati) tvaṃ ca (gacchasi, tumhe) gacchatha. So ca (gacchati,) tvaṃ
analyzed: paras saḥ ca gacchati tvam ca gacchasi tumhe gacchatha saḥ ca gacchati tvam
translated: the other is added, as in he goes, you go, you all go. And he goes, you

original: ca (gacchasi,) ahaṃ ca (gacchāmi, mayaṃ) gacchāma.
analyzed: ca gacchasi aham ca gacchāmi mayam gacchāma
translated: and I go, we go.

original: 23. Saṅketo-navayavo-nubandho.
analyzed: saṅketaḥ ūna avayavaḥ nubandho
translated: The nine-membered compound is a connection.

original: Yo navayavabhūtosaṅketo, so-nubandhoti ñātabbo, “lupitādīnamāsimhi” 2-57 kattā.
analyzed: yaḥ nava yava bhūtaḥ u saṅketaḥ saḥ nubandho ti ñātabbaḥ lupita ādīnam āsimhi kattā
translated: The connection should be known as the compound of nine members, “In the word ‘āsimhi’ (in me) the first syllable is lost.”

original: Saṅketaggahaṇaṃ kiṃ? Pakatiyādisamudāyassānubandhatā mā hotūti, anavayavohi samudāyo… samudāyarūpattāyeva.
analyzed: saṅketa ggahaṇam kim pakatiya ādi samudāyassa anubandha tā mā hotu iti anavayavaḥ hi samudāyaḥ samudāya rūpattāya iva
translated: Why is the compound mentioned? In order that there may not be a connection of the collection of the original form, etc., because the collection is not a member, and because it is the form of a collection.

original: Anavayavaggahaṇaṃ kiṃ? “Atena” 2-108 janena. Imināva lopassāvagatattā nānubandhalopāya vacanamāraddhaṃ.
analyzed: an avayava ggahaṇam kim atena janena na anubandha lopāya vacanam āraddham
translated: Why is the non-member mentioned? “By this” person. Because the loss is understood by this very (word), the statement is not established for the loss without a connection.

original: 24. Vaṇṇaparena savaṇṇopi.
analyzed: vaṇṇa parena sa vaṇṇaḥ api
translated: . Even all the colours with a colour-word in front.

original: Vaṇṇasaddo paro yasmā tena savaṇṇopi gayhati saṃca rūpaṃ “yuvaṇṇānameo luttā” 1-29 vākeritaṃ, samonā.
analyzed: vaṇṇa saddo paraḥ yasmā tena savaṇṇaḥ api saṃ ca rūpam vāka īritam sama ūnā
translated: Because the word “colour” is in front, therefore even all the colours are referred to, “The young women are lost” (is said) by Vākerita, together.

original: 25. Ntu vantumantvāvantutavantusambandhī.
translated: . Only with the nt-ending, with the vant-ending, with the ant-ending, and with the tvant-ending.

original: Vantvādisambandhīyevantu gayhati, “ntantūnaṃ nto yomhi paṭhame” 2-215 guṇavanto.
analyzed: vantu ādi sambandhīya ivantu paṭhame guṇavantaḥ
translated: Only with the vant-ending, etc., is referred to, “The nt-ending and the nt-ending are in the first (case), I am” (is said), the virtuous.

original: Vantvādisambandhīti kiṃ? Jantū tantū.
analyzed: vantu ādi sambandhi iti kim jantū tantū
translated: What is meant by “with the vant-ending, etc., is referred to”? The living beings, the threads.

original: (Paribhāsāyo.)
analyzed: paribhāsāyo
translated: (The Paribhāṣās.)

original: 26. Saro lopo sare.
analyzed: saraḥ lopaḥ sare
translated: . The loss of the sa is in the sa.

original: Sare saro lopanīyo hoti. Tatri-me, saddhi-ndriyaṃ, nohe-taṃ, bhikkhuno-vādo, sametā-yasmā, abhibhā-yatanaṃ, puttāma-tthi, asante-ttha.
analyzed: sare saraḥ lopanīyaḥ hoti tatra ime saddhi indriyam bhikkhunā uvādaḥ sameta ayasmai abhibhāyatanam asantā ittha
translated: The ending of the word is dropped after the word sarā. Here are some examples: saddhi-ndriyaṃ, nohe-taṃ, bhikkhuno-vādo, sametā-yasmā, abhibhā-yatanaṃ, puttāma-tthi, asante-ttha.

original: 27. Paro kvaci.
analyzed: paraḥ kvaci
translated: . After the word paro, the ending is sometimes dropped.

original: Saramhā paro saro kvaci lopanīyo hoti. So-pi, sāva, yato-dakaṃ, tato-va. Kvacītikiṃ? Saddhi-ndriyaṃ, ayamadhikāro āparicchedāvasānā, tena nātippasaṅgo.
analyzed: paraḥ saraḥ kvaci lopanīyaḥ hoti saḥ api yatas udakam kvaci iti kim saddhindriyam ayam adhikāraḥ tena na ati pasaṅgo
translated: After the word sarā, the ending is sometimes dropped after the word paro. So-pi, sāva, yato-dakaṃ, tato-va. Sometimes? saddhi-ndriyaṃ, this is the context up to the end of the section, therefore there is no over-application.

original: 28. Na dvevā.
analyzed: na dvā iva
translated: . Not in the case of two.

original: Pubbaparasarā dvepi vā kvaci na lupyante, latā iva, late-va, latā-va.🔽29. Yuvaṇṇānameo luttā.
analyzed: dve api vā kvaci na lupyante latāḥ iva latā iva latā ava  yuvan ṇā nameḥ luttā
translated: In the case of two, the ending is not dropped after the words pubba and para, like latā iva, late-va, latā-va.🔽. The ending of the words of the second case is changed to eo, as if they were of another.

original: Luttā sarā paresaṃ ivaṇṇuvaṇṇānaṃ eo honti vā yathākkamaṃ.
analyzed: luttā sarā paresam honti vā yathākkamam
translated: The ending of the words of the second case is changed to eo, as if they were of another, in order.

original: Tasse-daṃ, vāte-ritaṃ, no-peti, vāmo-rū, ate-vaññehi, vo-dakaṃ. Kathaṃ “paccorasmi”nti? Yogavibhāgā. Vātveva? Tassidaṃ.
analyzed: tassa idam vāta īritam na upeti vāma ūrū vā udakam katham pacca urasmin ti yogavibhāgāḥ tassa idam
translated: Tasse-daṃ, vāte-ritaṃ, no-peti, vāmo-rū, ate-vaññehi, vo-dakaṃ. How is it “paccorasmi”? By the division of the rules. Vātveva? Tassidaṃ.

original: Lutteti kiṃ? Latā iva.
analyzed: luttā iti kim latāḥ iva
translated: What is the purpose of the word luttā? Like latā.

original: 30. Yavā sare.
analyzed: yavā sare
translated: . After the word yava.

original: Sare pare ivaṇṇuvaṇṇānaṃ yakāravakārā honti vā yathākkamaṃ. Byākato, iccassa, ajjhiṇamutto, svāgataṃ, svāpanalānilaṃ, vātveva? Iti-ssa. Kvacitveva? Yānī-dha, sū-paṭṭhitaṃ.
analyzed: sare pare yakāra vakārāḥ honti vā yathākkamam iccassa svāgatam svāpa nala anilam vā tvā iva iti ssa su upaṭṭhitam
translated: In the middle of a word, the vowels ya and va become ya and va respectively of the preceding and following vowels. Byākato, iccassa, ajjhiṇamutto, svāgataṃ, svāpanalānilaṃ, vātveva? Iti-ssa. Kvacitveva? Yānī-dha, sū-paṭṭhitaṃ.

original: 31. Eonaṃ.
analyzed: e ū nam
translated: . Eonaṃ.

original: Eonaṃyavāyonti vā sare yathākkamaṃ. Tyajja te-jja, svāhaṃ so-haṃ. Kvacitveva? Puttāma-tthi, asante-ttha.
analyzed: vā sare yathākkamam tyajja svāham soham
translated: Eonaṃyavāyonti vā in the middle of a word, the vowels ya and va become ya and va respectively of the preceding and following vowels. Tyajja te-jja, svāhaṃ so-haṃ. Kvacitveva? Puttāma-tthi, asante-ttha.

original: 32. Gossā-vaṅa.
analyzed: gossāvaṅa
translated: . Gossā-vaṅa.

original: Sare gossa avaṅa hoti. Gavā-ssaṃ. ‘Yatharīva, tatharive’ti nipātāva, ‘bhusāmive’ti ivasaddo evattho.
analyzed: sare gossa hoti gavāssam yathari iva tathari iva iti nipāta ava bhusām iva iti iva saddaḥ eva atthaḥ
translated: In the middle of a word, the vowel of go becomes avaṅa. Gavā-ssaṃ. ‘Yatharīva, tatharive’ti nipātāva, ‘bhusāmive’ti ivasaddo evattho.

original: 33. Byañjane dīgharassā.
analyzed: byañjane dīgha ras sā
translated: . Byañjane dīgharassā.

original: Rassadīghānaṃ kvaci dīgharassā honti byañjane. Tatrā-yaṃ, munīcare, sammadeva, mālabhārī.
analyzed: rassa dīghānam kvaci dīgha rassāḥ honti byañjane tatra ayam munīcare sammadā iva mālabhārī
translated: In the middle of a word, the long and short vowels sometimes become long and short respectively in the consonants. Tatrā-yaṃ, munīcare, sammadeva, mālabhārī.

original: 34. Saramhā dve.
analyzed: saramhā dve
translated: . Saramhā dve.

original: Saramhā parassa byañjanassa kvaci dve rūpāni honti. Paggaho. Saramhāti kiṃ? Taṃ khaṇaṃ.
analyzed: saramhā parassa byañjanassa kvaci dve rūpāni honti paggahaḥ saramhā iti kim tam khaṇam
translated: In the middle of a word, the vowel of the preceding consonant sometimes has two forms. Paggaho. Saramhāti kiṃ? Taṃ khaṇaṃ.

original: 35. Catutthadutiyesvesaṃ tatiyapaṭhamā.
analyzed: tatiya paṭhamā
translated: . Catutthadutiyesvesaṃ tatiyapaṭhamā.

original: Catutthadutiyesu paresvesaṃ catutthadutiyānaṃ tabbagge tatiya paṭhamā honti. Paccāsatthyā,
analyzed: catuttha dutiyesu paresu esam catuttha dutiyānam tad bagge paṭhamāḥ honti
translated: In the last and second of the others, the last and second of the last and second are the third and first of the last and second. Paccāsatthya,

original: nigghoso, akkhanti, bojjhaṅgā, setacchattaṃ, daḍḍho, niṭṭhānaṃ, mahaddhano, yasatthero,
analyzed: nigghosaḥ akkhanti bojjhaṅgā setacchattam daḍḍhaḥ niṭṭhānam mahat dhanaḥ yasa thero
translated: nigghoso, akkhanti, bojjhaṅgā, setacchattaṃ, daḍḍho, niṭṭhānaṃ, mahaddhano, yasatthero,

original: apphuṭaṃ, abbhuggato. Esvīti kiṃ? Thero. Esanti kiṃ? Pattho.
analyzed: apphuṭam abbhuggataḥ kim theraḥ
translated: apphuṭaṃ, abbhuggato. Esvīti kiṃ? Thero. Esanti kiṃ? Pattho.

original: 36. Vitisseve vā.
analyzed: vi tis seve vā
translated: . Vitisseve vā.

original: Evasadde pare itissa vo hoti vā. Itveva, icceva. Eveti kiṃ? Iccāha.
analyzed: eva sadde pare itissa vaḥ hoti vā itu eva icca iva eva iti kim icca āha
translated: Evasadde pare itissa vo hoti vā. Itveva, icceva. Eveti kiṃ? Iccāha.

original: 37. Eonama vaṇṇe.
analyzed: e o nama vaṇṇe
translated: . Eonama vaṇṇe.

original: Eonaṃ vaṇṇe kvaci a hoti vā. Disvā yācaka māgate, akaramhasa te, esa attho, esa dhammo,
analyzed: vaṇṇe kvaci a hoti vā disvā yācaka mā āgate akaramhasa te esa atthaḥ esa dhammo
translated: Eonaṃ vaṇṇe kvaci a hoti vā. Disvā yācaka māgate, akaramhasa te, esa attho, esa dhammo,

original: aggamakkhāyati, svātanaṃ, hiyyattanaṃ, karassu. Vātveva? Yācake āgate eso dhammo. Vaṇṇeti kiṃ? So.
analyzed: aggam akkhāyati svātanam hiyyattanam karassu vātvā iva yācake āgate esaḥ dhammo vaṇṇeti kim so
translated: aggamakkhāyati, svātanaṃ, hiyyattanaṃ, karassu. Vātveva? Yācake āgate eso dhammo. Vaṇṇeti kiṃ? So.

original: 38. Niggahītaṃ.
analyzed: niggahītam
translated: . Niggahītaṃ.

original: Niggahītamāgamo hoti vā kvaci. Cakkhuṃ udapādi cakkhuudapādi, purimaṃ jātiṃ purimajātiṃ,
analyzed: niggahītam āgamaḥ hoti vā kvaci cakkhum udapādi cakkhu udapādi purimam jātim purima jātim
translated: Niggahītamāgamo hoti vā kvaci. Cakkhuṃ udapādi cakkhuudapādi, purimaṃ jātiṃ purimajātiṃ,🔽.

original: kattabbaṃ kusalaṃ bahuṃ. Avaṃsirotiādīsu niccaṃ… vavatthitavibhāsattā vādhikārassa,
analyzed: kattabbam kusalam bahum avaṃsiraḥ iti ādīsu niccam vavatthita vibhāsa ttā vā adhikārassa
translated: In the words avaṃsiroti, etc., the vowel of the reduplicate is always long, because of the special rule.

original: sāmattiyenāgamova, sa ca rassa sarasseva hoti… tassa rassānugatattā.
analyzed: sāmattiyena āgamaḥ uva sa ca rassa sa rassā iva hoti tassa
translated: The vowel is long by the power of the reduplicate, and that is long only of a short vowel … because it is connected with a long vowel.

original: 39. Lopo.
analyzed: lopaḥ
translated: The vowel is elided.

original: Niggahītassa lopo hoti vā kvaci. Kyāhaṃ kimahaṃsāratto saṃratto. Salle kho-gantukāmo gantumanoti, ādīsu niccaṃ.🔽40. Parasarassa.
analyzed: niggahītassa lopaḥ hoti vā kvaci kyā aham kim aham sāratto saṃratto ādīsu niccam  para sarassa
translated: The vowel of the reduplicate is elided before a vowel, sometimes. Kyāhaṃ, kimahaṃ, sāratto, saṃratto, kho, gantukāmo, gantumano, etc.

original: Niggahītamhā parassa sarassa lopo hoti vā kvaci. Tvaṃ-si tvamasi.🔽41. Vagge vagganto.🔽Niggahītassa kho vagge vagganto vā hoti paccāsattyā. Taṅkaroti taṃ karoti, tañcarati
analyzed: niggahītamhā parassa sarassa lopaḥ hoti vā kvaci tvam si tvam asi  vagge vagga antaḥ  niggahītassa kho vagge vagga antaḥ vā hoti paccāsattyā tam karoti tam karoti tam carati
translated: The vowel of the reduplicate is elided before the vowel of another word, sometimes. Tvaṃ-si, tvamasi.🔽The reduplicate is repeated in a group.

original: taṃ carati, taṇṭhānaṃ taṃ ṭhānaṃ, tandhanaṃ taṃ dhanaṃ, tampāti taṃ pāti. Niccaṃ
analyzed: tam carati tat ṭhānam tat ṭhānam tat dhanam tam dhanam tam pāti tam pāti niccam
translated: The reduplicate is repeated in a group, sometimes, by the rule. Taṅkaroti, taṃ karoti, tañcarati, taṃ carati, taṇṭhānaṃ, taṃ ṭhānaṃ, tandhanaṃ, taṃ dhanaṃ, tampāti, taṃ pāti. Always

original: padamajjhe gantvā, kvacaññātrapi santiṭṭhati.
analyzed: pada majjhe gantvā santiṭṭhati
translated: after going in the middle of the word, sometimes it stands elsewhere too.

original: 42. Yevahisu ño.
analyzed: ye va hi su ñaḥ
translated: The vowel is ño in the words yeva, hi.

original: Ya eva hi saddesu niggahītassa vā ño hoti. Yaññadeva, taññeva, tañhi, vātveva? Yaṃ yadeva.
analyzed: yaḥ eva hi saddesu niggahītassa vā ñaḥ hoti yaṃ yad eva
translated: The vowel of the reduplicate is ño, sometimes, in the words yeva and hi. Yaññadeva, taññeva, taṃhi, vātveva. Yaṃ yadeva.

original: 43. Ye saṃssa.
analyzed: ye saṃssa
translated: 43. Ye saṃssa.

original: Saṃsaddassa yaṃ niggahītaṃ tassa vā ño hoti yakāre. Saññamo saṃyamo.
analyzed: saṃsaddassa yam niggahītam tassa vā ñaḥ hoti yakāre saññamaḥ saṃyamaḥ
translated: The ya of saṃsadda has ño or ya when it is checked. Saññamo, saṃyamo.

original: 44. Mayadā sare.
analyzed: mayadā sare
translated: . Mayadā sare.

original: Niggahītassa mayadā honti vā sare kvaci. Tamahaṃ, tayidaṃ, tadalaṃ. Vā tveva? Taṃ ahaṃ.
analyzed: niggahītassa maya dāḥ honti vā sare kvacid tam aham tayidam tat alam vā tu eva tam aham
translated: The mayadā of niggahīta are optionally added to saras, or not. Tamahaṃ, tayidaṃ, tadalaṃ. Or not? Taṃ ahaṃ.

original: 45. Vanataragā cāgamā.
analyzed: vanataragā ca āgamā
translated: . Vanataragā cāgamā.

original: Ete mayadā ca āgamā honti sare vā kvaci. Tivaṅgikaṃ, ito nāyati, cinitvā, tasmātiha,
analyzed: ete mayadā ca āgamāḥ honti sare vā kvacid tivaṅgikam itas na āyati cinitvā tasmāt atiha
translated: These mayadā and āgamā are optionally added to saras, or not. Tivaṅgikaṃ, ito nāyati, cinitvā, tasmātiha,

original: nirojaṃ, puthageva, idhamāhu, yathayidaṃ, attadatthaṃ. Vā tveva? Attatthaṃ. ‘Atippago
analyzed: nirojam puthak eva attadattham vā tu eva attattham atippago
translated: nirojaṃ, puthageva, idhamāhu, yathayidaṃ, attadatthaṃ. Or not? Attatthaṃ. ‘Atippago

original: kho tāvā’ti-paṭhamanto pagasaddova.
analyzed: kho tāva ati paṭhama antaḥ paga saddo va
translated: kho tāvā’ti-paṭhamanto pagasaddova.

original: 46. Chā ḷo.
analyzed: chā ḷo
translated: . Chā ḷo.

original: Chasaddā parassa sarassa ḷakāro āgamo hoti vā. Chaḷaṅgaṃ, chaḷāyatanaṃ. Vātveva? Chaabhiññā.
analyzed: cha saddā parassa sarassa ḷakāraḥ āgamaḥ hoti vā chaṭ aṅgam chaṭ āyatanam cha abhiññā
translated: The ḷ of chā is added to the saras of parassa, optionally. Chaḷaṅgaṃ, chaḷāyatanaṃ. Or not? Chaabhiññā.

original: 47. Tadaminādīni.
analyzed: tad ami nādīni
translated: . Tadaminādīni.

original: Tadaminādīni sādhūni bhavanti. Taṃ iminā tadaminā, sakiṃ āgāmī sakadāgāmī, ekaṃ idha
analyzed: tadaminā ādīni sādhūni bhavanti tam iminā tadaminā āgāmī sakadāgāmī ekam
translated: Tadaminādīni are good. Taṃ iminā tadaminā, sakiṃ āgāmī sakadāgāmī, ekaṃ idha

original: ahaṃ ekamidāhaṃ, saṃvidhāya avahāro saṃvidāvahāro, vārino vāhako valāhako, jīvanassa
analyzed: aham ekam ida aham saṃvidhāya avahāraḥ saṃvidāvahāraḥ vārinaḥ vāhakaḥ valāhakaḥ jīvanassa
translated: I am one. I have made a single day. A taking away after having made an agreement is a saṃvidāvahāra. A carrier of water is a vāhako. A valāhako is a carrier of water. Of life

original: mūto jīmūto, chavassa sayanaṃ susānaṃ, uddhaṃ khamassa udukkhalaṃ, pisitāso pisāco,
analyzed: mūtaḥ jīmūtaḥ chavassa sayanam su sānam uddham khamassa udukkhalam pisitāsaḥ pisācaḥ
translated: A mūto is a jīmūto. A bed of the dead is a susāna. A pestle is an udukkhalaṃ. A pisitāso is a pisāco.

original: mahiyaṃ ravatīti mayūro, evamaññepi payogato-nugantabbā, paresaṃ pisodarādimivedaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: mahiyam ravati iti mayūraḥ evam aññe pi payogataḥ nugantabbā paresam daṭṭhabbam
translated: One who cries out in the earth is a mayūro. So too in other instances it should be understood by the method. This should be seen as the same as the other’s pisodarā, etc.

original: 48. Tavaggavaraṇānaṃ ye cavaggabayañā.
analyzed: ta vagga vara ṇānam ye ca vagga bayañā
translated: . In the case of the words of the Tavaggavaraṇas, the cavaggabayañā.

original: Tavaggavaraṇānaṃ kvaci cavaggabayañā honti yathākkamaṃ yakāre. Apuccaṇḍatāya, tacchaṃ, yajjevaṃ, ajjhattaṃ, thaññaṃ, dibbaṃ, payyosanā, pokkharañño. Kvacitveva? Rattyā
analyzed: ta vagga varaṇānam kvaci ca vagga bayañāḥ honti yathākkamam yakāre a puccaṇḍa tāya taccham yat jevam ajjhattam thaññam dibbam payyosanā pokkharañño kvaci tvā eva rattyā
translated: In the case of the words of the Tavaggavaraṇas, the cavaggabayañā are sometimes yakāras. They are tacchaṃ, yajjevaṃ, ajjhattaṃ, thaññaṃ, dibbaṃ, payyosanā, pokkharañño. Where are they not? In rattyā.

original: 49. Vaggalasehi te.
analyzed: vagga lasehi te
translated: . They are with the vaggalas.

original: Vaggalasehi parassa yakārassa kvaci te vaggalasā honti.
analyzed: vagga lasehi parassa yakārassa kvaci te vagga lasāḥ honti
translated: With the vaggalas, in some instances the yakāras of another are vaggalas.

original: Sakkate, paccate, aṭṭate, kuppate, phallate, assate. Kvacitveva? Kyāhaṃ.
analyzed: sakkate paccate aṭṭate kuppate phallate assate kvaci tu eva kyā aham
translated: They are sakkate, paccate, aṭṭate, kuppate, phallate, assate. Where are they not? In kyāhaṃ.

original: 50. Hassa vipallāso.
analyzed: hassa vipallāsaḥ
translated: . The hassa is inverted.

original: Hassa vipallāso hoti yakāre. Guyhaṃ.
analyzed: vipallāsaḥ hoti yakāre guyham
translated: The hassa is inverted in the yakāra. It is guyhaṃ.

original: 51. Ve vā.
analyzed: ve vā
translated: . Or ve.

original: Hassa vipallāso hoti vā vakāre. Bavhābādho bavhābādho.
analyzed: hassa vipallāsaḥ hoti vā vakāre bavhābādhaḥ bavhābādhaḥ
translated: The addition of the letter ba is in the case of the letter a.

original: 52. Tathānarānaṃ ṭaṭhaṇalā
analyzed: ṭa ṭha ṇa lā
translated: The addition of the letter ṭhaṇala is in the case of the letters tathana.

original: Tathanarānaṃ ṭaṭhaṇalā honti vā. Dukkaṭaṃ, aṭṭhakathā, gahaṇaṃ, paligho, palāyati. Vātveva? Dukkataṃ. Kvacitveva? Sugato.
analyzed: honti vā dukkaṭam aṭṭha kathā gahaṇam palighaḥ palāyati vā tu eva dukkatam kvaci tu eva sugataḥ
translated: The addition of the letter ṭhaṇala is in the case of the letters tathana. Dukkataṃ, aṭṭhakathā, gahaṇaṃ, paligho, palāyati. Vātveva? Dukkataṃ. Kvacitveva? Sugato.

original: 53. Saṃyogādi lopo.
analyzed: saṃyoga ādi lopaḥ
translated: The elision of the letter sa and so on.

original: Saṃyogassa yo ādībhūto-vayavo tassa vā kvaci lopo hoti. Pupphaṃ-sā jāyate-gini.
analyzed: saṃyogassa yaḥ ādībhūta uvayavo tassa vā kvaci lopaḥ hoti pupphaṃsā
translated: The elision of the letter sa is in the case of the letter that is the first part of a compound. Pupphaṃ-sā jāyate-gini.

original: 54. Vicchābhikkhaññesu dve.
analyzed: vicchā bhikkhaññesu dve
translated: Two in the case of vicchā and abhikkhañña.

original: Vicchāyamābhikkhaññe ca yaṃ vattate, tassa dve rūpāni honti. Kriyāya guṇena dabbena
analyzed: ca yam vattate tassa dve rūpāni honti kriyāya guṇena dabbena
translated: Two forms are used in the case of vicchā and abhikkhañña. Kriyāya guṇena dabbena

original: vā bhinne atthe byāpitumicchā vicchā. Rukkhaṃ rukkhaṃ siñcati, gāmo gāmo ramaṇīyo,
analyzed: vā bhinne atthe byāpitum icchā vicchā rukkham rukkham siñcati gāmaḥ gāmaḥ ramaṇīyaḥ
translated: vā bhinne atthe byāpitumicchā vicchā. Rukkhaṃ rukkhaṃ siñcati, gāmo gāmo ramaṇīyo,

original: gāme gāme pānīyaṃ, gehe gehe issaro, rasaṃ rasaṃ bhakkhayati, kiriyaṃ kiriyamārabhate.
analyzed: gāme gāme pānīyam gehe gehe issaraḥ rasam rasam bhakkhayati kiriyam kiriyam ārabhate
translated: gāme gāme pānīyaṃ, gehe gehe issaro, rasaṃ rasaṃ bhakkhayati, kiriyaṃ kiriyamārabhate.

original: Atthiyevā-nupubbiyepi vicchā mūle mūle thūlā, agge agge sukhumā, yadi hi ettha mūlaggabhedo
analyzed: vicchā mūle mūle thūlā agge agge sukhumā yadi hi ettha mūla agga bhedaḥ
translated: Atthiyevā-nupubbiyepi vicchā mūle mūle thūlā, agge agge sukhumā, yadi hi ettha mūlaggabhedo

original: na siyā, ānupubbiyampi na bhaveyya. Māsakaṃ māsakaṃ imamhā kahāpaṇā bhavanthānaṃ
analyzed: na siyā ānupubbiyam pi na bhaveyya māsakam māsakam imamhā kahāpaṇā bhavanthānam
translated: and it would not be so. And if it were in order, it would not be so.🔽Give two of these kahāpaṇas for each māsaka.

original: dvinnaṃ dehīti māsakaṃ māsakamiccetasmā vicchāgamyate, saddantarato pana imamhā kahāpaṇāti
analyzed: dvinnam dehi iti māsakam māsakam icca itasmai vicchā gamyate pana imamhā
translated: But the restriction is from saddantarato imamhā kahāpaṇā.

original: avadhāraṇaṃ. Pubbaṃ pubbaṃ pupphanti, paṭhamaṃ paṭhamaṃ paccantītyatrāpi vicchāva.
analyzed: avadhāraṇam pubbam pubbam pupphanti paṭhamam paṭhamam paccanti iti atra api vicchāva
translated: The first of the first ripen, the first of the first are cooked. Here too there is a break.

original: Ime ubho aḍḍhā katarā katarā esaṃ dvinnamaḍḍhatā, sabbe ime aḍḍhā katamā katamā imesaṃ
analyzed: ime ubho aḍḍhā katarā katarā esam dvinnam aḍḍha tā sabbe ime aḍḍhā katamā katamā imesam
translated: Which of these two is the double of which? All of these are doubled. Which of these

original: aḍḍhutā ihāpi vicchāva. Ābhikkhaññaṃ ponopuññaṃ pacati pacati, papacati papacati,
analyzed: iha api vicchāvaḥ ābhikkhaññam ponopuññam pacati pacati papacati papacati
translated: is the doubling? Here too there is a break. He cooks by going forward and back, again and again. He cooks, he cooks. He cooks well, he cooks well.

original: lunāhi lunāhitvevāyaṃ lunāti, bhutvā bhutvā gacchati, paṭapaṭā karoti, paṭapaṭāyati.🔽55. Syādilopo pubbassekassa.
analyzed: lunāhi lunāhi tvā iva ayam lunāti bhutvā bhutvā gacchati paṭapaṭā karoti paṭapaṭāyati 🔽sya ādi lopaḥ pubbassa ikassa
translated: He cuts, he cuts. Having eaten, having eaten, he goes. He makes patapatā, he makes patapatā.

original: Vicchāyamekassa dvitte pubbassa syādilopo hoti. Ekekassa. Kathaṃ matthakamatthakenāti? ‘Syādilopo pubbassā’ti yogavibhāgā, nācātippasaṅgo yogavibhāgā iṭṭhappasiddhīti.
analyzed: vicchāyam ekassa dvitte pubbassa syādi lopaḥ hoti ekekassa katham matthaka matthakena ati syādi lopo pubbassa ati yogavibhāgāḥ yogavibhāgāḥ iṭṭha ppasiddhi iti
translated: In the case of the first of two words, there is elision of the first syllable. Of each. How is it that the head is with the head? ‘Elision of the first syllable of the first’ is a division of the compound; the inclusion of the ‘na’ is a division of the compound, and the establishment of the desired sense.

original: 56. Sabbādīnaṃ vītihāre.
analyzed: sabba ādīnam vītihāre
translated: . In the case of the removal of all, etc.

original: Sabbādīnaṃ vītihāre dve bhavanti pubbassa syādilopo ca. Aññamaññassa bhojakā, itarītarassa bhojakā.
analyzed: sabba ādīnam vītihāre dve bhavanti pubbassa ca aññam aññassa bhojakāḥ itari itarassa bhojakā
translated: In the case of the removal of all, etc., there are two: elision of the first syllable of the first, and the eater of each other, the eater of the other.

original: 57. Yāvabodhaṃ sambhame.🔽Turitenāpāyahetupadassanaṃ sambhamo, tasmiṃsati vatthu yāvantehi saddehi so-ttho
analyzed: yā avabodham sambhame  turitena apāya hetu padassanam sambhamaḥ tasmin sati vatthu yāvantehi saddehi sotthaḥ
translated: . In the case of the combination up to the understanding.

original: viññāyate, tāvanto saddā payujjante. Sappo sappo sappo, bujjhassu bujjhassu bujjhassu,
analyzed: viññāyate tāvantaḥ saddāḥ payujjante sappaḥ sappaḥ sappaḥ bujjhassu bujjhassu
translated: The appearance of the reason for the swift going is the combination; in that, as many words as the meaning is understood by, that many words are used. Snake, snake, snake; wake up, wake up, wake up;

original: bhinno bhikkhusaṅgho bhinno bhikkhusaṅgho.
analyzed: bhinnaḥ bhikkhu saṅghaḥ bhinnaḥ bhikkhu saṅghaḥ
translated: the Community of monks is split, the Community of monks is split.

original: 58. Bahulaṃ.
analyzed: bahulam
translated: . In the case of the frequent.

original: Ayamadhikāro āsatthaparisamattiyā. Tena nātippasaṅgo iṭṭhappasiddhi ca.
analyzed: ayam adhikāraḥ āsattha parisamattiyā tena na atippasaṅgaḥ ca
translated: This is the scope of the completion of the meaning of the statement. Therefore there is no inclusion of the ‘na’ and the establishment of the desired sense.

original: Iti moggallāne byākaraṇe vuttiyaṃ
analyzed: iti moggallāne byākaraṇe vuttiyam
translated: Thus in the commentary on the grammar of Moggallāna

original: Paṭhamo kaṇḍo.
analyzed: paṭhamaḥ kaṇḍaḥ
translated: The first chapter.

original: 2. Dutiyo kaṇḍo (syādi)
analyzed: dutiyaḥ kaṇḍaḥ syādi
translated: . The second chapter (syādi)🔽.

original: 1. Dve dve-kānekesu nāmasmā si yo, aṃ yo, nā hi, sa naṃ, smā hi, sa naṃ, smiṃ su.
analyzed: dve dvi ika anekesu si yaḥ hi sa nam hi sa nam smin su
translated: 1. In the two and the one and the many, from the noun, the si, the yo, the aṃ, the hi, the sa, the naṃ, the smā, the hi, the sa, the naṃ, the smiṃ, the su.

original: Etesaṃ dve dve honti ekānekatthesu vattamānato nāmasmā. Muni munayo, muniṃ munayo,
analyzed: etesam dve dve honti eka aneka atthesu vattamānataḥ nāmasmai muni munayaḥ munim munayaḥ
translated: These two and two are in the two and the one and the many, from the noun. Sage, sages, sage, sages,

original: muninā munīhi, munissa munīnaṃ, munismā munīhi, munissa munīnaṃ, munismiṃ munīsu,
analyzed: muninā munīhi munissa munīnam munisma munīhi munissa munīnam munismin munīsu
translated: by the sage, by the sages, of the sage, of the sages, by the sage, by the sages, of the sage, of the sages, in the sage, in the sages,

original: evaṃ kumārī kumāriyo, kaññā kaññāyoti. Etāni satta dukāni satta vibhattiyo vibhāgo
analyzed: evam kumārī kumāriyo kaññā kaññāyo ti etāni satta dukāni satta vibhattiyaḥ vibhāgaḥ
translated: thus maiden, maidens, girl, girls. These seven duals, the seven cases, the analysis

original: vibhatīti katvā, ettha siamitī-kārā-kārā “kimaṃ sisu” 2,200 ti saṃketatthā.
analyzed: katvā ettha si am iti īkāra ākārā kimam si su ti saṃketatthā
translated: having been done, here the si and the mi and the i and the a and the u and the e and the o are the meaning of the convention.

original: 2. Kamme dutiyā.
analyzed: kamme dutiyā
translated: . In the second case in the verb.

original: Karīyati kattu kiriyāyā-bhisambandhīyatīti kammaṃ, tasmiṃ dutiyāvibhatti hotaṃ. Kaṭaṃ karoti, odanaṃ pacati, ādiccaṃ passati.
analyzed: karīyati kattu kiriyāya abhisambandhīyati iti kammam tasmin dutiyā vibhatti hotam kaṭam karoti odanam pacati ādiccam passati
translated: It is done, it is made, it is connected with the action by the doer, thus it is the object, in that the second case is. He makes a pot, he cooks rice, he sees the sun.

original: ‘Odano paccatī’ti odanasaddato kammatā nappatīyate, kiñcarahi? Ākhyātato. ‘Kaṭaṃ
analyzed: odanaḥ paccati iti odana saddataḥ kamma tā na ppatīyate kiñcarahi ākhyātataḥ kaṭam
translated: ‘Rice is cooked’ is not understood from the word ‘rice’ as the object, but rather from the verb. ‘Pot🔽.

original: karoti vipulaṃ dassanīya’nti attheva guṇayuttassa kammatā, icchitepi kammattāva dutiyā
analyzed: karoti vipulam atthā iva guṇa yuttassa kamma tā icchite pi kamma ttā ava dutiyā
translated: and he makes a great deal of milk to be seen’—thus the function of the one possessing the qualities is established.

original: siddhā gāvuṃ payo dohati, gomantaṃ gāvaṃ yācati, gāvamavarundhati vajaṃ, māṇavakaṃ🔽maggaṃ pucchati, gomantaṃ gāvaṃ bhikkhate, rukkhamavacināti phalāni, sissaṃ dhammaṃ
analyzed: siddhāḥ gāvum payaḥ dohati gomantam gāvam yācati gāvam avarundhati vajam māṇavakam  maggam pucchati gomantam gāvam bhikkhate rukkham avacināti phalāni sissam dhammaṃ
translated: Even though the function is not intended, it is still established: ‘He milks the cow with the calf’, ‘He asks for the cow with the calf’, ‘He ties up the cow with the calf’, ‘He gives the calf to the young man’,🔽‘He asks the young man about the road’, ‘He begs for the cow with the calf’, ‘He orders the fruit from the tree’, ‘He teaches the Dhamma to the pupil’, ‘He instructs the pupil in the Dhamma’.

original: brūte, sissaṃ dhammamanusāsatīti. Evaṃ anicchitepi ahiṃ laṅghayati, visaṃ bhakkheti.
analyzed: brūte sissam dhammam anusāsati iti evam an icchite api ahim laṅghayati visam bhakkheti
translated: Thus even though the function is not intended, it is still established: ‘He crosses the snake’, ‘He eats the poison’.

original: Yaṃnevicchitaṃ nāpi anicchitaṃ, tatthāpi dutiyā siddhā. Gāmaṃ gacchanto rukkhamūlamupasappati.
analyzed: yaṃneva icchitam na api an icchitam tattha api dutiyā siddhā gāmam gacchantaḥ rukkha mūlam upasappati
translated: And where neither is intended nor not intended, there too the second is established: ‘Going to the village, he approaches the foot of the tree’,

original: Pathaviṃ adhisessati, gāmamadhitiṭṭhati, rukkhamajjhāsatetiadhisīṭhāsānaṃpayoge-dhikaraṇe
analyzed: pathavim adhisessati gāmam adhitiṭṭhati rukkham ajjhāsata iti adhisīṭhāsānam payoga idhikaraṇe
translated: ‘He will lie down on the earth’, ‘He stands in the village’, ‘He sits in the middle of the tree’—in the case of the verbs ‘to lie down’, ‘to stand’, and ‘to sit’,

original: kammavacanicchā, vatticchāto hi kārakāni honti. Taṃ yathā-valāhakā vijjotate, valāhakassa
analyzed: kamma vacanicchā vatti chātaḥ hi kārakāni honti tam yathā valāhakā vijjotate valāhakassa
translated: the function is intended in the instrumental case. For the cases are formed from the function of the verb. That is to say: ‘The cloud thunders’, ‘The cloud lightens’,

original: vijjotate, valāhako vijjotate, valāhake vijjotate, valāhakena vijjotateti. Evamabhinivisassa
analyzed: vijjotate valāhakaḥ vijjotate valāhake vijjotate valāhakena vijjotate iti evam abhinivisassa
translated: and the cloud, and the lightning, and the lightning flash, and the lightning streak.

original: vā dhammamabhinivisate dhamme vā.🔽Tathā upanvajjhāvasassābhojana nivuttivacanassa gāmamupavasati, ga, mamanuvasati,
analyzed: vā dhammam abhinivisate dhamme vā  tathā gāmam upavasati gamam anuvasati
translated: So too with the word abhinivisati: he misconstrues a visible datum, or he misconstrues ideas.🔽So too with the word upanvajjati: he lies in wait for a visible datum, or he lies in wait for ideas.🔽So too with the word nivut: he lies in wait in a village, he lies in wait on a mountain, he lies in wait in a house.

original: pabbatamadhivasati, gharamāvasati. Abhojananivutti vacanassāti kiṃ? Gāme upavasati,
analyzed: pabbatam adhivasati gharam āvasati abhojana nivutti vacanassa ati kim gāme upavasati
translated: So too with the word āvasati: he lies in wait in a village,

original: bhojananivuttiṃ karotīti attho. Tappānācārepi kammattāva dutiyā siyā nadimpivati,
analyzed: bhojana nivuttim karoti iti dutiyā siyā
translated: he lies in wait for food.

original: gāmaṃ carati, evaṃ ‘sace maṃ ālapissatī’tiādīsupi. Vihitāva patidhayoge dutiyā –
analyzed: gāmam carati evam sace mama ālapissati iti ādīsu pi vihitā ava pa tidha yoge dutiyā
translated: So too with the word carati: he roams in a village, he roams in a river, he roams in a forest.

original: ‘paṭibhantu taṃ cunda bojjhaṅgā’ti. Taṃ pati bojjhaṅgā bhāsantūti attho, yadātu dhātunāyutto🔽pati, tadā tenā-yogā sambandhe chaṭṭhīva ‘tassa nappaṭibhātī’ti. Akkhe dibbati, akkhehi
analyzed: tam cunda bojjhaṅgā ati tam bojjhaṅgāḥ bhāsantu uti atthaḥ dhātunā ayuttaḥ  tadā tena ayogā sambandhe chaṭṭhī iva tassa na paṭibhāti iti akkhe dibbati akkhehi
translated: So too with the word paṭibhantu: the factors of enlightenment are his, he has the factors of enlightenment, the factors of enlightenment are manifest to him.

original: dibbati, akkhesu dibbatīti kammakaraṇādhikaraṇavacanicchā.
analyzed: dibbati akkhesu dibbati iti kamma karaṇa adhikaraṇa vacanicchā
translated: So too with the word dibbati: he throws the dice, he throws with the dice, he throws at the dice.

original: 3. Kāladdhānamaccantasaṃyoge.
analyzed: kāla d dhāna mac canta saṃyoge
translated: 3. The connection of time with a noun in the sense of ‘during’ is by means of the function, the quality, and the instrument.

original: Kiriyā, guṇa, dabbehi sākallena kāladdhānaṃ sambandho accantasaṃyogo. Tasmiṃ viññāyamāne
analyzed: kiriyā guṇa dabbehi sākallena sambandhaḥ tasmin viññāyamāne
translated: The connection of time with a noun in the sense of ‘during’ is by means of the function, the quality, and the instrument. When that is recognized,

original: kālasaddehi addhaaddehi ca dutiyā hoti. Māsamadhīte, māsaṃ kalyāṇi, māsaṃ guḷadhānā,
analyzed: kālasaddehi addhaaddehi ca dutiyā hoti māsam adhīte māsam kalyāṇi māsam guḷa dhānā
translated: the second case is formed with the words for time and with the words for half, etc. He studied for a month, the good woman for a month, the sugar for a month,🔽he studied for a kos, the crooked river for a kos, the rock for a kos.

original: kosamadhīte, kosaṃ kuṭilā nadī, kosaṃ pabbato. Acantasaṃyogeti kiṃ? Māsassa dvīhamadhīte,
analyzed: kosam adhīte kosam kuṭilā nadī kosam pabbataḥ kim māsassa dvīham adhīte
translated: What? He studied for two months of the month,

original: kosassekadese pabbato.
analyzed: kosassa ika dese pabbataḥ
translated: the rock in one place of the kos.

original: Pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā, ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā, imaṃ rattiṃ cattāro mahārājāti evamādīsu kālavācī hi accantasaṃyogattāva dutiyā siddhā. Vibhattivipallāsenapi vā bahulaṃvidhānā.
analyzed: pubbaṇha samayam nivāsetvā ekam samayam bhagavā imam rattim cattāraḥ mahā rājā iti evamādīsu kāla vācī hi dutiyā siddhā vibhatti vipallāsena api vā bahulam vidhānā
translated: Having dressed in the morning, at one time the Blessed One, this night the four Great Kings—in such passages as these the second case is established by the connection of time in the sense of ‘during’ because of the connection of time with the words for time. Or it is often by the inversion of the case-ending.

original: Phalappattiyaṃ kiriyāparisamattyapavaggo, tasmiṃ viññāyamāne kāladdhānaṃ kiriyāyāccantasaṃyoge
analyzed: phala ppattiyam kiriyā parisamatti apavaggo tasmin viññāyamāne kāla ddhānam
translated: In the acquisition of fruit, the function, the equality, and the instrument are the section. When that is recognized, the connection of time with a noun in the sense of ‘during’ is by means of the function, the quality, and the instrument.

original: tatiyābhimatā, sāpi karaṇattāva siddhā ‘māsenānuvāko-dhīto, kosenānuvāko-dhīto’ti.
analyzed: tatiyā abhimatā sā api siddhā
translated: The third case is intended. That is also established by the instrument itself, ‘The recitation was learned by a month, the recitation was learned by a kos.’

original: Anapavaggetu asādhakatamattākaraṇattābhāve dutiyāva ‘māsamadhīto-nuvāko, na cāne na gahito’ti.
analyzed: an apavagge tu māsam adhītaḥ nuvākaḥ na ca ane na
translated: because of the absence of the non-fulfilment of the meaning of the cause, the second-mentioned is not accepted, though it has been learnt for two months, and is not grasped.

original: Kārakamajjhe ye kāladdhānavācino, tato sattamīpañcamiyo abhimatā ‘ajja bhutvā devadatto
analyzed: kāraka majjhe ye sattamī pañcamiyaḥ abhimatāḥ ajja bhutvā devadattaḥ
translated: In the middle of the cause, those that have the meaning of time as the object are the seventh and fifth cases, which are accepted, as in the following: ‘Having eaten today, Devadatta

original: dvihe bhuñjissati, dvīhā bhuñjissati, atraṭṭho-yamissāso kose lakkhaṃ vijjhati, kosā
analyzed: dvihe bhuñjissati dvīhā bhuñjissati kose lakkham vijjhati kosā
translated: will eat in two days, will eat in two days, here the profit of a hundred thousand is lost in the granary, from the granary

original: lakkhaṃ vijjhatī’ti, tāpīha sakasakakārakavacanicchāyeva siddhā.🔽4. Gati bodhāhāra saddatthākammaka bhajjādīnaṃ payojje.
analyzed: lakkham vijjhati iti tā api iha saka saka kāraka vacana icchāyā iva siddhā  gati bodha āhāra saddattha akammaka bhajja ādīnam payojje
translated: the profit of a hundred thousand is lost.’ These too are established by the desire for the respective cause.🔽The seventh case is used for the purpose of going, of understanding, of nourishing, of sound, of action, and of the class of ‘breaking’ and so on.

original: Gamanatthānaṃ bodhatthānaṃ āhāratthānaṃ saddatthānamakammakānaṃ bhajjādīnañca payojje
analyzed: gamana tthānam bodha tthānam āhāra tthānam sadda tthānam akammakānam bhajja ādīnam ca payojje
translated: The seventh case is used for the purpose of going, for the purpose of understanding, for the purpose of nourishing, for the purpose of sound, for the purpose of action, and for the class of ‘breaking’ and so on.

original: kattari dutiyā hoti. Sāmatthiyā ca payojakabyāpārena kammatāvassa hotīti patīyate.
analyzed: kattari dutiyā hoti sāmatthiyā ca payojaka byāpārena kamma tāvassa hoti iti patīyate
translated: It is understood that it is the second case in the maker, and that it is the seventh case in the action by the extension of the function of the cause.

original: Gamayati māṇavakaṃ gāmaṃ, yāpayati māṇavakaṃ gāmaṃ, bodhayati māṇavakaṃ dhammaṃ,
analyzed: gamayati māṇavakam gāmam yāpayati māṇavakam gāmam bodhayati māṇavakam dhammaṃ
translated: He makes the youth go to the village, he makes the youth live in the village, he makes the youth understand the Dhamma,

original: vedayati māṇavakaṃ dhammaṃ, bhojayati māṇa-vakaṃ modakaṃ, āsayati māṇavakaṃ modakaṃ,
analyzed: vedayati māṇavakam dhammam bhojayati māṇavakam modakam āsayati māṇavakam modakam
translated: He makes the young man feel, he makes the young man eat a sweetmeat, he makes the young man swallow a sweetmeat,

original: ajjhāpayati māṇavakaṃ vedaṃ, pāṭhayati māṇavakaṃ vedaṃ, āsayati devadattaṃ, sāyayati
analyzed: ajjhāpayati māṇavakam vedam pāṭhayati māṇavakam vedam āsayati devadattam sāyayati
translated: he makes the young man learn the Veda, he makes the young man recite the Veda, he makes Devadatta lie down, he makes Devadatta sleep,

original: devadattaṃ, aññaṃ bhajjāpeti, aññaṃ koṭṭāpeti, aññaṃ santharāpeti. Etesamevāti kiṃ?🔽Pāceti odanaṃ devadattena yaññadatto. Payojjeti kiṃ? Gacchati devadatto. Yadā carahi
analyzed: devadattam aññam bhajjāpeti aññam koṭṭāpeti aññam santharāpeti etesam eva ati kim  pāca iti odanam devadattena payojja iti kim gacchati devadattaḥ yadā carahi
translated: he makes Devadatta eat, he makes Devadatta chew. He makes Devadatta eat with whom?🔽He makes Devadatta eat rice. He makes Devadatta go. He makes Devadatta go with whom?🔽When he makes Devadatta go, he makes Devadatta go with another who is being sent. Then it should be said:

original: gamayati devadattaṃ yaññadatto, tamaparo payojeti, tadā gamayati devadattaṃ yaññadatteneti🔽bhavitabbaṃ … gamayatissā-gamanatthattā.
analyzed: gamayati devadattam tam aparaḥ tadā gamayati devadattam yaññadattena iti  bhavitabbam gamayatissa āgamana ttha ttā
translated: he makes Devadatta go with Devadatta.

original: 5. Harādīnaṃ vā.
analyzed: hara ādīnam vā
translated: . Or with Har and so on.

original: Harādīnaṃ payojje kattari dutiyā hoti vā. Hāreti bhāraṃ devadattaṃ devadatteneti
analyzed: hara ādīnam payojje kattari dutiyā hoti vā hāra iti bhāram devadattam devadattena iti
translated: With Har and so on, the second case is used for the one who is being sent. He makes Devadatta carry the load, he makes Devadatta carry the load with Devadatta,

original: vā, ajjhohāreti sattuṃ devadattaṃ devadatteneti vā, kāreti kaṭaṃ devadattaṃ devadatteneti
analyzed: vā ajjhohāreti sattum devadattam devadattena iti vā kāreti kaṭam devadattam devadattena iti
translated: he makes Devadatta eat the food, he makes Devadatta eat the food with Devadatta, he makes Devadatta make the cart, he makes Devadatta make the cart with Devadatta.

original: vā dassayate janaṃ rājaṃ janeneti vā, abhivādayate guruṃ devadattaṃ devadatteneti vā.
analyzed: vā dassayate janam rājam janena iti vā abhivādayate gurum devadattam devadattena iti vā
translated: or he shows the people to the king, or he shows the king to the people, or he pays homage to the elder, or he shows Devadatta to Devadatta.

original: 6. Na khādādīnaṃ.
analyzed: na khāda ādīnam
translated: Not with khādati, etc.

original: Khādādīnaṃ payojje kattari dutiyā na hoti. Khādayati devadattena, ādayati devadattena,
analyzed: khāda ādīnam payojje kattari dutiyā na hoti khādayati devadattena ādayati devadattena
translated: With khādati, etc., the second case is not used for the nominative in the sense of the instrument. He eats with Devadatta, he takes with Devadatta,

original: avha, payati devadattena, saddāyayati devadattena, kandayati devadattena, nāyayati devadattena.
analyzed: devadattena saddāyayati devadattena kandayati devadattena nāyayati devadattena
translated: he carries with Devadatta, he makes a sound with Devadatta, he makes weep with Devadatta, he leads with Devadatta.

original: (1) Vahissāniyantuke. Vāhayati bhāraṃ devadattena aniyantuketi kiṃ? Vāha-yati bhāraṃ balībadde.
analyzed: vahissa aniyantuke vāhayati bhāram devadattena a niyantukā iti kim vāhayati bhāram balībadde
translated: But with vāhati in the sense of ‘not guiding’. He causes to carry a load with Devadatta, not guiding. What? He causes to carry a load with oxen.

original: (2) Bhakkhissāhiṃ sāyaṃ. Bhakkhayati modake devadattena. Ahiṃsāyanti kiṃ? Bhakkhayati balībadde sassaṃ.
analyzed: sāyam bhakkhayati modake devadattena ahiṃsāyanti kim bhakkhayati balībadde sassam
translated: With bhakkhati in the sense of ‘not killing’. He causes to eat cakes with Devadatta. What? He causes to eat grain with oxen, not killing.

original: 7. Jhādīhi yuttā.
analyzed: jha ādīhi yuttā
translated: With jhāyati, etc., in the sense of ‘connected’.

original: Dhīādīhi yuttato dutiyā hoti. Dhiratthu maṃ pūtikāyaṃ, antarā ca rājagahaṃ antarā ca nālandaṃ, samādhānamantarena, mucalindamabhito saramiccādi, chaṭṭhiyāpavādo-yaṃ.
analyzed: dhī ādīhi dutiyā hoti pūtikāyam antarā ca rājagaham antarā ca nālandam samādhānam antarena mucalindam abhitas saram iccādi
translated: The second case is used when connected with jhāyati, etc. He is ashamed of me, of this putrid body. Between Rājagaha and Nāḷandā, between the two, with the interval of concentration, he went round the Mucalinda, etc. The sixth case is excluded in this.

original: 8. Lakkhaṇitthambhūtavicchāsvabhinā.
translated: 8. The Locative case is that which has the characteristic of a place.

original: Lakkhaṇādīsvatthesvabhinā yuttamhā dutiyā mahāti. Rukkhamabhi vijjotate vijju, sādhu devadatto mātaramabhi, rukkhaṃ rukkhamabhitiṭṭhati.
analyzed: lakkhaṇa ādīsu atthesu abhinā dutiyā rukkham abhi vijjotate vijju sādhu devadattaḥ mātaram abhi rukkham rukkham abhitiṭṭhati
translated: The Locative case is that which has the characteristic of a place, etc., and is coupled with the second case. The lightning flashes in the tree, it is good if Devadatta goes to his mother, the tree stands in the tree.

original: 9. Patiparīhi bhāge ca.🔽Patiparīhi yuttamhā lakkhaṇādīsu bhāge catthe dutiyā hoti. Rukkhaṃ pati vijjotate🔽vijju, sādhu devadatto mātaraṃ pati, rukkhaṃ rukkhaṃ pati tiṭṭhati, yadettha maṃ
analyzed: pati parīhi bhāge ca  pati parīhi yuttamhā lakkhaṇa ādīsu bhāge catthe dutiyā hoti rukkham pati vijjotate  vijju sādhu devadattaḥ mātaram pati rukkham rukkham pati tiṭṭhati yat ettha maṃ
translated: . The Allative case is that which has the characteristic of a direction.

original: pati siyā. Rukkhaṃ pari vijjotate vijju, sādhu devadatto mātaraṃ pari, rukkhaṃ rukkhaṃ
analyzed: pati siyā rukkham pari vijjotate vijju sādhu devadattaḥ mātaram pari rukkham rukkham
translated: The Allative case is that which has the characteristic of a direction, etc., and is coupled with the second case. The lightning flashes towards the tree, it is good if Devadatta goes to his mother, the tree stands towards the tree, as if I were there. The lightning flashes around the tree, it is good if Devadatta goes around his mother, the tree stands around the tree, as if I were there.

original: pari tiṭṭhati, yadettha maṃ pari siyā.🔽10. Anunā.🔽Lakkhaṇādīsvatthesvanunā yuttamhā dutiyā hoti. Rukkhamanu vijjotate vijju, saccakiriyamanu
analyzed: pari tiṭṭhati yat ettha mama pari siyā  anunā  lakkhaṇa ādīsu atthesu anunā dutiyā hoti rukkham anu vijju saccakiriyam anu
translated: . The Ablative case is that which has the characteristic of a source.

original: vuṭṭhi pāvassi, hetu ca lakkhaṇaṃ bhavati, sādhu devadatto mātaramanu, rukkhaṃ rukkhamanu
analyzed: vuṭṭhi pāvassi hetu ca lakkhaṇam bhavati sādhu devadattaḥ mātaram anu rukkham rukkham anu
translated: The Ablative case is that which has the characteristic of a source, etc., and is coupled with the second case. The lightning flashes from the tree, the rain fell from the cloud, the cause is the characteristic, it is good if Devadatta goes from his mother, the tree stands from the tree,

original: tiṭṭhati, yadettha maṃ anu siyā.
analyzed: tiṭṭhati yat ettha mama anu siyā
translated: stands, whatever there is here that is mine.

original: 11. Sahatthe.
analyzed: sahatthe
translated: . With (the locative case).

original: Sahatthe-nunā yuttamhā dutiyā hoti. Pabbatamanu senā tiṭṭhati.
analyzed: saha atthenunā yuttamhā dutiyā hoti pabbatam anu senā tiṭṭhati
translated: With (the locative case) yuttamhā dutiyā hoti. Pabbatamanu senā tiṭṭhati.

original: 12. Hīne.
analyzed: hīne
translated: . With (the ablative case).

original: Hīnatthe-nunā yuttamhā dutiyā hoti. Anu sāriputtaṃ paññavanto.
analyzed: dutiyā hoti anu sāriputtam paññavanto
translated: With (the ablative case) yuttamhā dutiyā hoti. Anu sāriputtaṃ paññavanto.

original: 13. Upena.
analyzed: upena
translated: . With (the instrumental case).

original: Hīnatthe upena yuttamhā dutiyā hoti. Upa sāriputtaṃ paññavantho.
analyzed: hīna atthe upena yuttamhā dutiyā hoti upa sāriputtam paññavantho
translated: With (the instrumental case) yuttamhā dutiyā hoti. Upa sāriputtaṃ paññavantho.

original: 14. Sattamyādhikye.
analyzed: sattamī ādhikye
translated: . With (the locative case) in excess.

original: Ādhikyatthe upena yuttamhā sattamī hoti. Upa khāriyaṃ doṇo.
analyzed: ādhikya atthe upena sattamī hoti upa khāriyam doṇo
translated: With (the locative case) in excess yuttamhā sattamī hoti. Upa khāriyaṃ doṇo.

original: 15. Sāmitte-dhinā.
analyzed: sāmittedhinā
translated: . With (the genitive case) in the sense of 'belonging to'.

original: Sāmibhāvatthe-dhinā yuttamhā sattamī hoti. Adhi brahmadatte pañcālā, adhi pañcālesu brahmadatto.
analyzed: sāmibhāvatthā idhinā sattamī hoti adhi brahmadatte pañcālāḥ adhi pañcālesu brahmadattaḥ
translated: With (the genitive case) in the sense of 'belonging to' yuttamhā sattamī hoti. Adhi brahmadatte pañcālā, adhi pañcālesu brahmadatto.

original: 16. Kattukareṇesu tatiyā.
analyzed: kattu kareṇesu tatiyā
translated: . With (the instrumental case) in the sense of 'doing'.

original: Kattari karaṇe ca kārake tatiyā hoti. Purisena kataṃ, asinā chindati. Pakatiyā-bhirūpo,
analyzed: kattari karaṇe ca kārake tatiyā hoti purisena katam asinā chindati
translated: With (the instrumental case) in the sense of 'doing' and 'instrument' tatiyā hoti. Purisena kataṃ, asinā chindati. Pakatiyā-bhirūpo,

original: gotthena gotamo, sumedho nāma nāmena, jātiyā sattavassikoti bhūdhātussa sambhavā
analyzed: gotthena gotamaḥ sumedhaḥ nāma nāmena jātiyā sattavassikaḥ ti bhūdhātussa sambhavā
translated: gotthena gotamo, sumedho nāma nāmena, jātiyā sattavassikoti bhūdhātussa sambhavā

original: karaṇe eva tatiyā. Evaṃ samena dhāvati visamena dhāvati, dvidoṇena dhaññaṃ kiṇāti,🔽pañcakena pasavo kiṇātīti.
analyzed: karaṇe eva tatiyā evam samena dhāvati visamena dhāvati dvi doṇena dhaññam kiṇāti  pañcakena pasavaḥ kiṇāti iti
translated: In the instrument case the locative is used. Thus: “He runs evenly, he runs unevenly”, “He buys grain by the drona”, “He buys cattle by the pen”.

original: 17. Sahatthena.
analyzed: sahatthena
translated: . With one’s own hand.

original: Sahatthena yoge tatiyā siyā. Puttena saha gato, puttena saddhiṃ āgato, tatiyāpi chaṭṭhīva appadhāne eva bhavati.
analyzed: sahatthena yoge tatiyā siyā puttena saha gataḥ puttena saddhim āgataḥ tatiyā api chaṭṭhī iva a padhāne eva bhavati
translated: In the instrument case the locative is used with “with one’s own hand”. Thus: “Gone with his son”, “Come with his son”. The locative is also used in the sixth case in the sense of “without”.

original: 18. Lakkhaṇe.
analyzed: lakkhaṇe
translated: . In the sense of a distinguishing mark.

original: Lakkhaṇe vattamānato tatiyā siyā. Tidaṇḍakena paribbājakamaddakkhī, akkhinā kāṇo, tena hi aṅgena aṅgino vikāro lakkhīyate.
analyzed: lakkhaṇe vattamānataḥ tatiyā siyā tidaṇḍakena paribbājaka maddakkhī akkhinā kāṇaḥ tena hi aṅgena aṅginaḥ vikāraḥ lakkhīyate
translated: In the sense of a distinguishing mark the locative is used in the present participle. Thus: “I saw the wanderer with three staves”, “One-eyed in the eye”, “By that part the alteration of the part is distinguished”.

original: 19. Hetumhi.
analyzed: hetumhi
translated: . In the sense of cause.

original: Takkiriyā yogge tatiyā siyā. Annena vasati, vijjāya yaso.
analyzed: takkiriyā yogge tatiyā siyā annena vasati vijjāya yaso
translated: In the sense of cause the locative is used in the instrument case. Thus: “He lives by alms”, “By knowledge there is glory”.

original: 20. Pañcamīṇe vā.
analyzed: pañcamīṇe vā
translated: . Or in the fifth case.

original: Iṇe hetumhi pañcamī hoti vā. Satasmā baddho, satena vā.
analyzed: iṇe hetumhi pañcamī hoti vā satasmā baddhaḥ satena vā
translated: In the sense of cause the locative is used in the fifth case. Thus: “Bound by a hundred”, “By a hundred”.

original: 21. Guṇe.
analyzed: guṇe
translated: . In the sense of a quality.

original: Paraṅgabhūte hetumhi pañcamī hoti vā. Jaḷattā baddho jaḷattena vā, paññāya mutto, hutvā abhāvatoaniccā, saṅkhāranirodhā viññāṇanirodho.
analyzed: paraṅga bhūte hetumhi pañcamī hoti vā jaḷattā baddhaḥ jaḷattena vā paññāya muttaḥ hutvā abhāvato aniccā saṅkhāra nirodhā viññāṇa nirodho
translated: In the sense of a quality the locative is used in the fifth case. Thus: “Bound by dullness”, “By dullness”, “Freed by wisdom”, “Impermanent by becoming, non-becoming”. “By the cessation of formations, the cessation of consciousness”.

original: 22. Chaṭṭhī hetvatthehi.
analyzed: chaṭṭhī hetu atthehi
translated: . In the sixth case in the sense of cause.

original: Hetvatthavācīhi yoge hetumhi chaṭṭhī siyā. Udarassa hetu, udarassa kāraṇā.🔽23. Sabbādito sabbā.
analyzed: hetu attha vācīhi yoge hetumhi chaṭṭhī siyā udarassa hetu udarassa kāraṇā  sabba āditaḥ sabbā
translated: In a copulative compound with a word denoting cause, the sixth case is used for the cause. The cause of the belly, the reason for the belly.

original: Hetvatthehi yoge sabbādīhi sabbā vibhattiyo honti. Ko hetu, kaṃ hetuṃ, kena hetunā,🔽kassa hetussa, kasmā hetusmā, kassa hetussa, kasmiṃ hetusmiṃ, kiṃ kāraṇaṃ, kena kāraṇena,
analyzed: hetu atthehi yoge sabba ādīhi sabbāḥ vibhattiyaḥ honti kaḥ hetu kam hetum kena hetunā  kassa hetussa kasmai hetusmai kassa hetussa kasmin hetusmin kim kāraṇam kena kāraṇena
translated: In a copulative compound with all, etc., all the case endings are used. What is the cause? What is the cause of what? By what cause?🔽Of what cause? Why? From what cause? Of what cause? In what cause? What is the reason? By what reason?

original: kiṃ nimittaṃ, kena nimittena, kiṃ payojanaṃ, kena payojanena iccevamādi. Hetvatthehītveva? Kena kataṃ.
analyzed: kim nimittam kena nimittena kim payojanam kena payojanena iti evamādi kena katam
translated: What is the reason? By what reason? What is the purpose? By what purpose? Thus, etc. In a copulative compound with a word denoting cause, the sixth case is used. By what was it done?

original: 24. Catutthī sampadāne.
analyzed: catutthī sampadāne
translated: The fourth case is used for the recipient.

original: Yassa sammā padīyate tasmiṃ catutthī siyā. Saṅghassa dadāti. Ādhāravivakkhāyaṃ sattamīpi siyā saṅghe dehi.
analyzed: yassa sammā padīyate tasmin catutthī siyā saṅghassa dadāti ādhāra vivakkhāyam sattamī pi siyā saṅghe dehi
translated: In the case of one to whom something is rightly given, the fourth case may be used. He gives to the Sangha. In the analysis of the support, the seventh case may also be used: Give to the Sangha.

original: 25. Tādatthye.
analyzed: tādatthye
translated: In the sense of that purpose.

original: Tasse-daṃ tadatthaṃ, tadatthabhāve jotanīye nāmasmā catutthī siyā. Sītassa paṭighātāya,
analyzed: tassa idam tad attham tad attha bhāve jotanīye nāmasmā catutthī siyā sītassa paṭighātāya
translated: This is the purpose of that, in the case of indicating the state of having that purpose, the fourth case may be used. For the prevention of cold,

original: atthāya hitāya (sukhāya) devamanussānaṃ, nālaṃ dārabharaṇāya, yūpāya dāru, pākāya vajatītvevamādi.
analyzed: atthāya hitāya sukhāya deva manussānam nālam dāra bharaṇāya yūpāya dāru pākāya vajati iti evamādi
translated: for the benefit, for the welfare, for the happiness of gods and humans, not enough for the support of a wife, wood for a sacrificial post, wood for cooking, thus, etc.

original: Kassa sāduṃ na ruccabhi, mā-yasmantānampi saṅghabhedo ruccittha, khamati saṅghassa,
analyzed: kassa sādum na saṅgha bhedaḥ rucca itthā khamati saṅghassa
translated: Whose is the sweet not pleasing? Let not a schism in the Community be pleasing to the venerable ones. Is the Community agreed?

original: bhattamassa nacchādesīti chaṭṭhī sambandhavacanicchāyaṃ, na cevaṃ virodho siyā sadisarūpattā,
analyzed: bhattam assa na chādesi iti chaṭṭhī na ca evam virodhaḥ siyā sadisa rūpa ttā
translated: In the sixth case of the expression of relationship, “He does not conceal the Community’s meal”, there would be no such contradiction, because of the similarity .

original: evaṃvidhesu ca sambandhassa saddikānumatattā, kassa vā tvaṃ dhammaṃ rocesīti atthamatte paṭhamā.
analyzed: evaṃvidhesu ca sambandhassa saddika anumata ttā kassa vā tvam dhammam rocesi iti attha matte paṭhamā
translated: And in such a case, because of the agreement of the relationship, “Whose Dhamma do you approve of?” is the first in the mere meaning.

original: Evamaññāpi vidhaññayyā, paratopi yathāgamaṃ.
analyzed: evam aññā api paratas pi yathāgamam
translated: So too in other cases, as in the text, “As it is heard from others”,

original: Rañño sataṃ dhāreti, rañño chattaṃ dhāretīti sambandhe chaṭṭhī, evaṃ rañño silāghate,
analyzed: raññaḥ satam dhāreti raññaḥ chattam dhāreti iti sambandhe chaṭṭhī evam raññaḥ silāghate
translated: “He bears the king’s hundred”, “He bears the king’s sunshade” : in the sixth case of relationship. So too, “the king’s stone box”,

original: rañño hanute, rañño upatiṭṭhate, rañño sapate, devāpi tassa pihayanti tādino, tassa
analyzed: raññaḥ hanute raññaḥ upatiṭṭhate raññaḥ sapate devā api tassa pihayanti tādinaḥ tassa
translated: “He serves the king”, “He attends on the king”, “He is loyal to the king”, “Even the gods envy him who is such”,🔽“To him, O Great Hero, if I were to be angry”,

original: kujjha mahāvīra, yadihaṃ tassa pakuppeyyaṃ, duhayati disānaṃ megho, yo mittānaṃ na
analyzed: kujjha mahāvīra tassa pakuppeyyam duhayati disānam meghaḥ yaḥ mittānam na
translated: “The cloud rains on the directions”, “He who does not deceive friends”,

original: dūbhati, yo appaduṭṭhassa narassa dussati, kyāhaṃ ayyānaṃ aparajjhāmi, issayanti
analyzed: dūbhati yaḥ appaduṭṭhassa narassa dussati kyā aham ayyānam aparajjhāmi issayanti
translated: “He who is hostile to the man who is not hostile”, “Do I offend the venerable ones?”, “They envy”,

original: samaṇānaṃ titthiyā, dhammena nayamānānaṃ kā usūyā rañño bhāgyamārajjhati, rañño bhāgyamikkhate,
analyzed: samaṇānam titthiyāḥ dhammena nayamānānam kā usūyā raññaḥ bhāgyam ārajjhati raññaḥ bhāgyam ikkhate
translated: The ascetics, the sectarians, when being led by the Dhamma, what envy is there of the King’s fortune that he loses? When the King’s fortune is proclaimed,

original: tena yācito ayācito vā tassa gāvo paṭisuṇāti, gāvo āsuṇāti, bhagavato paccassosuṃ,
analyzed: tena yācitaḥ a yācitaḥ vā tassa gāvaḥ paṭisuṇāti gāvaḥ āsuṇāti bhagavataḥ paccassosum
translated: whether asked or unasked, the cows listen to him, the cows hear him, the cows hear the Fortunate One,

original: hotu patigiṇāti, hotvanugiṇāti, ārocayāmi vo pativedayāmi vo, dhammaṃ te desessāmi,
analyzed: hotu pati giṇāti hotu anu giṇāti ārocayāmi vaḥ pati vedayāmi vaḥ dhammam te desessāmi
translated: let it be, he understands, let it be, he has understood, I announce to you, I make known to you, I will teach the Dhamma to you,

original: yathā vo bhagavā byākareyya, alaṃ te idha vāsena, kiṃ te jaṭāhi dummedha, arahati mallo mallassāti.
analyzed: yathā vaḥ bhagavā byākareyya alam te idha vāsena kim te dummedha arahati mallaḥ mallassa ati
translated: as the Fortunate One would explain, enough for you to live here, what is the use of your matted hair, fool, the Maller deserves a Maller.”

original: Jīvitaṃ tiṇāyapi na maññamānoti tādatthya catutthī, tiṇena yo attho tadatthāyapīti
analyzed: jīvitam tiṇāya api na maññamānā uti catutthī tiṇena yaḥ attho tad atthāya api iti
translated: “Not regarding life as worth more than a blade of grass” is the fourth (case) in the sense of that which is necessary, the meaning is: “for the sake of which (life) is not regarded as worth more than a blade of grass,”

original: attho, “yo ca sītañca uṇhañca, tiṇā bhiyyo na maññati” tiṇamiva jīvitaṃ maññamānoti🔽savisayāva vibhattiyo. Saggāya gacchatīti tādatthye catutthī, yo hi saggaṃ gacchati
analyzed: atthaḥ yaḥ ca sītañca uṇhañca tiṇā bhiyyas na maññati tiṇam iva jīvitam maññamānaḥ ti  sa visayā saggāya gacchati iti tādatthye catutthī yaḥ hi saggam gacchati
translated: “He who does not regard cold or heat as worth more than a blade of grass” (thinking) “life is like a blade of grass,”🔽the case endings are as usual. “He goes to heaven” is the fourth (case) in the sense of that which is necessary, for he who goes to heaven

original: tadatthaṃ tassa gamananti, kammavacanicchāyantu dutiyāva saggaṃ gacchatīti.
analyzed: tad attham tassa gamanan ti saggam gacchati iti
translated: the meaning is: “for the sake of which there is his going,” but in the case of the verbal noun the second (case) is usual: “he goes to heaven.”

original: Āyu bhoto hotu, ciraṃ jīvitaṃ, bhaddaṃ kalyāṇaṃ atthaṃ payojanaṃ, kusalaṃ anāmayaṃ,
analyzed: āyu bhotaḥ hotu ciram jīvitam bhaddam kalyāṇam attham payojanam kusalam anāmayam
translated: May there be long life for you, may there be a long life for you, may there be good, may there be good, may there be a good purpose, may there be good, may there be good health,

original: hitaṃ pathyaṃ sukhaṃ sātaṃ bhoto hotu, sādhu sammuti metassa, puttassāvikareyya guyhamatthaṃ,
analyzed: hitam pathyam sukham sātam bhoto hotu sādhu sammuti mā itassa puttassa a vikareyya guyham attham
translated: may there be good, may there be good, may there be happiness, may there be happiness for you, may there be agreement with him, may he reveal the secret meaning to his son,

original: tassa me sakko pāturahosi, tassa pahiṇeyya, bhikkhūnaṃ dutaṃ pāhesi, kappati samaṇānaṃ
analyzed: tassa me sakko pāturahosi tassa pahiṇeyya bhikkhūnam dutam pāhesi kappati samaṇānam
translated: he was present to me, Sakka, I would send to him, he sent a messenger to the monks, is it allowable for ascetics,

original: āyogo, ekassa dvinnaṃ tiṇṇaṃ vā pahoti, upamaṃ te karissāmi, añjaliṃ te paggaṇhāmi,
analyzed: āyogaḥ ekassa dvinnam tiṇṇam vā pahoti upamam te karissāmi añjalim te paggaṇhāmi
translated: is it enough for one, two, or three, I will make a simile for you, I raise my clasped hands to you,

original: tassa phāsu, lokassattho, namo te purisājañña, sotthi tassa, alaṃ mallo mallassa,
analyzed: tassa phāsu lokassatthaḥ namaḥ te purisa ajañña sotthi tassa alam mallaḥ mallassa
translated: he is comfortable, the meaning of the world, homage to you, O best of men, he is safe, enough, Malla, for the Malla,

original: samattho mallo mallassa, tassa hitaṃ, tassa sukhaṃ, svāgataṃ te mahārājāti sabbattha
analyzed: samatthaḥ mallaḥ mallassa tassa hitam tassa sukham svāgatam te mahā rāja ati sabbattha
translated: the Malla is able for the Malla, that is good for him, that is happiness for him, welcome to you, great king, everywhere

original: chaṭṭhī sambandhe, evaṃvidhamaññampeva viññeyyaṃ yathāgamaṃ.🔽26. Pañcamyavadhismā.
analyzed: chaṭṭhī sambandhe viññeyyam yathāgamam  pañcamī avadhi smā
translated: the sixth case is used for connection, such should be understood in other cases also, according to the text.🔽. The fifth case is used for the point of departure.

original: Padatthāvadhismā pañcamīvibhatti hoti. Gāmasmā āgacchatu, evaṃ corasmā bhāyati, corasmā
analyzed: pañcamī vibhatti hoti gāmasmai āgacchatu evam corasmai bhāyati corasmai
translated: The fifth case is used for the point of departure of the word meaning. Let him come from the village, thus he fears from the thief, from the thief,

original: uttasati, orasmā tāyati, corasmā rakkhatīti, sace bhāyatha dukkhassa, pamāde bhayadassivā,
analyzed: uttasati orasmā tāyati ca urasmā rakkhati iti sace bhāyatha dukkhassa pamāde bhaya dassivā
translated: He is afraid, he is frightened, he is protected from the thief, if you are afraid of suffering, if you are afraid of heedlessness,

original: tasanti daṇḍassāti chaṭṭhī sattamiyopi honteva sambandhādhāravacanicchāyaṃ.
analyzed: daṇḍassa ati chaṭṭhī sattamiyaḥ api hontā iva sambandha ādhāra vacani chāyam
translated: He is afraid of the rod: the sixth and seventh are only in the sense of a statement of relationship.

original: Ajjhenā parājeti, paṭipakkhe parājetīti savisayāva vibhattiyo. Sace kevaṭṭassa parajjissāmīti
analyzed: ajjhenā parājeti paṭipakkhe parājeti iti sa visayāḥ va vibhattiyaḥ sace kevaṭṭassa parajjissāmi iti
translated: He conquers the enemy: he conquers the opponent. The case endings are only in the sense of an object. If I were to conquer the fisherman,

original: chaṭṭhīpi hoti sambandhavacanicchāyaṃ. Yavehi gāvo vāreti, pāpā cittaṃ nivāraye,
analyzed: chaṭṭhī pi hoti sambandha vacanicchāyam yavehi gāvaḥ vāreti pāpāḥ cittam nivāraye
translated: The sixth is also in the sense of a statement of relationship. The cows are restrained by means of barley, the mind is restrained from evil,

original: kāke rakkhati taṇḍulāti savisayeva pañcamī. Cittaṃ rakkhetha medhāvīti dutiyāva dissati
analyzed: kāke rakkhati sa visayā iva pañcamī cittam rakkhetha medhāvī iti dutiyā ava dissati
translated: The rice is protected from the crows: the fifth is only in the sense of an object. The wise one should guard the mind: only the second is seen

original: kammatthe. Upajjhāyā antaradhāyati, upajjhāyā adhite, kāmato jāyate sokoti savisaye pañcamī.
analyzed: kammatthe upajjhāyā antaradhāyati upajjhāyā adhite kāmatas jāyate sokaḥ iti sa visaye pañcamī
translated: in the sense of an action. The preceptor disappears, the preceptor is intent, grief is born from desire: the fifth is only in the sense of an object.

original: Tattheva-ntaradhāyi su, naṭassa suṇoti, padumaṃ tattha jāyethāti sattamīchaṭṭhiyopi
analyzed: tattha iva antaradhāyi su naṭassa suṇoti padumam tattha jāyetha iti sattamī chaṭṭhiyāḥ pi
translated: There only he disappears, he hears the actor, the lotus is born there: the seventh and sixth

original: honteva savisaye. Himavantā pabhavati gaṅgā, pāṇātipātā viramassu khippaṃ, añño devadattā,
analyzed: hontā iva sa visaye himavantā pabhavati gaṅgā pāṇa atipātā viramassu khippam aññaḥ devadattā
translated: are only in the sense of an object. The Ganges originates from the Himalayas, quickly refrain from killing living beings, other than Devadatta,

original: bhinno devadattāti savisayeva pañcamī. Evaṃ ārā so āsavakkhayā, itaro devadattā,🔽uddhaṃ pādatalā adho kesamatthakā, pubbo gāmā, pubbeva sambodhā, tato paraṃ, tato
analyzed: bhinnaḥ devadattā ati sa visayā iva pañcamī evam ārā saḥ āsava kkhayā itaraḥ devadattā  uddham pāda talāḥ adhas kesamatthakā pubbaḥ gāmā pubbā iva sambodhā tatas param tatas
translated: ‘He is emancipated from the cankers’—here the locative is used in the sense of the locative of cause.🔽‘From the soles of the feet upwards and from the crown of the head downwards’—here the locative is used in the sense of the locative of extent.🔽‘The village of Pāṭali’—here the locative is used in the sense of the locative of priority.🔽‘At one time’—here the locative is used in the sense of the locative of time.

original: aparena samayena, tatuttarinti. Sambandhavacanicchāyaṃ chaṭṭhīpi purato gāmassa,
analyzed: aparena samayena sambandha vacani chāyam chaṭṭhī pi puratas gāmassa
translated: ‘After that’—here the locative is used in the sense of the locative of posteriority.🔽‘In front of the village’—here the locative is used in the sense of the locative of direction.🔽‘To the south of the village’—here the locative is used in the sense of the locative of direction.

original: dakkhiṇato gāmassa, upari pabbatassa, heṭṭhā pāsādassāti. Pāsādamāruyha pekkhati
analyzed: dakkhiṇatas gāmassa upari pabbatassa heṭṭhā pāsādassa ati pāsādam āruyha pekkhati
translated: ‘On the top of the mountain’—here the locative is used in the sense of the locative of support.🔽‘Having ascended the palace he looks out’—here the locative is used in the sense of the locative of origin.🔽‘He looks out from the palace’—here the locative is used in the sense of the locative of origin.

original: pāsādā pekkhati, āsane upavisitvā pekkhati āsanā pekkhatīti avadhivacanicchāyaṃ pañcamī.
analyzed: pāsādā pekkhati āsane upavisitvā pekkhati āsanā pekkhati iti avadhi vacani chāyam pañcamī
translated: ‘Having sat down on the seat he looks out’—here the locative is used in the sense of the locative of origin.🔽‘From where do you come?’—here the locative is used in the sense of the locative of origin.

original: Pucchānākhyānesu kuto bhavaṃ? Pātaṭaliputtasmāti. Tathā desakālamānepi pāṭaliputtasmā
analyzed: puccha an ākhyānesu kutas tathā desa kāla māne pi
translated: ‘From Pāṭaliputta’—here the locative is used in the sense of the locative of origin.🔽‘From Pāṭaliputta to Rājagaha it is seven yojanas’—here the locative is used in the sense of the locative of extent.

original: rājagahaṃ satta yojanāni, sattasu yojanesūti vā. Evaṃ ito tiṇṇaṃ māsāna-maccayenāti,
analyzed: rājagaham satta yojanāni sattasu yojanesu iti vai evam itas tiṇṇam māsānam accayena ati
translated: ‘Having gone three months from here’—here the locative is used in the sense of the locative of time.🔽‘The difficult-to-obtain’—here the locative is used in the sense of the locative of cause.

original: kicchāladdhanti guṇe pañcamī. Kicchena me adhigatanti hetumhi karaṇe vā tatiyā. Evaṃ
analyzed: guṇe pañcamī kicchena me adhigatanti hetumhi karaṇe vā tatiyā evam
translated: ‘The difficult-to-obtain was obtained by me’—here the locative is used in the sense of the locative of cause.

original: thokā mutto, thokena muttoti. Thokaṃ calatīti kiriyāvisesane kammani dutiyā.
analyzed: thokā mutto thokena mutto ti thokam calati iti kiriyā visesane kammani dutiyā
translated: ‘He is freed by a little, he is freed by a little’ . ‘He moves a little’ is a second-case locative in a special verbal noun.

original: Dūranti katthayogepi savisayeva pañcamīchaṭṭhiyo siyuṃ, dūraṃ gāmasmā, antikaṃ gāmasmā,🔽dūraṃ gāmassa, antikaṃ gāmassāti, dūranti katthehi tu sabbāva savisaye siyuṃ bādhakābhāvā
analyzed: dūram ti kattha yoge pi sa visayā iva pañcamī chaṭṭhiyaḥ siyum dūram gāmasmai antikam gāmasmai  dūram gāmassa antikam gāmassa ati dūram ti katthehi tu sa visaye siyum bādhaka abhāvā
translated: ‘Far’ and ‘near’ are fifth-case and sixth-case locatives only when they are in apposition, as ‘Far from the village’ and ‘Near the village’;

original: dūro gāmo, antiko gāmotvevamādi.
analyzed: dūraḥ gāmaḥ antikaḥ gāmaḥ uta evamādi
translated: but when they are not in apposition they are all locatives, because there is no obstruction, as ‘The village is far’ and ‘The village is near’ .

original: Keci panāhu ‘asattavacanahetehi pāṭipadikatthe dutiyātatiyāpañcamīsattamiyo, sattavacanehi
analyzed: keci pana āhu a satta vacana hetehi pāṭipadika atthe dutiyā tatiyā pañcamī sattamiyo satta vacanehi
translated: But some say that the second, third, fifth, and seventh cases are used in the sense of the locative when they are preceded by a word denoting non-existence,
