original: aputte, kvaci na hoti pañca bhuttavanto assa bhātuno putto assa atthīti bahulādhikārato.
analyzed: a putte kvaci na hoti pañca bhuttavantaḥ assa bhātuno putto assa atthi iti bahula adhikārataḥ
translated: In the absence of a child, it is not in any place. He has five sons. He is the son of his brother. He has.

original: 18. Tattha gahetvā tena paharitvā yuddhe sarūpaṃ.
analyzed: tattha gahetvā tena paharitvā yuddhe sarūpam
translated: . Having seized there, having struck with that, in the battle, it is of the same form.

original: Sattamyantaṃ tatiyantañca sarūpamanekaṃ tattha gahetvā tena paharitvā yuddhe-ññapadatthe
analyzed: sattamī antam tatiya antam ca sarūpam anekam tattha gahetvā tena paharitvā
translated: The seventh case ending and the third case ending are of the same form in many places. Having seized there, having struck with that, in the battle, in the sense of the accusative case,

original: ekatthaṃ vā hoti, kesesu ca kesesu ca gahetvā yuddhaṃ pavattaṃ kesākesi, daṇḍehi
analyzed: ekattham vā hoti kesesu ca kesesu ca gahetvā yuddham pavattam kesākesi daṇḍehi
translated: it is in one place. Having seized in whatever places, the battle that takes place is kesākesi. Having struck with sticks

original: ca daṇḍehi ca paharitvā yuddhaṃ pavattaṃ daṇḍādaṇḍi, muṭṭhāmuṭṭhi, “ci vītiyāre”
analyzed: ca daṇḍehi ca paharitvā yuddham pavattam daṇḍādaṇḍi muṭṭhāmuṭṭhi ci vītiyāre
translated: and with sticks, the battle that takes place is daṇḍādaṇḍi, muṭṭhāmuṭṭhi, ci vītiyāre

original: (3-51) ti ci samāsanto, “cismiṃ” (3.66) ti akāro. Tattha teneti kiṃ? Kāyañca kāyañca
analyzed: ti ci samāsanto cismin ti akāro tattha tena iti kim kāyam ca kāyam ca
translated: (-) is a compound of ci. In ci (.) is the letter a. There, what is meant by tene? Having seized body and body,

original: gahetvā yuddhaṃ pavattaṃ. Gahetvā paharitvāti kiṃ? Rathe ca rathe ca ṭhatvā yuddhaṃ
analyzed: gahetvā yuddham pavattam gahetvā paharitvā ati kim rathe ca rathe ca yuddham
translated: the battle that takes place. What is meant by gahetvā paharitvā? Having stood in the chariot and in the chariot,

original: pavatti. Yuddheti kiṃ? Hatthe ca hatthe ca gahetvā sakhyaṃ pavattaṃ. Sarūpanti kiṃ?
analyzed: yuddha iti kim hatthe ca hatthe ca gahetvā sakhyam pavattam sarūpam ti kim
translated: the battle that takes place. What is meant by yuddha? Having seized hand and hand, the friendship that takes place. What is meant by sarūpa?

original: Daṇḍehi ca musalehi ca paharitvā yuddha pavattaṃ.
analyzed: daṇḍehi ca musalehi ca paharitvā yuddha pavattam
translated: Having struck with sticks and with pestles, the battle that takes place.

original: 19. Catthe.
analyzed: catthe
translated: . In the fourth case.

original: Anekaṃ syādyantaṃ catthe ekatthaṃ vā bhavati. Samuccayonvācayo itarītarayogo samāhāro
analyzed: anekam syādi antam catthe ekattham vā bhavati samuccaya unvācayo itarītara yogo samāhāraḥ
translated: The compound is of two kinds, copulative and appositional.

original: ca ca saddatthā, tattha samuccayānvācayesu nekatthībhāvo sambhavati, tesu hi samuccayo
analyzed: ca ca tattha samuccaya anvācayesu na ikatthībhāvaḥ sambhavati tesu hi samuccayaḥ
translated: The copulative is of two kinds, collective and distributive.

original: aññamaññanirapekkhā namattappadhānānaṃ katthaci kiriyāvisese cīyamānatā, yathā ‘dhave🔽ca khadire ca palāse ca chindā’ti. Anvācayo ca yattheko padhānabhāvena vidhīyate
analyzed: aññamañña nirapekkhā namatta ppadhānānam katthaci kiriyā visese cīyamāna tā yathā dhave  ca khadire ca palāse ca chindāti ca padhāna bhāvena vidhīyate
translated: In the collective the component members are not mutually dependent, and the action is distributed among them, as in ‘Cut the wood, the grass, and the sticks.’🔽In the distributive the one is enjoined as the principal,

original: aparo ca guṇabhāvena, yathā ‘bhikkhañcara gāvo cānaye’ti. Itaradvaye tu sambhavati,
analyzed: aparaḥ ca guṇa bhāvena yathā bhikkhan cara gāvaḥ ca anayā iti itara dvaye tu sambhavati
translated: and the other as a subordinate, as in ‘Go round the village, the cow and the boy.’🔽In the other two kinds of copulative compound it is possible for the meaning to be manifold,🔽for in them the appositional compound is of two kinds, that in which the component members are not mutually dependent, and that in which they are mutually dependent.

original: tesu hi aññamaññasāpekkhānamavayavabhadānugato itarītarayogo, yathā ‘sāriputtamoggallānā’ti,
analyzed: tesu hi itarītara yogaḥ yathā
translated: In the former the component members are not principal, as in ‘Sāriputta and Moggallāna.’🔽The plural is used because the component members are not principal.

original: assāvayavappadhānattā bahuvacanameva. Aññamaññasāpekkhānameva tirohitāvayavabhedo
analyzed: assa avayava ppadhāna ttā bahuvacanam eva aññam añña sa apekkhānam eva tirohita avayava bhedaḥ
translated: In the latter the component members are mutually dependent, and the distinction of the component members is concealed,

original: samudāyappadhāno samāhāro, yathā ‘chattupāhana’nti, assa pana samudāyappadhānattā ekavacanameva.
analyzed: samudāya ppadhānaḥ samāhāraḥ yathā chattu upāhananti assa pana samudāya ppadhāna ttā ekavacanam eva
translated: and the compound is a collective one, as in ‘umbrella-and-alms-bowl.’ The singular is used because the collective is principal.

original: Te ca samāhārītarītarayogā bahulaṃ vidhānā niyatavisayāyeva honti, tatrāyaṃ visayavibhāgo🔽nirutthipiṭakāgato-pāṇitūriyayoggasenaṅgānaṃ, niccaverīnaṃ, saṅkhyāparimāṇa-saññānaṃ,
analyzed: te ca samāhāri itari itara yogāḥ bahulam vidhānāḥ niyata visayāya iva honti tatra ayam visaya vibhāgaḥ  saṅkhyā parimāṇa saññānam
translated: And these are often found in a collection, and they are limited to their own sphere. Here is the division of the spheres:🔽The parts of the hand, the parts of the lute, the parts of the body, the parts of the number, the parts of the measure, the parts of the perception,

original: khuddajantukānaṃ, pacanacaṇḍālānaṃ, caraṇasādhāraṇānaṃ, ekajjhāyanapāvacanānaṃ, liṅgavisesānaṃ,
analyzed: khuddajantukānam pacana caṇḍālānam caraṇa sādhāraṇānam ekajjhāyana pāvacanānam liṅga visesānam
translated: the parts of the small creatures, the parts of the cooking, the parts of the outcaste, the parts of the walking, the parts of the common, the parts of the one-jhāna, the parts of the going forth, the parts of the gender,

original: vividhaviruddhānaṃ disānaṃ, nadīnañca niccaṃ samāhārekattaṃ bhavati, tiṇarukkhapasusakunadhanadhaññabyañjanajanappadānaṃ
analyzed: vividha viruddhānam disānam nadīnam ca niccam samāhāra ekattam bhavati tiṇa rukkha pasu sakuna dhana dhañña byañjana jana ppadānam
translated: the parts of the various and opposed directions, and the parts of the rivers, are always found in a collection. Or the parts of the grass, trees, animals, birds, wealth, grain, letters, people, and countries,

original: vā, aññesamitarītarayogova.
analyzed: vā aññesam itari itara yogaḥ u va
translated: are found in a collection. The other parts are found in a collection or not.

original: Pāṇyaṅgānaṃ-cakkhusotaṃ, mukhanāsikaṃ, hanugīvaṃ, chavimaṃsalohitaṃ, nāmarūpaṃ, jarāmaraṇaṃ.
analyzed: mukha nāsikam hanu gīvam chavi maṃsa lohitam nāma rūpam jarā maraṇam
translated: The parts of the hand are: eye, ear, mouth, nose, cheek, neck, skin, flesh, blood, name-and-form, aging-and-death.

original: Turiyaṅgānaṃ-alasatālambaraṃ, murajagomukhaṃ, saṅkhadeṇḍimaṃ, maddavikapāṇavikaṃ,
analyzed: muraja gomukham saṅkha deṇḍimam maddavika pāṇavikam
translated: The parts of the lute are: laziness, cloth, the head of a mongoose, a conch, a drum, a soft hand, a drum, a flute,

original: gītavāditaṃ, sammatālaṃ. Yoggaṅgānaṃ phālapācanaṃ, yuganaṅgalaṃ. Senaṅgānaṃ-asisattitomarapiṇḍaṃ,
analyzed: gīta vāditam sammatālam yoggaṅgānam phālapācanam yuganaṅgalam senaṅgānam asisatti tomara piṇḍam
translated: singing, playing, a cymbal, and a clapper. The parts of the army are: a sword, a spear, an arrow, a javelin, a club,

original: asicammaṃ, dhanukalāpaṃ, paharaṇāvaraṇaṃ. Niccaverīnaṃ-ahinakulaṃ, bīḷālamūsikaṃ,🔽kākolūkaṃ, nāgasupaṇṇaṃ. Saṅkhyāparimāṇa saññānaṃ-ekakadukaṃ, dukatikaṃ, tikacatukkaṃ,
analyzed: asi cammam dhanu kalāpam paharaṇa āvaraṇam bīḷāla mūsikam  kāka ulūkam nāga supaṇṇam saṅkhyā parimāṇa saññānam ekaka dukam duka tikam tika catukkam
translated: a sword, a quiver, a bow, a shield. A constant enemy, a wicked family, a cat, a rat,🔽an owl, a crow, a nāga, a supaṇṇa. Of the perceptions of number and measure, one, two,🔽three, four,

original: catukkapañcakaṃ, dasekādasakaṃ. Khuddajantukānaṃ kīṭapaṭaṅgaṃ, kunthakipillikaṃ,🔽ḍaṃsamakasaṃ, makkhikakipillikaṃ. Pacanacaṇḍālānaṃ-orabbhikasūkarikaṃ, sākunti kamāgavikaṃ,
analyzed: catukka pañcakam dasa ikādasakam kīṭa paṭaṅgam kuntha kipillikam  ḍaṃsa makasam makkhika kipillikam pacana caṇḍālānam orabbhika sūkarikam sākuntika māgavikam
translated: a sword, a quiver, a bow-case, a weapon, a shield. Of those who are always hostile: a cat and a mongoose, an owl and a crow, a nāga and a supaṇṇa. Of the number and measure of perceptions: one, two, three, four,🔽five, ten, eleven. Of small creatures: insects and moths, ants and termites,🔽mosquitoes and flies, bees and wasps. Of the outcastes and scavengers: a hunter and a pig-keeper, a poultry-keeper and a fisherman,

original: sapākacaṇḍālaṃ, venarathakāraṃ, pukkusa chavaḍāhakaṃ. Caraṇasādhāraṇānaṃ-atisabhāradvājaṃ,
analyzed: sa pāka caṇḍālam vena rathakāram pukkusa chava ḍāhakam
translated: a sweeper and a cart-driver, a pukkusa and a corpse-remover. Of those who share the same practice: a bull and a banner,

original: kaṭhakalāpaṃ, sīlapaññāṇaṃ, samathavipassanaṃ, vijjācaraṇaṃ. Ekajjhāyanapāvacanānaṃ
analyzed: kaṭha kalāpam sīla paññāṇam samatha vipassanam vijjā caraṇam ekajjhāyana pāvacanānam
translated: a stick and a bundle, virtue and wisdom, serenity and insight, knowledge and conduct. Of those who are liberated by one attainment:

original: dīghamajjhimaṃ, ekuttarasaṃyuttakaṃ, khandhakavibhaṅgaṃ. Liṅgavisesānaṃ-itthipukhaṃ,
analyzed: dīgha majjhimam eka uttara saṃyuttakam khandhaka vibhaṅgam
translated: long, medium, connected with the first, the analysis of the aggregates and the elements. Of the differences in gender: a woman and a man,

original: dāsidāsaṃ, cīvarapiṇḍapātasenāsanagilānappaccayabhesajjaparikkhāraṃ, tiṇakaṭṭhasākhāpalāsaṃ,
analyzed: dāsi dāsam cīvara piṇḍapāta senāsana gilāna ppaccaya bhesajja parikkhāram tiṇa kaṭṭha sākhā palāsam
translated: a slave and a slave-woman, robes, almsfood, a dwelling, and medicinal requisites, grass, sticks, leaves, flowers,

original: ‘lābhī hoti cīvarapiṇḍapātasenā- sanagilānappaccayabhesajjaparikkhārāna’ntipi dissati.🔽Vividhaviruddhānaṃ kusalākusalaṃ, sāvajjānavajjaṃ, hīnappaṇītaṃ, kaṇhasukkaṃ, chekapāpakaṃ.🔽Disānaṃ pubbāparaṃ, dakkhiṇuttaraṃ, pubbadakkhiṇaṃ, pubbuttaraṃ, adharuttaraṃ, aparadakkhiṇaṃ,
analyzed: lābhī hoti cīvara piṇḍapāta senā sana gilāna ppaccaya bhesajja parikkhārānaṃ antipi dissati  vividha viruddhānam kusala akusalam sāvajja anavajjam hīna ppaṇītam kaṇha sukkam cheka pāpakam  disānam pubba aparam dakkhiṇa uttaram pubba dakkhiṇam pubba uttaram adhar uttaram apara dakkhiṇam
translated: ‘He is one who obtains robes, almsfood, resting place, and medicinal requisites for curing the sick’ is also seen.🔽The various opposites are wholesome and unwholesome, blameworthy and blameless, low and refined, dark and bright, and having a proximate and a far-off object.

original: aparuttaraṃ. Nadīnaṃ-gaṅgāyamunaṃ, mahisarabhu.
analyzed: aparuttaram nadīnaṃgaṅgā yamunam mahisarabhu
translated: The directions are east and west, north and south, northeast and southeast, northwest and southwest, below and above. The rivers are the Ganges and the Yamunā, the Mahi and the Sarabhū.

original: Tiṇavisesānaṃ-kāsakusaṃ kāsakusā, usīrabīraṇaṃ usīrabīraṇā, muñjapabbajaṃ muñjapabbajaṃ
analyzed: kāsakusā usīrabīraṇam usīrabīraṇā muñjapabbajam muñjapabbajam
translated: The different kinds of grass are kāsā and kusā, usirā and vīraṇā, and muñja and pabbaja.

original: muñjapabbajā. Rukkhavisesānaṃ khadirapalāsaṃ khadirapalāsā, vossakaṇṇaṃ dhavāssakaṇṇā,
analyzed: muñja pabbajāḥ rukkha visesānam khadira palāsam khadira palāsāḥ vossakaṇṇam dhava assakaṇṇā
translated: The different kinds of trees are khadira and palāsa, vossakaṇṇā and dhavāssakaṇṇā,

original: pilakkhanigrodhaṃ pilakkhanigrodhā, assatthakapitthanaṃ assatthakapitthanā, sākasālaṃ
analyzed: pilakkha nigrodham pilakkha nigrodhāḥ assattha kapitthanam assattha kapitthanā sākasālam
translated: pilakkha and nigrodha, assattha and kapitthana, and sāka and sāla.

original: sākasālā. Pasuvisesānaṃ-gajagavajaṃ gajagavajā, gomahisaṃ gomahisā, eṇeyyagomahisaṃ
analyzed: sākasālā gajagavajā gomahisam gomahisāḥ eṇeyyagomahisam
translated: The different kinds of animals are gaja and gavaja, go and mahisā, and eṇeyya and gomahisā.

original: eṇeyyagomahisā, eṇeyyavarāhaṃ eṇeyyavarāhā, ajeḷakaṃ ajeḷakā, kukkurasūkaraṃ kukkurasūkarā,🔽hatthigavāssavaḷavaṃ hatthigavāssavaḷavā. Sakunavisesānaṃ-haṃsabalāvaṃ haṃsabalāvā,
analyzed: eṇeyya go mahisā eṇeyya varāham eṇeyya varāhāḥ ajeḷakam ajeḷakā kukkura sūkaram kukkura sūkarā  hatthi gavāssa vaḷavam hatthi gavāssa vaḷavā sakuna visesānaṃhaṃsabalāvam haṃsabalāvā
translated: the deer, the cow, the buffalo, the deer, the boar, the deer, the boar, the goat, the goat, the dog, the pig, the dog, the pig,🔽the elephant, the cow, the horse, the ass, the elephant, the cow, the horse, the ass. Of different birds: the swan, the goose, the swan, the goose,

original: kāraṇḍavacakkavākaṃ kāraṇḍavacakkavākā, bakabalākaṃ bakabalākā. Dhanānaṃ-hiraññasuvaṇṇaṃ
analyzed: kāraṇḍava cakkavākam kāraṇḍava cakkavākāḥ baka balākam baka balākāḥ dhanānaṃhirañña suvaṇṇam
translated: the duck, the ruddy goose, the duck, the ruddy goose, the crane, the heron, the crane, the heron. Of wealth: gold, silver,

original: hiraññasuvaṇṇā, maṇisaṅkhamuttāveḷuriyaṃ maṇisaṅkhamuttāveḷuriyā, jātarūparajataṃ🔽jātarūparajatā. Dhaññānaṃ-sāliyavakaṃ sāliyavakā, tilamuggamāsaṃ tilamuggamāsā, nipphāvakulatthaṃ
analyzed: hiraññasuvaṇṇā maṇi saṅkha muttā veḷuriyam maṇi saṅkha muttā veḷuriyā jātarūpa rajatam  jātarūpa rajatā dhaññā naṃsa āli yavakam sāli yavakā tila mugga māsam tila mugga māsāḥ nipphāva kulattham
translated: gold, silver, gems, pearls, corals, crystals, gems, pearls, corals, crystals, bronze, iron,🔽bronze, iron. Of grains: rice, barley,

original: nipphāvakulatthā. Byañjanānaṃ-sākasuvaṃ sākasuvā, gabyamāhisaṃ gabyamāhisā, eṇeyyavārāhaṃ
analyzed: nipphāva kulatthāḥ byañjana anaṃsākasuvam sākasuvāḥ gabyamāhisam gabyamāhisāḥ eṇeyyavārāham
translated: rice, barley, sesamum, kidney beans, beans, sesamum, kidney beans, beans, vetches, beans, vetches. Of vegetables: potherbs,🔽potherbs, garlic, onions, garlic, onions, deer, boar,🔽deer, boar, antelope, peacock, antelope, peacock. Of countries: Kāsi, Kosala,

original: eṇeyyavārāhā, migamāyūraṃ migamāyūrā. Janapadānaṃ-kāsikosalaṃ kāsikosalā, vajjimallaṃ
analyzed: eṇeyya vārāhāḥ migamāyūram migamāyūrāḥ janapadānaṃkāsi kosalam kāsi kosalāḥ vajjimallam
translated: Kāsi, Kosala, Vajji, Malla,

original: vajjimallā, cetivaṃsaṃ cetivaṃsā, macchasūrasenaṃ macchasūrasenā, kurupañcālaṃ kurupañcālā.
analyzed: vajjimallā cetivaṃsam cetivaṃsā macchasūrasenam macchasūrasenā kurupañcālam kurupañcālā
translated: Vajjis and Mallians, Cetis and Vamsas, Macchas and Surasenas, Kurus and Pañcālas.

original: Itarītarayogo yathā-candimasūriyā, samaṇabrāhmaṇā mātāpitaro iccādi.
analyzed: itarītara yogaḥ yathā samaṇa brāhmaṇāḥ mātā pitaraḥ iccādi
translated: The compound of the other and the other, as the moon and the sun, ascetics and brahmans, mother and father, etc.

original: Etasmiṃ ekatthībhāvakaṇḍe yaṃ vuttaṃ pubbaṃ, tadeva pubbaṃ nipatati kamātikkame payojanābhāvā.
analyzed: etasmin ekatthībhāva kaṇḍe yam vuttam pubbam tat eva pubbam nipatati kama atikkame payojana abhāvā
translated: In this section on the state of being one in meaning, what was said before comes first, because there is no purpose in transgressing the order.

original: Kvaci vipallāsopi hoti bahulādhikārato, dantānaṃ rājā rājadanto, katthaci kamaṃ paccānādarā
analyzed: kvaci bahula adhikārataḥ dantānam rājā rājadanto katthaci
translated: In some cases, there is also inversion due to the predominance of the many, as the king of the teeth, the tooth-king. In some cases, there is contempt for the order,

original: pubbakālassāpi paranipāto, littavāsito, naggamusito, sittasammaṭṭho, bhaṭṭhaluñcito.🔽Catthe yadekatthaṃ tattha keci pubbapadaṃ bahudhā niyamenti, tadiha byabhicāradassāna
analyzed: pubba kālassa api para nipātaḥ littavāsitaḥ naggamusitaḥ sittasammaṭṭhaḥ bhaṭṭhaluñcitaḥ  catthe yat ekattham tattha keci pubba padam bahudhā niyamenti tat iha byabhicāra dassāna
translated: and the superseding of the former time, as the one who has put on a loincloth, the one who has put on a robe, the one who has anointed himself with oil, the one who has shaved his hair.

original: na vuttanti daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: na vuttam ti daṭṭhabbam
translated: In the fourth, where it is one in meaning, there some restrict the first member in many ways, and here it should be seen that it is not stated because of the appearance of exceptions.

original: 20. Samāhāre napuṃsakaṃ.
analyzed: samāhāre napuṃsakam
translated: In a collection, the neuter.

original: Catthe samāhāre yadekatthaṃ, taṃ napuṃsakaliṅgaṃ bhavati, tathācevodāhaṭaṃ, katthaci na hoti ‘sabhāparisāyā’ti ñāpakā, ādhipaccaparivāro, chandapārisuddhi, paṭisandhipavattiyaṃ.
analyzed: catthe samāhāre yat ekattham tam napuṃsaka liṅgam bhavati tathā ca iva udāhaṭam katthaci na hoti sabhā parisāya ati ñāpakāḥ
translated: In the fourfold collection, that which is in one place has the neuter gender, and so it is stated. But in some places it is not so, as shown by the examples sabhā parisā yā, ādhipaccaparivāro, chandapārisuddhi, paṭisandhipavattiyaṃ.

original: 21. Saṅkhyādi.
analyzed: saṅkhyā ādi
translated: . Number, etc.

original: Ekatthe samāhāre saṅkhyādi napuṃsakaliṅgaṃ bhavati, pañcagavaṃ, catuppathaṃ, samāhārassekattā ekavacanameva hoti, samāhāretveva pañcakāpālo pūvo, tiputto.
analyzed: ekatthe samāhāre saṅkhyā ādi napuṃsaka liṅgam bhavati pañcagavam catuppatham samāhārassa ikattā eka vacanam eva hoti samāhāretvā eva pañca kāpālaḥ pūvaḥ ti putto
translated: In the fourfold collection, number, etc., have the neuter gender. There is only the singular because of the unity of the collection: pañcagavaṃ, catuppathaṃ. But in the collection itself, pañcakāpālo pūvo, tiputto.

original: 22. Kvacekattañca chaṭṭhiyā.
analyzed: kvacekattam ca chaṭṭhiyā
translated: . And in some places the singleness in the sixth case.

original: Chaṭṭhiyekatthe kvaci napuṃsakattaṃ hotekatthañca, salabhānaṃ chāyā salabhacchāyaṃ,
analyzed: chaṭṭhiyā ikatthe kvaci napuṃsaka attam hotā ikattham ca salabhānam chāyā salabha chāyam
translated: In the sixth case, the singleness in some places has the neuter gender, as shown by the examples salabhānaṃ chāyā salabhacchāyaṃ,

original: evaṃ sakuntānaṃ chāyā sakuntacchāyaṃ, pāsādacchāyaṃ pāsādacchāyā, gharacchāyaṃ gharacchāyā,
analyzed: evam sakuntānam chāyā sakunta chāyam pāsāda chāyam pāsāda chāyā ghara chāyam ghara chāyā
translated: sakuntānaṃ chāyā sakuntacchāyaṃ, pāsādacchāyaṃ pāsādacchāyā, gharacchāyaṃ gharacchāyā,

original: amanussasabhāya napuṃsakekattaṃ bhavati brahmasabhaṃ, devasabhaṃ, indasabhaṃ, yakkhasabhaṃ,
analyzed: a manussa sabhāya napuṃsakekattam bhavati brahma sabham deva sabham inda sabham yakkha sabham
translated: amanussasabhāya napuṃsakekattaṃ bhavati brahmasabhaṃ, devasabhaṃ, indasabhaṃ, yakkhasabhaṃ,🔽.

original: sarabhasabhaṃ, manussasabhāyaṃ pana khattiyasabhā, rājasabhā iccevamādi, kvacīti kiṃ rājapuriso.
analyzed: sarabha sabham manussa sabhāyam pana khattiya sabhā rāja sabhā icca evamādi kvaci iti kim rāja purisaḥ
translated: In an assembly of men, however, it is a Khattiya assembly, a King’s assembly, and so on. In some places: what is the meaning? A man of the King’s court.

original: 23. Syādīsu rasso.
analyzed: sya ādīsu rassaḥ
translated: In sy and so on the vowel is ra.

original: Napuṃsake vattamānassa rasso hoti syādīsu. Salabhacchāyaṃ, syādīsūti kiṃ? Salabhacchāye.
analyzed: napuṃsake vattamānassa rassaḥ hoti syādīsu salabhacchāyam syādīsu iti kim salabhacchāye
translated: The vowel ra is substituted for the final vowel of a masculine noun in sy and so on. In the shadow of the spider, In sy and so on: what is the meaning? In the shadow of the spider.

original: 24. Ghapassantassāppadhānassa.
analyzed: gha passa antassa a ppadhānassa
translated: In gha and so on the vowel is ra.

original: Antabhūtassa appadhānassa ghapassa syādīsu rasso hoti. Bahumālo poso, nikkosambi, ativāmoru, antassāti kiṃ? Rājā kaññāpiyo, appadhānassāti kiṃ? Rājakumārī brahmabandhū.
analyzed: anta bhūtassa appadhānassa ghapassa sya ādīsu rassaḥ hoti bahu mālaḥ posaḥ nikkosambi ati vāma ūru antassa ati kim rājā kaññāpiyaḥ appadhānassa ati kim rāja kumārī brahmabandhū
translated: The vowel ra is substituted for the final vowel of a noun ending in a consonant in gha and so on. A man with many garlands, a necklace, a very tall tree, In gha and so on: what is the meaning? The King’s daughter, a kinsman of the King. In gha and so on: what is the meaning? A King’s daughter, a kinsman of the King.

original: 25. Gossu.
analyzed: gossu
translated: In go the vowel is u.

original: Antabhūtassa appadhānassa gossa syādīsu u hoti. Cittagu, appadhānassātveva? Sugo, antassātveva? Gokulaṃ.
analyzed: anta bhūtassa appadhānassa gossa syādīsu u hoti cittagu sugo antaḥ sātvā eva go kulam
translated: The vowel u is substituted for the final vowel of a noun ending in a consonant in go and so on. A man with a good mind, In go and so on: what is the meaning? A good man, In go and so on: what is the meaning? A cow-pen.

original: 26. Itthiyamatvā.
analyzed: itthiyam atvā
translated: In itthiyaṃ the vowel is a.

original: Itthiyaṃ vattamānato akārantato nāmasmā āpaccayo hoti. Dhammadinnā.
analyzed: itthiyam vattamānataḥ a kāra antataḥ nāmasmai ā paccayaḥ hoti dhamma dinnā
translated: The vowel a is substituted for the final vowel of a noun ending in a consonant in itthiyaṃ. Dhammadinnā.

original: 37. Nadādito vī.
analyzed: nad āditaḥ vī
translated: In nadādito the vowel is i.

original: Nadādīhi itthiyaṃ vīppaccayo hoti. Nadī, mahī, kumārī, taruṇī, vāruṇī, gotamī. (14) “Gotovā” gāvī go, ākatigaṇo-yaṃ, koro “ntantūnaṃ vīmhi to vā” (3-36) ti visesanattho.
analyzed: nada ādīhi itthiyam vīppaccayaḥ hoti nadī mahī kumārī taruṇī vāruṇī gotamī gotovā gāvī go ti visesana tthaḥ
translated: The feminine of nadā, etc., is formed by adding -ī. Nadī, mahī, kumārī, taruṇī, vāruṇī, gotamī.

original: 28. Yakkhāditinī ca.
analyzed: yakkha āditinī ca
translated: . And in yakkhā, etc.

original: Yakkhādito itthiyaṃ inī hoti vīca. Yakkhinī yakkhī, nāginī nāgī, sīhinī sīhī.
analyzed: yakkha aditaḥ itthiyam inī hoti vīca yakkhinī yakkhī nāginī nāgī sīhinī sīhī
translated: The feminine of yakkha, etc., is formed by adding -inī. Yakkhinī, yakkhī, nāginī, nāgī, sīhinī, sīhī.

original: 26. Ārāmikādīhi.
analyzed: ārāmika ādīhi
translated: . And in ārāmikā, etc.

original: Ārāmikādito inī hotitthiyaṃ. Ārāmikinī, anantarāyikinī, rājinī (15) “saññāyaṃ mānuso” mānusinī, aññatra mānusī.
analyzed: ārāmika āditas inī hotitthiyam ārāmikinī anantarāyikinī rājinī saññā ayam mānusaḥ mānusinī aññatra mānusī
translated: The feminine of ārāmika, etc., is formed by adding -inī. ārāmikinī, anantarāyikinī, rājinī. “Saññāyaṃ mānuso” mānusinī, aññatra mānusī.

original: 30. Yuvaṇṇehi nī.🔽Itthiyamivaṇṇuvaṇṇantehi nī hoti bahulaṃ. Sadāpayatapāṇinī, daṇḍinī, bhikkhunī, khattabandhunī, paracittavidunī, mātuādito kasmā na hoti? Itthippaccayaṃ vināpi itthattābhidhānato.
analyzed: yuvaṇṇehi nī  nī hoti bahulam daṇḍinī bhikkhunī khattabandhunī paracittavidunī mātu āditaḥ kasmā na hoti itthippaccayam vinā api itthattā abhidhānato
translated: . And in yuvaṇṇa, etc.

original: 31. Ktimhāññatthe.
analyzed: kti mha añ ña tthe
translated: The feminine of yuvaṇṇa, etc., is formed by adding -inī. Sadāpayatapāṇinī, daṇḍinī, bhikkhunī, khattabandhunī, paracittavidunī. Why is it not so in mātuā, etc.? Because the meaning of “woman” is expressed even without the feminine ending.

original: Ktimhāññattheyeva itthiyaṃ nī hoti bahulaṃ. Sāhaṃ ahiṃ sāratinī, tassā muṭṭhassatiniyā, sā gāvī vacchagiddhinī, aññattheti kiṃ? Dhammarati.🔽32. Gharaṇyādayo.
analyzed: ktimha aññatthā iya iva itthiyam nī hoti bahulam sā aham ahim sāratinī tassā muṭṭhassatiniyā sā gāvī vacchagiddhinī aññatthā iti kim dhammarati  gharaṇī ādayaḥ
translated: The feminine form nī is used in the sense of “other” in the word itthiyaṃ.🔽The words gharaṇī, etc., are feminine.

original: Gharaṇippabhutayo nīppaccantāsādhavo bhavanti. Gharaṇī, pokkharaṇī, īssa-ttaṃ nipātanā, (16) “ācariyā vā ya-lopo ca” ācarinī, ācariyā.
analyzed: bhavanti gharaṇī pokkharaṇī īssattam nipātanā ācariyā vā ya lopaḥ ca ācarinī ācariyā
translated: The words gharaṇī, pokkharaṇī, īssa-ttaṃ, nipātanā, ācarinī, ācariyā are feminine.

original: 33. Mātulāditvānī bhariyāyaṃ.
analyzed: mātulāditvānī
translated: The words mātulānī, etc., are feminine in the sense of “wife.”🔽The words mātulānī, vāruṇānī, gahapatānī, ācariyānī, khattiyānī are feminine in the sense of “wife.”

original: Mātulādito bhariyāyamānī hoti. Mātulānī, vāruṇānī, gahapatānī, ācariyānī, (17) “abhariyāyaṃ khattiyā vā” khattiyānī khattiyā, nadādipāṭhā bhariyāyantu khattiyī.🔽34. Upamāsaṃhita sahita saññata saha saphavāma lakkhaṇāditūrutū.
analyzed: mātula āditaḥ bhariyāyamānī hoti mātulānī vāruṇānī gahapatānī ācariyānī a bhariyāyam khattiyā vā khattiyānī khattiyāḥ nada ādi pāṭhāḥ bhariyāyantu khattiyī  upamā saṃhita sahita saññata saha saphavāma lakkhaṇa āditūrutū
translated: The words nadī, etc., are feminine.

original: Ūrusaddā upamānādipubbā ittiyamū hoti. Karabhorū, saṃhitorū, sahitorū, saññatorū, sahorū, saphorū, vāmorū, lakkhaṇorū, ūtiyogavibhāgā ū brahmabandhū.
analyzed: ūru saddāḥ upamāna ādi pubbāḥ hoti karabha ūrū saṃhita ūrū sahita ūrū saññata ūrū sahorū saphorū vāma ūrū lakkhaṇa ūrū ūti yogavibhāgāḥ ū brahmabandhū
translated: The words karabhorū, saṃhitorū, sahitorū, saññatorū, sahorū, saphorū, vāmorū, lakkhaṇorū are feminine in the sense of “simile,” etc.

original: 35. Yuvā ti.
analyzed: yuvā ti
translated: 35. Yuvā.

original: Yuvasaddato ti hotitthiyaṃ. Yuvati.
analyzed: ti hotitthiyam yuvati
translated: The feminine of yuvā is yuvati.

original: 36. Ntantūnaṃ vīmhito vā.
analyzed: nta ntūnam vīm hitaḥ vā
translated: Or with the affix ntūnaṃ.

original: Vīmhi ntantūnaṃ to vā hoti. Gacchatī gacchantī, sīlavatī sīlavantī.
analyzed: to vā hoti gacchatī gacchantī sīlavatī sīlavantī
translated: The affix ntūnaṃ has the augment vīmhita or the affix to. Gacchati, gacchantī; sīlavatī, sīlavantī.

original: 37. Bhavato bhoto.
analyzed: bhavataḥ bhoto
translated: . Bhavato bhoto.

original: Vīmhi bhavato bhotādeso hoti vā. Bhotī bhavantī.
analyzed: bhavataḥ bhotā ādesaḥ hoti vā bhotī bhavantī
translated: The substitution bhoto takes place optionally in the locative case of bhava. Bhotī, bhavantī.

original: 38. Gossāvaṅa.
analyzed: gossāvaṅa
translated: . Gossāvaṅa.

original: Gosaddassa vīmhāvaṅa hoti. Gāvī.
analyzed: go saddassa hoti gāvī
translated: The locative of go has the augment āvaṅa. Gāvī.

original: 39. Puthussa pathavaputhavā.
analyzed: puthussa pathava puthavā
translated: . Puthussa pathavaputhavā.

original: Vīmhi puthussa pathavaputhavā honti. Pathavī, puthavī, ṭhe pathavī.
analyzed: puthussa pathava puthavā honti pathavī puthavī ṭhe pathavī
translated: The affixes pathavaputhavā are added to the locative of puthu. Pathavī, puthavī, ṭhe pathavī.

original: 40. Samāsantva.
analyzed: samāsantva
translated: . Samāsantva.

original: Samāsantva iti cādhikarīyati.
analyzed: iti ca adhikarīyati
translated: The locative is also used as a case-ending.

original: 41. Pāpādīhi bhūmiyā.
analyzed: pāpa ādīhi bhūmiyā
translated: . Pāpādīhi bhūmiyā.

original: Pāpādīhī parā yā bhūmi tassā samāsanto a hoti. Pāpabhūmaṃ, jātibhūmaṃ.
analyzed: parā yā bhūmi tassā hoti pāpa bhūmam jāti bhūmam
translated: The locative of pāpa and other words has the case-ending a. Pāpabhūmaṃ, jātibhūmaṃ.

original: 42. Saṅkhyāhi.
analyzed: saṅkhyāhi
translated: . Saṅkhyāhi.

original: Saṅkhyāhi parā yā bhūmi tassā samāsanto a hoti. Dvibhūmaṃ, tibhūmaṃ.
analyzed: saṅkhyā hi parā yā bhūmi tassā samāsantaḥ hoti dvi bhūmam ti bhūmam
translated: The locative of saṅkhā and other words has the case-ending a. Dvibhūmaṃ, tibhūmaṃ.

original: 43. Nadīgodāvarīnaṃ.
analyzed: nadī godāvarī nam
translated: . Nadīgodāvarīnaṃ.

original: Saṅkhyāhi parāsaṃ nadīgodāvarīnaṃ samāsanto a hoti, pañcanadaṃ, sattagodāvaraṃ, saṅkhyāhitveva? Mahānadī, nadīgodāvarīnanti kiṃ? Dasitthi.
analyzed: saṅkhyāhi parāsam samāsantaḥ hoti pañca nadam satta godāvaram saṅkhyā hi iva mahā nadī kim
translated: When a number is compounded with a river-name ending in -ā, a is the prefix, as pañcanadaṃ, sattagodāvaraṃ. But when the number is not compounded, as mahānadī, nadīgodāvarī, what is the reason? dasitthi.

original: 44. Asaṅkhyehi cāṅgulyānaññāsaṅkhyatthesu.
analyzed: asaṅkhyehi ca aṅguli an aññā saṅkhya tthesu
translated: . And with fingers, etc., when the number is not expressed.

original: Asaṅkhyehi saṅkhyāhi ca parāya aṅgulyā samāsanto a hoti no ce aññapadatthe asaṅkhyatthe
analyzed: a saṅkhyehi saṅkhyāhi ca parāya aṅgulyā samāsantaḥ a hoti no ce añña padatthe a saṅkhyatthe
translated: When a number is compounded with a finger, etc., a is the prefix, but not when the number is expressed, nor when the compound is not in the sense of “one”.

original: ca samāso vattate. Niggatamaṅgulīhi niraṅgulaṃ, accaṅgulaṃ, dve aṅguliyo samāhaṭā
analyzed: ca samāsaḥ vattate niggatam aṅgulīhi niraṅgulam accaṅgulam dve aṅguliyaḥ samāhaṭā
translated: niggatamaṅgulīhi niraṅgulaṃ, accaṅgulaṃ, dve aṅguliyo samāhaṭā

original: dvaṅgulaṃ, anaññāsaṅkhyatthesūti kiṃ? Pañcaṅguli hattho, upaṅguli, kathaṃ ‘dve aṅgulīmānamassāti
analyzed: dvi aṅgulam anaññāsaṅkhyatthesu iti kim pañca aṅguli hatthaḥ upaṅguli katham dve aṅgulī mānam assa ati
translated: dvaṅgulaṃ, anaññāsaṅkhyatthesūti kiṃ? Pañcaṅguli hattho, upaṅguli, kathaṃ ‘dve aṅgulīmānamassāti

original: dvaṅgula’nti? Nātra samāsoññapadatthe vihito mattādīnaṃ lope kate tattha vattate.
analyzed: na atra vihitaḥ matta ādīnam lope kate tattha vattate
translated: dvaṅgula’nti? Nātra samāsoññapadatthe vihito mattādīnaṃ lope kate tattha vattate.

original: Aṅgulasaddo vā pamāṇavāci saddantaraṃ, yathā ‘senaṅgulappamāṇena aṅgulānaṃ sataṃ
analyzed: aṅgula saddaḥ vā pamāṇa vāci saddantaram yathā aṅgulānam satam
translated: Aṅgulasaddo vā pamāṇavāci saddantaraṃ, yathā ‘senaṅgulappamāṇena aṅgulānaṃ sataṃ

original: puṇṇaṃ catuddasa vā aṅgulānī’ti.
analyzed: puṇṇam catuddasa vai aṅgulāni iti
translated: puṇṇaṃ catuddasa vā aṅgulānī’ti.

original: 45. Dīghāhovassekadesehi ca rattyā.
analyzed: dīgha aha vassa ika desehi ca rattyā
translated: . And with long, etc., and with night.

original: Dīghādīhi asaṅkhyehi saṅkhyāhi ca paramasmā rattiyā samāsanto a hoti. Dīgharattaṃ,
analyzed: dīgha ādīhi asaṅkhyehi saṅkhyāhi ca paramasmai rattiyā samāsantaḥ a hoti dīgharattam
translated: With Dīghā, etc., with the indeclinable asaṅkhyā, and with the indeclinable paramā, the compound ends in a. Dīgharattaṃ,

original: ahorattaṃ (tto), vassārattaṃ (tto), pubbarattaṃ, apararattaṃ, aḍḍhurattaṃ, atikkanto
analyzed: ahorattam vassārattam pubbarattam apararattam aḍḍhurattam atikkanto
translated: ahorattaṃ (tto), vassārattaṃ (tto), pubbarattaṃ, apararattaṃ, aḍḍhurattaṃ, atikkanto

original: rattiṃ atiratto, dverattī samāhaṭā dirattaṃ (tto), vā kvaci bahulādhikārā ekarattaṃ
analyzed: rattim atirattaḥ dverattī samāhaṭāḥ dirattam ttaḥ vā kvacid bahula adhikārāḥ ekarattam
translated: rattiṃ atiratto, dverattī samāhaṭā dirattaṃ (tto), vā kvaci bahulādhikārā ekarattaṃ

original: (tto), ekaratti, anaññāsaṅkhyatthesutveva? Dīgharattihemanto, uparatti, kvaci hoteva
analyzed: tto eka ratti dīgha ratti hemantaḥ upa ratti kvaci hotā iva
translated: (tto), ekaratti, anaññāsaṅkhyatthesutveva? Dīgharattihemanto, uparatti, kvaci hoteva

original: bahulaṃ vidhānāyathārattaṃ.
analyzed: bahulam vidhāna a yathārattam
translated: bahulaṃ vidhānāyathārattaṃ.

original: 46. Gotvacatthe cālope.
analyzed: go tvacatthe ca a lope
translated: . And in the sense of ‘cattle’ with cālope.

original: Gosaddā alopavisayā samāsanto a hoti na ce catthe samāso aññapadatthe asaṅkhyatthe
analyzed: go saddāḥ a lopa visayā samāsa antaḥ a hoti na ce ca tthe samāsaḥ añña pada tthe a saṅkhyā atthe
translated: The word go, with the indeclinable alopa, forms a compound ending in a, not in the sense of ‘not’ but in the sense of another word and in the sense of an indefinite number,

original: ca, rājagavo, paramagavo, pañcagavadhano, dasagavaṃ, alopeti kiṃ? Pañcahi gohi kīto
analyzed: ca rājagavaḥ paramagavaḥ pañcagava dhanaḥ dasagavam kim pañcahi
translated: rājagavo, paramagavo, pañcagavadhano, dasagavaṃ, alopeti kiṃ? Pañcahi gohi kīto

original: pañcagu, acattheti ki? Ajassagāvo, anaññāsaṅkhyatthesutveva? Cittagu, upagu.
analyzed: pañcagu a c atthā iti ki ajassagāvaḥ cittagu upagu
translated: pañcagu, acattheti ki? Ajassagāvo, anaññāsaṅkhyatthesutveva? Cittagu, upagu.

original: 47. Rattindivadāragavacaturassā.
analyzed: rattindiva dāragava caturassā
translated: . With ratti, divā, dārā, and gava, and with caturassā.

original: Ete saddā aantā nipaccante. Ratto ca divā ca rattindivaṃ, ratti ca divā ca rattindivaṃ, dārā ca gāvo ca dāragavaṃ, catasso assiyo assa caturasso.
analyzed: ete saddāḥ a antāḥ nipaccante rattaḥ ca divā ca rattiṃdivam ratti ca divā ca rattiṃdivam dārā ca gāvaḥ ca dāragavam catassaḥ assiyaḥ assa caturassaḥ
translated: These are the words that are declined. Night and day are rattindivaṃ, and night and day are rattindivaṃ. Wives and cattle are dāragavaṃ, and four horses are caturasso.

original: 48. Āyāmenugavaṃ.
analyzed: āyāmenugavam
translated: . Āyāmenugavaṃ.

original: Anugavanti nipaccate āyāme gamyamāne. Anugavaṃ sakaṭaṃ, āyāmeti kiṃ? Gunnaṃ pañchā anugu.
analyzed: anugavanti nipaccate āyāme gamyamāne anugavam sakaṭam āyāma iti kim anugu
translated: Anugavanti nipaccate āyāme gamyamāne. Anugavaṃ sakaṭaṃ, āyāmeti kiṃ? Gunnaṃ pañchā anugu.

original: 49. Akkhismāññatthe. Akkhismā samāsanto a hoti aññatthe ce samādhasā. Visālakkho, visālakkhī.
analyzed: akkhisma aññatthe akkhisma samāsantaḥ a hoti aññatthe ce samādhasā visālakkhaḥ visālakkhī
translated: . Akkhismāññatthe. Akkhismā samāsanto a hoti aññatthe ce samādhasā. Visālakkho, visālakkhī.

original: 50. Dārumyaṅgulyā.
analyzed: dārumyā aṅgulyā
translated: . Dārumyaṅgulyā.

original: Aṅgulantā aññapadatthe dārumhi samāsanto a hoti. Dvaṅgulaṃdāru, pañcaṅgulaṃ, aṅgulisadisāvayavaṃ
analyzed: aṅgula antā añña pada tthe dārumhi samāsa antaḥ hoti dvaṅgulam dāru pañcaṅgulam aṅguli sadisa avayavam
translated: Aṅgulantā aññapadatthe dārumhi samāsanto a hoti. Dvaṅgulaṃdāru, pañcaṅgulaṃ, aṅgulisadisāvayavaṃ

original: dhaññādīnaṃ vikkhepakaṃ dāruṃ vuccate, pamāṇe tu pubbe viya siddhaṃ sakharājasaddā
analyzed: dhañña ādīnam vikkhepakam dārum vuccate pamāṇe tu pubbe viya siddham sakha rāja saddā
translated: grain, etc., is called a stick for throwing, but in the case of a measure it is established as before, like the word sakharāja.

original: akārantāva, sissopi na dissati, gāṇḍī vadhanvāti pakatantarena siddhaṃ.
analyzed: na dissati na dissati
translated: They are only in the accusative case, and the affix is not seen, but it is established by the rule gāṇḍī vadhanvā.

original: 51. Ci vītihāre.
analyzed: ci vīti hāre
translated: . Ci vītihāre.

original: Oghābyatihāre gamyamāne aññapadatthe vattamānato ci hoti. Kesākesi daṇḍādaṇḍi, cakāro “cismi”nti (3.66) visesanattho, sugandhi, duggantīti payogo na dissate.
analyzed: ogha abyatihāre gamyamāne añña padatthe vattamānataḥ ci hoti kesākesi daṇḍādaṇḍi cakāro cismin ti visesana atthaḥ sugandhi dugganti iti payogaḥ na dissate
translated: When the meaning is “going beyond the flood”, ci is used because of the occurrence of the word gamya. Kesākesi, daṇḍādaṇḍi. The particle ca is for the purpose of distinguishing “cismi”. Sugandhi, duggantīti payogo na dissate.

original: 52. Ltvitthiyūhi ko.
analyzed: l tu itthi yūhi kaḥ
translated: . Ltvitthiyūhi ko.

original: Ltuppaccayantehi, itthiyamīkārūkārantehi ca bahulaṃ kappaccayo hoti aññapadatthe. Bahukattuko, bahukumāriko, bahubrahmabandhuko, bahulaṃtveva? Subbhū.
analyzed: ltup paccaya antehi itthiyamī kārūkāra antehi ca bahulam ka ppaccayaḥ hoti añña pada atthe bahu kattukaḥ bahu kumārikaḥ bahu brahmabandhukaḥ bahulam tu eva sup bhū
translated: Ltuppaccayantehi, itthiyamīkārūkārantehi ca bahulaṃ kappaccayo hoti aññapadatthe. Bahukattuko, bahukumāriko, bahubrahmabandhuko, bahulaṃtveva? Subbhū.

original: 53. Vāññato.
analyzed: vā añ a taḥ
translated: . Vāññato.

original: Aññehi aññapadatthe ko vā bahulaṃ hoti. Bahumālako, bahumālo.
analyzed: aññehi añña pada tthe kaḥ vā bahulam hoti bahu mālakaḥ bahu mālaḥ
translated: Aññehi aññapadatthe ko vā bahulaṃ hoti. Bahumālako, bahumālo.

original: 54. Uttarapade. Etamadhikataṃ veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: uttara pade etam adhikatam veditabbam
translated: . Uttarapade. Etamadhikataṃ veditabbaṃ.

original: 55. Imassidaṃ.
analyzed: imaḥ idam
translated: . Imassidaṃ.

original: Uttarapade parato imassa idaṃ hoti. Idamaṭṭhitā, idappaccayatā, niggahītalopo passa ca dvibhāvo.
analyzed: uttara pade paratas imassa idam hoti idamaṭṭhitā idappaccaya tā niggahīta lopaḥ passa ca dvi bhāvaḥ
translated: Uttarapade parato imassa idaṃ hoti. Idamaṭṭhitā, idappaccayatā, niggahītalopo passa ca dvibhāvo.

original: 56. Puṃ pumassa vā. Pumassa puṃ hotuttarapade vibhāsā. Pulliṅgaṃ, pumaliṅgaṃ.
analyzed: pum pumassa vā pumassa pum hot uttara pade vibhāsā pulliṅgam puma liṅgam
translated: . Puṃ pumassa vā. Pumassa puṃ hotuttarapade vibhāsā. Pulliṅgaṃ, pumaliṅgaṃ.

original: 57. Ṭantantūnaṃ.
analyzed: ṭan tan tu ūnam
translated: . Ṭantantūnaṃ.

original: Esaṃ ṭa hotuttarapade kvaci vā. Bhavampatiṭṭhāmayaṃ, bhagavaṃmūlakā no dhammā, bahulādhikārā tarādīsu ca pageva mahattarī, rattaññumahattaṃ.
analyzed: kvaci vā bhavampatiṭṭhāmayam bhagavaṃmūlakāḥ no dhammāḥ bahula adhikārā tara ādīsu ca pagā iva mahattarī
translated: Bhavampatiṭṭhāmayaṃ, bhagavaṃmūlakā no dhammā, bahulādhikārā tarādīsu ca pageva mahattarī, rattaññumahattaṃ.

original: 58. A. Esaṃ a hotuttarapade. Guṇavantapatiṭṭho-smi.
analyzed: a hot uttara pade
translated: . A. The particle a is used after a word ending in a vowel. Guṇavantapatiṭṭho-smi.

original: 59. Manādyāpādīnamo maye ca. Manādīnamāpādīnaṃ ca o hotuttarapade maye ca. Manoseṭṭhā, manomayā, rajojallaṃ, rajomayaṃ, āpogataṃ, āpomayaṃ, anuyanti disodisaṃ.
analyzed: maye ca manādīnam āpādīnam ca o hotṛ uttara pade maye ca manoseṭṭhāḥ manaḥ mayāḥ rajaḥ jallam rajaḥ mayam āpaḥ gatam āpaḥ mayam anuyanti disaḥ disam
translated: . Manādyāpādīnamo maye ca. The particle o is used after manādika and apādīnaṃ, and the particle maye ca. Manoseṭṭhā, manomayā, rajojallaṃ, rajomayaṃ, āpogataṃ, āpomayaṃ, anuyanti disodisaṃ.

original: 60. Parassa saṅkhyāsu.
analyzed: parassa saṅkhyāsu
translated: . Parassa saṅkhyāsu.

original: Saṅkhyāsuttarapadesu parassa o hoti. Parosataṃ, parosahassaṃ, saṅkhyāsūti kiṃ? Paradattūpajīvino.
analyzed: saṅkhyā su ttara padesu parassa o hoti parosatam parosahassam saṅkhyāsu iti kim para dattu upajīvinaḥ
translated: The particle o is used after parassa in the sense of a number. Parosataṃ, parosahassaṃ. Saṅkhyāsūti kiṃ? Paradattūpajīvino.

original: 61. Jane puthassu.
analyzed: jane puthassu
translated: . Jane puthassu.

original: Jane uttarapade puthassa u hoti. Ariyehi puthagevāyaṃ janoti puthujjano.
analyzed: jane uttara pade puthassa u hoti ariyehi puthak eva ayam janoti puthujjanaḥ
translated: The particle u is used after puthassa in the sense of people. Ariyehi puthagevāyaṃ janoti puthujjano.

original: 62. So chassāhāyatane vā.
analyzed: saḥ chas sāha āyatane vā
translated: . So chassāhāyatane vā.

original: Ahe āyatane cuttarapade chassa so vā hoti. Sāhaṃ chāhaṃ, saḷāyatanaṃ, chaḷāyatanaṃ.
analyzed: ahe āyatane c uttara pade chassa saḥ vā hoti sāham chāham saḷāyatanam chaḷāyatanam
translated: The particles so and vā are used after chassa in the sense of āyatana. Sāhaṃ chāhaṃ, saḷāyatanaṃ, chaḷāyatanaṃ.

original: 63. Ltupitādīnamāraṅaraṅa.
analyzed: l tup ita ādīn am āraṅaraṅa
translated: . Ltupitādīnamāraṅaraṅa.

original: Ltuppaccayantānaṃ pitādīnañca yathākkamamāraṅaraṅa vā hontuttarapade, satthāradassanaṃ, kattāraniddeso, mātarapitaro, vātveva? Satthudassanaṃ, mātāpitaro.
analyzed: ltup paccaya antānam pitā ādīnam ca vā hontu uttara pade satthāra dassanam kattāra niddesaḥ mātara pitaraḥ satthu dassanam mātā pitaraḥ
translated: And in the words pitā, etc., which are derived from ltu, the words āraṅaraṅa, etc., are respectively used as the first members, and the words satthāradassanaṃ, kattāraniddeso, mātarapitaro, vātveva? satthudassanaṃ, mātāpitaro are used as the second members.

original: 64. Vijjāyonisambandhānamā tatra catthe.
analyzed: vijjā yoni sambandhā namā tatra catthe
translated: . In the words vijjā, yoni, and sambandha, the words ā, tatra, cattha are used.

original: Ltupitādīnaṃ vijjāsambandhīnaṃ yonisambandhīnaṃ ca tesveva ltupitādīsu vijjāyonisambandhisuttarapadesu
analyzed: ltupita ādīnam vijjā sambandhīnam yoni sambandhīnam ca tesu eva ltupita ādīsu vijjā yoni sambandhi suttara padesu
translated: In the words vijjā, yoni, and sambandha, which are derived from ltu, pitā, etc., the words ā, tatra, cattha are used as the second members in the words vijjā, yoni, and sambandha, which are derived from ltu, pitā, etc.

original: catthavisaye ā hoti. Hotāpotaro mātāpitaro, ltupitādīnaṃ tveva? Puttabhātaro, tatreti
analyzed: ā hoti hotā potaraḥ mātā pitaraḥ tu eva putta bhātaraḥ tatra iti
translated: . In the words hotā, potā, mātāpitaro, the words ā, tatra, cattha are used. In the words puttabhātaro, the words ā, tatra, cattha are used.

original: kiṃ? Pitupitāmahā, cattheti kiṃ? Mātubhātā, vijjāyonisambandhānanti kiṃ? Dātubhattāro.🔽65. Putte.
analyzed: kim pitu pitāmahā cattha iti kim mātu bhātā kim dātu bhattāro  putte
translated: . In the words pitupitāmahā, the words ā, tatra, cattha are used. In the words mātubhātā, the words ā, tatra, cattha are used. In the words dātubhattāro, the words ā, tatra, cattha are used.🔽. In the words putte, the words ā, tatra, cattha are used.

original: Putte uttarapade catthavisaye ltupitādīnaṃ vijjāyoni sambandhānamā hoti. Pitāputtā, mātāputtā.🔽66. Cismiṃ.🔽Cippaccayante uttarapade ā hoti. Kesākesi, muṭṭhāmuṭṭhi.
analyzed: putte uttara pade hoti pitā puttā mātā puttā  ci smiṃ  cip paccaya ante uttara pade ā hoti kesākesi muṭṭhāmuṭṭhi
translated: In the words pitāputtā, mātāputtā, the words ā, tatra, cattha are used.🔽. In the words kesā, muṭṭhā, the words ā, tatra, cattha are used.

original: 67. Itthiyambhāsitapumitthī pumevekatthe.
analyzed: itthiyam bhāsita pum itthī pum eva ekatthe
translated: . In the words itthiyambhāsitapumitthī, pumevekatthe, the words ā, tatra, cattha are used.

original: Itthiyaṃ vattamāne ekatthe samānādhikaraṇe uttarapade pare bhāsitapumā itthī pumeva🔽hoti. Kumārabhariyo, dīghajaṅgho, yuvajāyo, itthiyanti kiṃ? Kalyāṇī padhānamesaṃ
analyzed: itthiyam vattamāne ekatthe samāna adhikaraṇe uttara pade pare bhāsita pumā itthī pumā eva  hoti kumāra bhariyaḥ dīgha jaṅghaḥ yuva jāyo kim kalyāṇī
translated: When used with a feminine noun in the same case, the masculine form of the word is used for the feminine.🔽A young wife, long-legged, young women.🔽What is the feminine? A good wife, a good practice.🔽What is the masculine? A young wife, a husband.

original: kalyāṇippadhānā, bhāsitapumeti kiṃ? Kaññābhariyo, itthīti kiṃ? Gāmaṇikulaṃ diṭṭhi
analyzed: kalyāṇippadhānā bhāsita pumā iti kim kaññābhariyaḥ itthī iti kim gāmaṇi kulam
translated: What is the feminine? A village family, a view.

original: assa gāmaṇidiṭṭhi, ekattheti kiṃ? Kalyāṇiyā mātā kalyāṇimātā.
analyzed: ekattha iti kim kalyāṇiyāḥ mātā kalyāṇi mātā
translated: What is the same case? A good mother, a good wife.

original: 68. Kvaci paccaye.
analyzed: kvaci pat caye
translated: . Sometimes in a condition.

original: Bhāsitapumitthī paccaye kvaci pumeva moti. Byattatarā, byattatamā.
analyzed: bhāsita pum itthī paccaye kvaci pum eva mā iti byattatarā byattatamā
translated: The masculine form is used for the feminine in a condition. More beautiful, most beautiful.

original: 69. Sabbādayo vuttimatte.
analyzed: sabba ādayaḥ vuttimatte
translated: . All endings in mere usage.

original: Itthivācakā sabbādayo vuttimatte pumeva honti. Tassā mukhaṃ tammukhaṃ, tassaṃ tatra, tāya tato, tassaṃ velāyaṃ tadā.
analyzed: itthi vācakā sabba ādayaḥ vuttimatte pum eva honti tassā mukham tammukham tassam tatra tāya tato tassam tadā
translated: All endings denoting a feminine are used as masculine in mere usage. Her face, that face. There, by that, at that time.

original: 70. Jāyāya jayaṃ patimhi.
analyzed: jāyāya jayam patimhi
translated: . Victory in a wife in a husband.

original: Patimhi pare jāyāya jayaṃ hoti, jayampatī, ‘jānipatī’ti pakatantarena siddhaṃ, tathā ‘dampatī, jampatī’ti.
analyzed: patimhi pare jāyāya jayam hoti jayampatī jānipatī iti pakata antarena siddham tathā dampatī jampatī iti
translated: After a word for a wife, victory is used for a husband. Victory in a husband, ‘husband and wife’ is established by the general rule. Likewise ‘couple’, ‘husband and wife’.

original: 71. Saññāyamudodakassa.
analyzed: saññāyamudodakassa
translated: . In the water of a river.

original: Saññāyamudakassuttarapade udādeso hoti. Udadhi, udapānaṃ.
analyzed: saññā ayam udakaḥ uttara pade ud ādesaḥ hoti udadhi udapānam
translated: The word udaka has the augment udā in the sense of water. Udadhi, udapāna.

original: 72. Kumbhādīsu vā.
analyzed: kumbha ādīsu vā
translated: . In kumbha, etc.,

original: Kumbhādīsuttarapadesu udakassa udādeso vā hoti. Udakumbho udakakumbho, udapatto udakapatto, udabindhu udakabindhu, ākatigaṇo-yaṃ.
analyzed: kumbha ādīsu uttara padesu udakassa udādesaḥ vā hoti uda kumbhaḥ udaka kumbhaḥ uda pattaḥ udaka pattaḥ uda bindhu udaka bindhu
translated: The word udaka has the augment udā in the sense of water in the words for the upper parts of kumbha, etc. Udakumbho, udakakumbho, udapatto, udakapatto, udabindhu, udakabindhu. The group āka.

original: 73. Sotādīsūlopo.
analyzed: so ta ādi sū lopaḥ
translated: . In sota, etc., the augment ussa is lost.

original: Sotādīsuttarapadesu udakassa ussa lopo hoti. Dakasotaṃ, dakarakkhaso.
analyzed: sota ādīsu uttara padesu udakassa ussa lopaḥ hoti daka sotam daka rakkhaso
translated: The augment ussa is lost in the words for the upper parts of sota, etc. Dakasotaṃ, dakarakkhaso.

original: 74. Ṭa naña ssa.
analyzed: ṭa nañaḥ ssa
translated: . Ṭa naña ssa.

original: Uttarapade naña saddassa ṭa hoti. Abrāhmaṇo, ñakāro kiṃ? Kevalassa mā hotu pāmanaputto.
analyzed: uttara pade naña saddassa ṭa hoti a brāhmaṇaḥ ñakāraḥ kim kevalassa mā hotu pāmanaputto
translated: The augment naña becomes ṭa in the following word. Abrāhmaṇo. What is the purpose of the affix ñaka? Let it not be the son of a mere pāmanapa.

original: 75. Ana sare.
analyzed: ana sare
translated: . Ana sare.

original: Sarādo uttarapade naña saddassa ana hoti. Anakkhātaṃ.
analyzed: sara ādaḥ uttara pade naña saddassa ana hoti an akkhātam
translated: The augment ana is added to naña in the following word. Anakkhātaṃ.

original: 76. Nakhādayo.
analyzed: nakha ādayaḥ
translated: . Nakhādayo.

original: Nakhādayo saddā anana ṭādesā nipaccante. Nāssa khamatthīti nakho, akhamaññaṃ, saññāsaddesu
analyzed: nakha ādayaḥ saddāḥ ananaḥ ṭādesāḥ nipaccante na assa kham atthi iti nakhaḥ akham aññam saññā saddesu
translated: The words beginning with nakha are declined as follows. Nāssa khamatthīti nakho, akhamaññaṃ, in the sense of a sign.

original: ca nipphattimattaṃ yathākathañci kattabbaṃnāssa kulamathīti nakulo, akulamaññaṃ,
analyzed: ca nipphattimattam yathā kathañci kattabbaṃna assa kulamathī iti nakulaḥ a kulamaññam
translated: And in the sense of a mere result, it is to be done in some way or other. Nāssa kulamathīti nakulo, akulamaññaṃ,

original: nakha nakula napuṃsakanakkhatta nāka evamādi.
analyzed: nakha nakula napuṃsaka nakkhatta nāka evamādi
translated: nakha, nakula, napuṃsaka, nakkhatta, nāka, etc.

original: 77. Nago vāppāṇini.
analyzed: nagaḥ vā ap pāṇini
translated: 77. Naga and appāṇinī.

original: Nagaiccappāṇini vā nipaccate. Nago rukkho, nago pabbato, ago rukkho, ago pabbato, appāṇinīti kiṃ? Ago vasalo sītena.
analyzed: vā nipaccate nagaḥ rukkhaḥ nagaḥ pabbataḥ agaḥ rukkhaḥ agaḥ pabbataḥ appāṇinī iti kim agaḥ vasalaḥ sītena
translated: Nagaiccappāṇini vā nipaccate. Nago rukkho, nago pabbato, ago rukkho, ago pabbato, appāṇinīti kiṃ? Ago vasalo sītena.

original: 78. Sahassa so-ññatthe.
analyzed: sahassa soññatthe
translated: . Sahassa so-ññatthe.

original: Aññapadatthavutthimhi samāse uttarapade pare sahassa so vā hoti. Saputto, sahaputto, aññattheti kiṃ? Saha katvā, saha yujjhitvā.
analyzed: añña pada attha vutthimhi samāse uttara pade pare sahassa saḥ vā hoti sa putto saha putto aññattha iti kim saha katvā saha yujjhitvā
translated: Aññapadatthavutthimhi samāse uttarapade pare sahassa so vā hoti. Saputto, sahaputto, aññattheti kiṃ? Saha katvā, saha yujjhitvā.

original: 79. Saññāyaṃ.
analyzed: saññāyam
translated: . Saññāyaṃ.

original: Sahassuttarapade so hoti saññāyaṃ. Sāssatthaṃ, sapalāsaṃ.
analyzed: sahassa uttara pade saḥ hoti saññāyam sa assattham sa palāsam
translated: Sahassuttarapade so hoti saññāyaṃ. Sāssatthaṃ, sapalāsaṃ.

original: 80. Appaccakkhe.
analyzed: a paccakkhe
translated: . Appaccakkhe.

original: Appaccakkhe gamyamāne sahassa so hotuttarapade, sāggi kapoto, sapisācā vātamaṇḍalikā.
analyzed: appaccakkhe gamyamāne sahassa so hotu uttara pade sa aggi kapoto sa pisācā vātamaṇḍalikā
translated: Appaccakkhe gamyamāne sahassa so hotuttarapade, sāggi kapoto, sapisācā vātamaṇḍalikā.

original: 81. Akāle sakatthe.
analyzed: a kāle sa katthe
translated: . Akāle sakatthe.

original: Sakatthappadhānassa sahasaddassa akāle uttarapade so hoti. Sampannaṃ brahmaṃ sabrahmaṃ, sacakkaṃ nidhehi, sadhuraṃ pājehi, akāleti kiṃ? Saha pubbaṇhaṃ, sahāparaṇhaṃ.
analyzed: sa ka attha ppadhānassa saha saddassa a kāle uttara pade saḥ hoti sampannam brahmam sa brahmam sa cakkam nidhehi sa dhuram pājehi akāle iti kim saha pubbaṇham saha aparaṇham
translated: Sakatthappadhānassa sahasaddassa akāle uttarapade so hoti. Sampannaṃ brahmaṃ sabrahmaṃ, sacakkaṃ nidhehi, sadhuraṃ pājehi, akāleti kiṃ? Saha pubbaṇhaṃ, sahāparaṇhaṃ.

original: 82. Ganthantādhikye.
analyzed: ganthanta ādhikye
translated: . Ganthantādhikye.

original: Ganthante ādhikye ca vattamānassa sahassa so hotuttarapade. Sakalaṃ jotimadhīte samuhuttaṃ, kālattho ārambho, ādhikye-sadoṇā khārī, samāsako kahāpaṇo, niccatthoyamārambho.
analyzed: ādhikye ca vattamānassa sahassa saḥ hotā uttara pade sakalam jotim adhīte sa muhuttam kālatthaḥ ārambhaḥ khārī samāsakaḥ kahāpaṇaḥ niccatthaḥ ayam ārambhaḥ
translated: The word sahassa becomes so in the sense of “more than a thousand” and in the sense of “all”. The word joti becomes samujjo in the sense of “all”. The word ārambha becomes khārī in the sense of “time”, and kahāpaṇa in the sense of “coin”. The word nicca becomes ārambha in the sense of “always”.

original: 83. Samānassa pakkhādīsu vā.
analyzed: samānassa pakkha ādīsu vā
translated: . The word samāna becomes so in the sense of “wing” and so on.

original: Pakkhādīsuttarapadesu samānassa so hoti vā. Sapakkho samānapakkho, sajoti samānajoti,
analyzed: pakkha ādīsu uttara padesu samānassa saḥ hoti vā sa pakkhaḥ samāna pakkhaḥ sajoti samāna joti
translated: The word samāna becomes so in the sense of “wing” and so on, in the words that follow. Sapakkho, samānapakkho; sajoti, samānajoti.

original: pakkhādīsūti kiṃ? Samānasīlo, pakkha, joti, janapada, ratti, pattinī, pattī, nābhi,
analyzed: pakkha ādīsu iti kim
translated: In the sense of “wing” and so on—what is the meaning of this? Samānasīlo, pakkha, joti, janapada, ratti, pattinī, pattī, nābhi,

original: bandhu brahmacārī, nāma, gotta, rūpa, ṭhāna, vaṇṇa, vayo, vacana, dhamma, jātiya, ghacca.
analyzed: bandhu brahmacārī nāma gotta rūpa ṭhāna vaṇṇa vayaḥ vacana dhamma jātiya ghacca
translated: bandhu brahmacārī, nāma, gotta, rūpa, ṭhāna, vaṇṇa, vayo, vacana, dhamma, jātiya, ghacca.

original: 84. Udare iye.
analyzed: udare iye
translated: . The word udara becomes iye.

original: Udare iye pare parato samānassa so vā hoti. Sodariyo, samānodariyo, iyeti kiṃ? Samānodaratā.
analyzed: udare iye pare paratas samānassa saḥ vā hoti sodariyaḥ samāna udariyaḥ iyā iti kim samāna udara tā
translated: The word udara becomes iye in the sense of “belly”, in the words that follow. Sodariyo, samānodariyo. Iyeti—what is the meaning of this? Samānodaratā.

original: 85. Rīrikkhakesu.
analyzed: rīrikkhakesu
translated: . The word rīrikkha becomes so in the sense of “similar”.

original: Etesu samānassa so hoti. Sarī, sarikkho, sariso.
analyzed: etesu samānassa saḥ hoti sarī sarikkhaḥ sarisaḥ
translated: The word rīrikkha becomes so in the sense of “similar”. Sarī, sarikkho, sariso.

original: 86. Sabbādīnamā.
analyzed: sap ba ādīn amā
translated: . The word sabba becomes ā in the sense of “similar”.

original: Rīrikkhakesu sabbādīnamā hoti. Yādī, yādikkho, yādiso.
analyzed: rīrikkhakesu sabba ādi namā hoti yādī yādikkhaḥ yādisaḥ
translated: The word sabba becomes ā in the sense of “similar” in the words that follow. Yādī, yādikkho, yādiso.

original: 87. Ntakimimānaṃ ṭākīṭī.
analyzed: nta kim imānam ṭākīṭī
translated: 87. Ntakimimānaṃ ṭākīṭī.

original: Rīrikkhakesu ntasadda kiṃsadda imasaddānaṃ ṭākīṭī honti yathākkamaṃ. Bhavādī, bhavādikkho, bhavādiso, kīdī, kīdikkho, kīdiso, īdī, īdikkho, īdiso.🔽88. Tumhāmhānaṃ tāmekasmiṃ.
analyzed: rīrikkhakesu nta sadda kiṃsadda ima saddānam ṭā kīṭī honti yathākkamam bhavādī bhavādikkhaḥ bhavādiso kīdī kīdikkhaḥ kīdisaḥ īdī īdikkhaḥ īdisaḥ  tumha amhānam tām ekasmin
translated: 87. In the case of the -īrikkhaka, the -nt- is -k-, the -im- is -m-, and the -as- is -s-, respectively. Bhavādī, bhavādikkho, bhavādiso, kīdī, kīdikkho, kīdiso, īdī, īdikkho, īdiso.

original: Rīrikkhakesu tumhāmhānaṃ tāmā hontekasmiṃ yathākkamaṃ. Tādī, tādikkho, tādiso, mādī, mādikkho, mādiso. Ekasminti kiṃ? Tumhādī, amhādī, tumhādikkho, amhādikkho, tumhādiso, amhādiso.🔽89. Taṃ mamaññatra.
analyzed: rīrikkhakesu tumha amhānam tāmāḥ honti ekasmin yathākkamam tādī tādikkhaḥ tādisaḥ mādī mādikkhaḥ mādisaḥ ekasmin ti kim tumhādī amhādī tumhādikkhaḥ amhādikkhaḥ tumhādisaḥ amhādisaḥ  tam mamaññatra
translated: . In the case of the -īrikkhaka, the -t- is -t-, the -am- is -m-, and the -as- is -s-, respectively, in the case of tumhā and amhā. Tādī, tādikkho, tādiso, mādī, mādikkho, mādiso.

original: Rīrikkhakantato aññasmiṃ uttarapade tumhāmhānamekasmiṃ taṃmaṃ honti yathākkamaṃ, tandīpā, mandīpā, taṃsaraṇā, maṃsaraṇā, tayyogo, mayyogoti bindulopo.🔽90. Vetasseṭa.🔽Rīrikkhakesvetasseṭa vā hoti, edī, etādī, edikkho, etādikkho, ediso, etādiso.
analyzed: rīrikkha kantataḥ aññasmin uttara pade tumha amhānam ekasmin taṃ maṃ honti yathākkamam tandīpā mandīpā taṃsaraṇā maṃsaraṇā bindu lopaḥ  vā itas seṭa  vā hoti edī etādī edikkhaḥ etādikkhaḥ edisaḥ etādisaḥ
translated: . In the case of the -īrikkhaka, the -t- is -t-, the -am- is -m-, and the -as- is -s-, respectively, in the case of tumhā and amhā, but not in the case of tumhā and amhā. Tandīpā, mandīpā, taṃsaraṇā, maṃsaraṇā, tayyogo, mayyogo.

original: 91. Vidhādīsu dvissa du.
analyzed: vidha ādīsu dvis sa du
translated: . In the case of the -īrikkhaka, the -t- is -t-, the -am- is -m-, and the -as- is -s-, respectively, in the case of tumhā and amhā, but not in the case of tumhā and amhā. Edī, etādī, edikkho, etādikkho, ediso, etādiso.

original: Dvissa du hoti vidhādīsu, duvidho, dupaṭṭaṃ evamādi.
analyzed: dvissa du hoti vidha ādīsu duvidhaḥ du paṭṭam evamādi
translated: Dvissa is du in vidhādīsu, duvidho, dupaṭṭaṃ, and so on.

original: 92. Di guṇādīsu.
analyzed: di guṇa ādīsu
translated: Di is in guṇādīsu.

original: Guṇādīsu dvissa di hoti, dviguṇaṃ, diratti, digu evamādi.
analyzed: guṇa ādīsu dvis sa di hoti dviguṇam evamādi
translated: Dvissa is di in guṇādīsu, dviguṇaṃ, diratti, digu, and so on.

original: 93. Tīsva.
analyzed: tīsva
translated: Ā is in tīsu.

original: Tīsu dvissa ahoti. Dvattikkhattuṃ, dvittipattapurā.
analyzed: tīsu dvissa ahoti dvatti kkhattum
translated: Dvissa is ā in tīsu, dvattikkhattuṃ, dvittipattapurā.

original: 94. Ā saṅkhyāyāsatādo-naññatthe.
analyzed: ā saṅkhyā yāsa tāda ūnañña tthe
translated: Ā is in saṅkhyāyāsatādo anaññatthe.

original: Saṅkhyāyamuttarapade dvissa ā hoti asatādo anaññadhattha. Dvādasa, dvāvīsati dvattiṃsa, saṅkhyāyanti kiṃ? Dirattaṃ, asatādoti kiṃ? Disataṃ, disahassaṃ. Anaññattheti kiṃ? Dvidasā.
analyzed: saṅkhyāyam uttara pade ā hoti anaññadhattha dvādasa dvāvīsati dvattiṃsa saṅkhyāyanti kim di rattam asatādo iti kim di satam di sahassam anaññattha iti kim dvidasā
translated: Dvissa is ā in saṅkhyāyāsatādo anaññatthe, dvādasa, dvāvīsati, dvattiṃsa; saṅkhyāyanti kiṃ? dirattaṃ; asatādo kiṃ? disataṃ, disahassaṃ; anaññatthe kiṃ? dvidasā.

original: 95. Tisse.
analyzed: tisse
translated: E is in tīsu.

original: Saṅkhyāyamuttarapade tissa e hoti asatādo anaññatthe, terasa, tevīsa, tettiṃsa, saṅkhyāyaṃtveva? Tirattaṃ, asatādotveva? Tisataṃ, anaññatthetveva? Ticatukā.
analyzed: saṅkhyāyam uttara pade tissaḥ e hoti asata adaḥ anaññatthe terasa tevīsa tettiṃsa saṅkhyāyam tu eva tirattam asata adaḥ tu eva tisatam anaññatthe tu eva ticatukā
translated: Dvissa is e in tīsu, terasa, tevīsa, tettiṃsa; saṅkhyāyanti kiṃ? tirattaṃ; asatādotveva tisataṃ; anaññatthetveva ticatukā.

original: 96. Cattālīsādo vā.
analyzed: cattālīsādaḥ vā
translated: Or cattālīsādo.

original: Tisse vā hoti cattālīsādo, tecattālāsaṃ ticattālīsaṃ, tepaññāsaṃ tipaññāsaṃ, tesaṭṭhi tisaṭṭhi, tesattati tisattati, teasīti tiyāsīti, tenavuti tinavuti, asatādotveva? Tisataṃ.🔽97. Dvissā ca.🔽Asatādo-naññatthe cattālīsādo dvisse vā hoti ā ca. Dvecattālīsaṃ, dvācattālīsaṃ dvicattālīsaṃ, dvepaññāsaṃ, dvāpaññāsaṃ dvipaññāsaṃ iccādi.🔽98. Bācattālīsādo.
analyzed: tisse vā hoti cattālīsa ado te cattālāsam ticattālīsam te paññāsam tipaññāsam te saṭṭhi tisaṭṭhi te sattati ti sattati te asīti tiyāsīti tenavuti tinavuti asata ādo tu eva tisatam  dvissā ca  a sata āda onaññatthe cattālīsa ādaḥ dvisse vā hoti ā ca dve cattālīsam dvā cattālīsam dvi cattālīsam dve paññāsam dvāpaññāsam dvipaññāsam iccādi  bācat tālīsādaḥ

original: Dvissa bā vā hoti acattālīsādo-naññatthe. Bārasa dvādasa, bāvīsati dvāvīsati, battiṃsa dvattiṃsa, acattālīsādoti kiṃ? Dvicattālīsaṃ.🔽99. analyzed: dutiyassa saha diyaḍḍha divaḍḍhā
translated: 106. The second, with a half-increase.

original: Aḍḍhā parassa dutiyassa saha aḍḍhasaddena diyaḍḍhadivaḍḍhā honti. Aḍḍhena dutiyo diyaḍḍho, divaḍḍho vā.

original: 107. Sare kada kussuttaratthe.
analyzed: sare kada kus su ttara tthe
translated: . In the sense of “more,” in the northern countries.

original: Kussuttarapadatthe vattamānassa sarādo uttarapade kadādeso hoti. Kadannaṃ, kadasanaṃ, sareti kiṃ? Kuputto, uttarattheti kiṃ? Kuoḍḍho rājā.
analyzed: kussu ttara pada atthe vattamānassa sara ādaḥ uttara pade kad ādesaḥ hoti kadannam kadasanam sara iti kim ku puttaḥ uttaratthā iti kim ku uḍḍhaḥ rājā
translated: In the sense of “more,” the word “more” has the substitution of “ka” for “ku” in the following word. “More food,” “more eating,” “more.” What is the omission? “Bad son,” “more.” What is the northern countries? “More high,” “king.”

original: 108. Kāppatthe.
analyzed: kāppatthe
translated: . In the sense of “less.”

original: Appatthe vattamānassa kussa kā hoti uttarapadatthe, appakaṃ lavaṇaṃ kālavaṇaṃ.
analyzed: appatthe vattamānassa kussa kā hoti uttara pada tthe appakam lavaṇam kālavaṇam
translated: In the sense of “less,” “ka” is used for “ku” in the following word. “Less salt,” “salt-less.”

original: 109. Purise vā.
analyzed: purise vā
translated: . Or in the sense of a man.

original: Kussa purise kā hoti vā. Kāpuriso kupuriso, ayamappattavibhāsā, appatthe tu pubbena niccaṃ hoti īsaṃ puriso kāpuriso.🔽110. Pubbāparajjasāyamajjhehāhassa ṇho.
analyzed: kussa purise kā hoti vā kāpurisaḥ kupurisaḥ ayam appatta vibhāsā appatthe tu pubbena niccam hoti īsam purisaḥ kāpurisaḥ  pubba aparajja sāya majjha iha ahassa ṇhaḥ
translated: In the sense of a man, “ka” is used for “ku” or not. “Bad man,” “good man.” This is the analysis of “less.” But in the sense of “less,” it is always with the preceding word: “a man,” “less,” “good man.”🔽. In the sense of “before,” “after,” “noon,” “evening,” “middle,” “day,” “ṇha.”🔽In the sense of “before,” etc., the substitution of “ṇha” is made for “ha” of the following word. “Before noon,” “after noon,” “today noon,” “evening noon,” “middle noon,” (noon).

original: Pubbādīhuttarapadassa ahassa ṇhādeso hoti, pubbaṇho, aparaṇho, ajjaṇho, sāyaṇho, majjhaṇho (paṇho).
analyzed: pubba ādi ih uttara padassa ahassa ṇha ādesaḥ hoti pubbaṇhaḥ aparaṇhaḥ ajjaṇhaḥ sāyaṇhaḥ majjhaṇhaḥ paṇhaḥ
translated: . In the sense of “before,” “after,” “noon,” “evening,” “middle,” “day,” “ṇha.”

original: Iti moggallāne byākaraṇe vuttiyaṃ
analyzed: iti moggallāne byākaraṇe vuttiyam
translated: Thus in the explanation of Moggallāna’s verse,

original: Samāsakaṇḍo tatiyo.
analyzed: samāsa kaṇḍaḥ tatiyaḥ
translated: The third chapter is finished.

analyzed: catutthaḥ kaṇḍaḥ ṇa ādi
translated: The fourth chapter (ṇādi)
