original: Kattikādīhi vidhavādīhi ca ṇeyyaṇerā vā yathākkamaṃ honti apacce, kattikeyyo, venateyyo, bhāgineyyo iccādi, vedhavero, bandhakero, nālikero, sāmaṇero iccādi.
analyzed: kattikā ādīhi vidhavā ādīhi ca ṇeyya ṇerāḥ vā yathākkamam honti apacce kattikeyyaḥ venateyyaḥ bhāgineyyaḥ iccādi vedhaveraḥ bandhakeraḥ nālikeraḥ sāmaṇeraḥ iccādi
translated: Kattikā, etc., and vidhavā, etc., have the forms Kattikeyya, etc., and Venateyyo, etc., respectively, when they are not relatives.

original: 4. Ṇyadiccādīhi.
analyzed: ṇi ad it ca ādīhi
translated: . Ṇyadiccā, etc.

original: Ditippabhutihi ṇyo vā hoti apacce, decco, ādicco, koṇḍañño, gaggyo, bhātabbo iccādi.
analyzed: diti ppa bhutihi ṇyaḥ vā hoti a pacce deccaḥ ādiccaḥ koṇḍaññaḥ gaggyaḥ bhātabbaḥ icca ādi
translated: Ditippabhuti have the form Decco, etc., and Koṇḍañño, etc., respectively, when they are not relatives.

original: 5. Ā ṇi.
analyzed: ā ṇi
translated: 5. Ā ṇi.

original: Akārantato ṇi vā hoti apacce, dakkhi, datthi, doṇi. Vāsavi, vāruṇi iccādi.
analyzed: a kāra antataḥ ṇi vā hoti a pacce dakkhi datthi doṇi vāsavi vāruṇi icca ādi
translated: Akārantas have the form Dakkhi, etc., and Vāsavi, etc., respectively, when they are not relatives.

original: 6. Rājato ñño jātiyaṃ.
analyzed: rājataḥ ññaḥ jātiyam
translated: . Rājato ñño jātiyaṃ.

original: Rājasaddato ñño vā hoti apacce jātiyaṃ gamyamānāyaṃ, rājañño, jātiyanti kiṃ? Rājāpaccaṃ.
analyzed: rāja saddataḥ ññaḥ vā hoti apacce jātiyam gamyamānā iyam rājaññaḥ jātiyanti kim rājāpaccam
translated: Rājā has the form Rājañño when it is a relative.

original: 7. Khattā yiyā.
analyzed: khattā yiyā
translated: . Khattā yiyā.

original: Khattasaddā yaiyā honti apacce jātiyaṃ, khatyo, khattiyo, jātiyaṃtveva? Khatti.
analyzed: khatta saddāḥ yaiyāḥ honti apacce jātiyam khatyaḥ khattiyaḥ jātiyam tu eva khatti
translated: Khatti has the form Khattiyo when it is a relative.

original: 8. Manuto ssasaṇa.
analyzed: manutaḥ ssasaṇa
translated: . Manuto ssasaṇa.

original: Manusaddato jātiyaṃ ssasaṇa honti apacce, manusso, mānuso, itthiyaṃ manussā, mānusī, jātiyaṃtveva? Mānavo.
analyzed: manu saddataḥ jātiyam honti apacce manussaḥ mānusaḥ itthiyam manussā mānusī jātiyam tu eva mānavaḥ
translated: Manu has the form Manussa when it is a relative.

original: 9. Janapadanāmasmā khattiyā raññe ca ṇo.
analyzed: janapada nāmasmā khattiyāḥ raññe ca ṇo
translated: 9. The name of a country, of a Khattiya, of a king, has ṇo.

original: Janapadassa yaṃ nāmaṃ, tannāmasmā khattiyā apacce raññe ca ṇo hoti, pañcālo, kosalo,
analyzed: janapadassa yam nāmam tad nāmasma khattiyāḥ apacce raññe ca no hoti pañcālaḥ kosalo
translated: The name of a country, of a Khattiya who is not a king, and of a king, has ṇo. Pañcāla, Kosala,

original: māgadho, okkāko, janapadanāmasmāti kiṃ? Dāsarathi, khattiyāti kiṃ? Pañcālassa brāhmaṇassa apaccaṃ pañcāli.
analyzed: māgadhaḥ okkākaḥ janapada nāmasma ati kim dāsarathi khattiyā ati kim pañcālassa brāhmaṇassa apaccam pañcāli
translated: Magadha, Okkāka. Janapadanāmasmā. What is the meaning of the word khattiya? Pañcāli of the brahmin Pañcāla.

original: 10. Ṇya kurusivīhi.
analyzed: ṇya kurusivīhi
translated: . Ṇya after Kurusivīhi.

original: Kurusivīhi apacce raññe ca ṇyo hoti. Korabyo, sebyo.
analyzed: kuru sivīhi a pacce raññe ca ṇyaḥ hoti korabyo sebyo
translated: After Kurusivīhi, ṇyo is substituted for the final vowel of a word denoting a king who is not a descendant of the king of Kurus or of the king of Sivi. Korabya, Sebya.

original: 11. Ṇa rāgā tena rattaṃ.
analyzed: ṇa rāgā tena rattam
translated: . Ṇa after rāga, because of the red colour.

original: Rāgavācitatiyantato rattamicchetasmiṃ atthe ṇo hoti, kasāvena rattaṃ kāsāvaṃ, kosumbhaṃ,
analyzed: rattam iccha itasmin atthe no hoti kasāvena rattam kāsāvam kosumbham
translated: After rāga, ṇo is substituted for the final vowel of a word denoting a colour, because of the red colour. Kāsa-ava, kosumba,

original: yāliddaṃ, rāgāti kiṃ? Devadattena rattaṃ vatthaṃ, idha kasmā na hoti? ‘Nīlaṃ pīta’nti,
analyzed: kim devadattena rattam vattham idha kasmai na hoti nīlam pītanti
translated: yālidda. Rāga. What is the meaning of the word devadatta? Vatthaṃ rattaṃ. Why is it not so here? ‘Nīlaṃ pītaṃ’.

original: guṇavacanattā vināpi ṇena ṇatthassābhidhānato.🔽12. Nakkhatteninduyuttena kāle.
analyzed: guṇavacana ttā vinā api ṇena ṇa tthassa abhidhānataḥ  nakkhattena indu yuttena kāle
translated: Because it is a word denoting a quality, the meaning of ṇat is expressed even without ṇo.🔽. Ṇo after nakkhatta, after induyutta, in the sense of time.

original: Tatiyantato nakkhattā tena lakkhite kāle ṇo hoti, tañce nakkhattaminduyuttaṃ hoti,
analyzed: tatiya ntatas nakkhattā tena lakkhite kāle no hoti tat ce nakkhattam indu yuttam hoti
translated: After nakkhatta, ṇo is substituted for the final vowel of a word denoting time, if that nakkhatta is connected with the moon.

original: phussī ratti, phussaṃ ahaṃ, nakkhatteneti kiṃ? Gurunā lakkhitā ratti. Induyutteneti
analyzed: phussī ratti phussam aham nakkhattena iti kim gurunā lakkhitā ratti indu yuttena iti
translated: ‘Phussī ratti, phussaṃ ahaṃ, nakkhatteneti kiṃ? Gurunā lakkhitā ratti. Induyutteneti

original: kiṃ? Katthikāya lakkhito muhutto, kāleti kiṃ? Phussena lakkhitā atthasiddhi, ajjakattikāti
analyzed: kim katthikāya lakkhitaḥ muhuttaḥ kāle ti kim phussena lakkhitā attha siddhi ajjakattikā ti
translated: kiṃ? Katthikāya lakkhito muhutto, kāleti kiṃ? Phussena lakkhitā atthasiddhi, ajjakattikāti

original: kattikāyutte cande kattikāsaddo vattate.
analyzed: kattikā yutte cande kattikā saddaḥ vattate
translated: kattikāyutte cande kattikāsaddo vattate.

original: 13. Sā-ssa devatā puṇṇamāsī.
analyzed: sā assa devatā puṇṇamāsī
translated: . Sā-ssa devatā puṇṇamāsī.

original: Seti paṭhamantā assāti chaṭṭhyatthe ṇo bhavati, yaṃ paṭhamantaṃ, sā ce devatā puṇṇamāsīvā,
analyzed: sā iti paṭhama antā assa ati chaṭṭhī atthe ṇaḥ bhavati yam paṭhama antam sā ce devatā
translated: Seti paṭhamantā assāti chaṭṭhyatthe ṇo bhavati, yaṃ paṭhamantaṃ, sā ce devatā puṇṇamāsīvā,

original: sugato devatā assābhi sogato, māhindo, yāmo, vāruṇo, phussī puṇṇamāsī assa sambandhinīti
analyzed: sugataḥ devatāḥ assa abhi sogataḥ māhindaḥ yāmaḥ vāruṇaḥ phussī puṇṇamāsī assa sambandhinī iti
translated: sugato devatā assābhi sogato, māhindo, yāmo, vāruṇo, phussī puṇṇamāsī assa sambandhinīti

original: phusso, māso, māyo, phagguno, citto, vesākho. Jeṭṭhamūlo, āsaḷho, sāvaṇo, poṭṭhapādo,
analyzed: phussaḥ māsaḥ māyo phagguno cittaḥ vesākhaḥ jeṭṭhamūlaḥ āsaḷhaḥ sāvaṇaḥ poṭṭhapādo
translated: phusso, māso, māyo, phagguno, citto, vesākho. Jeṭṭhamūlo, āsaḷho, sāvaṇo, poṭṭhapādo,

original: assayujo, kattiko, māgasiro, puṇṇamāsīti kiṃ? Phussī pañcamī assa, puṇṇamāsī ca bhatakamāsasambandhinī
analyzed: assayujaḥ kattikaḥ māgasiraḥ puṇṇamāsī iti kim phussī pañcamī assa puṇṇamāsī ca bhataka māsa sambandhinī
translated: assayujo, kattiko, māgasiro, puṇṇamāsīti kiṃ? Phussī pañcamī assa, puṇṇamāsī ca bhatakamāsasambandhinī

original: na hoti… puṇṇo mā assanti nibbacanā, ato eva nipātanā ṇo sāgamo ca, māsasutiyāva
analyzed: na hoti puṇṇaḥ mā assanti nibbacanāḥ atas eva nipātanā ṇo sa āgamaḥ ca māsa sutiyā ava
translated: na hoti… puṇṇo mā assanti nibbacanā, ato eva nipātanā ṇo sāgamo ca, māsasutiyāva

original: na pañcadasa rattādo vidhi.
analyzed: na pañcadasa
translated: Not in the case of the fifteen-day period.

original: 14. Tamadhīte taṃ jānāti kaṇikā ca.
analyzed: tam adhīte tam jānāti kaṇikā ca
translated: He who has learnt it knows it, and the little.

original: Dutiyantato tamadhīte taṃ jānātīti etesvatthesu ṇo hoti ṇo ṇiko ca, byākaraṇamadhīte
analyzed: tam adhīte tam jānāti iti etesu atthesu no hoti ca byākaraṇam adhīte
translated: In the case of the second, he who has learnt it knows it: in these meanings ṇo is added and also ṇiko. He who has learnt grammar

original: jānāti vā veyyākaraṇo, chandaso, kamako, padako, venayiko, suttantiko, dvitaggahaṇaṃ
analyzed: jānāti vā veyyākaraṇaḥ chandasaḥ kamakaḥ padakaḥ venayikaḥ suttantikaḥ dvita ggahaṇam
translated: knows it, or he is a grammarian, a metrist, a lexicographer, a Vinaya expert, a suttanta expert, a dhutaṅga expert. The mention of “two”

original: puthageva vidhānatthaṃ jānanassa ca ajjhenavisayabhāvadassanatthaṃ pasiddhūpasaṅgahatthaṃ ca.
analyzed: puthak eva vidhāna attham jānanassa ca ajjhena visaya bhāva dassana attham pasiddhu upasaṅgaha ttham ca
translated: is for the purpose of the rule in the next section, and for the purpose of showing that the knower is the subject of the rule, and for the purpose of including what is well known.

original: 15. Tassa visaye dese.
analyzed: tassa visaye dese
translated: In the case of his province.

original: Chaṭṭhiyantā visaye desarūpe ṇo hoti, vasātīnaṃ visayo deso vāsāto, deseti kiṃ? Cakkhussa visayo rūpaṃ, devadattassa visayo-nuvāko.
analyzed: chaṭṭhi yantāḥ visaye desa rūpe ṇo hoti vasātīnam visayaḥ desaḥ vāsātaḥ deseti kim cakkhussa visayaḥ rūpam devadattassa visayaḥ anuvākaḥ
translated: In the case of the sixth-case locative, ṇo is added to the locative, the province of the dwellers is the place of dwelling, from vāsā. What is the locative? The object of sight is visible form. The province of Devadatta is a locative.

original: 16. Nivāse tannāme.
analyzed: nivāse tad nāme
translated: In the case of his dwelling.

original: Chaṭṭhiyantā nivāse dese tannāme ṇo hoti, sivīnaṃ nivāso deso sebyo, vāsāto.
analyzed: nivāse dese tad nāme ṇo hoti sivīnam nivāsaḥ desaḥ sebyaḥ vāsātaḥ
translated: In the case of the sixth-case locative, ṇo is added to the locative, the dwelling of the people of Sīvī is the place of dwelling, from vāsā.

original: 17. Adūrabhave.
analyzed: a dūra bhave
translated: In the case of the near province.

original: Chaṭṭhiyantā adūrabhave dese tannāme ṇo hoti, vidisāya adūrabhavaṃ vedisaṃ.
analyzed: adūra bhave dese tad nāme no hoti vidisāya adūra bhavam vedisam
translated: In the case of the sixth-case locative, ṇo is added to the locative, the near province of the region is the place of the region, from vāsā.

original: 18. Tena nibbatte.
analyzed: tena nibbatte
translated: In the case of what is produced by it.

original: Tatiyantā nibbatte dese tannāme ṇo hoti, kusambena nibbattā kosambhī nagarī, kākandī, mākandī, sahassena nibbattā sāhassī parīkhā, hotumhi kattari karaṇe ca yathāyogaṃ tatiyā.
analyzed: tatiya antā nibbatte dese tad nāme ṇo hoti kusambena nibbattā kosambhī nagarī kākandī mākandī sahassena nibbattā sāhassī parīkhā hotumhi kattari karaṇe ca yathāyogam tatiyā
translated: The 3rd case ending becomes ṇo in the name of a place where it is produced, as Kosambhi town produced from the Kusa grass, Kakandi, Makandi, the moat Sahassī produced from a thousand (coins), in the sense of “having been made” and “having been done” respectively.

original: 19. Tamīdhatthi.
analyzed: tam īdhatthi
translated: . Tamīdhatthi.

original: Tanti paṭhamantā idhāti sattamyatthe dese tannāme ṇo hoti, yantaṃ paṭhamantamatthi ce, udumbarā asmiṃ dese santīti odumbaro, bādaro, babbajo.
analyzed: paṭhama antāḥ idha ati sattamī atthe dese tad nāme ṇaḥ hoti ya ntam paṭhama antam atthi ce udumbarāḥ asmin dese santi iti odumbaraḥ bādaraḥ babbajaḥ
translated: The 1st case ending becomes ṇo in the name of a place where it is, if the 1st case ending is there, as Udumbaro, Bādaro, Babbajo, because there are Udumbara trees in this place.

original: 20. Tatra bhave.
analyzed: tatra bhave
translated: . Tatra bhave.

original: Sattamyantā bhavatthe ṇo hoti, udake bhavo odako, oraso, jānapado, māgadho, kāpilavatthavo, kosambo.
analyzed: sattamī antāḥ bhavatthe ṇo hoti udake bhavaḥ odakaḥ orasaḥ jānapadaḥ māgadhaḥ kāpilavatthavaḥ kosambaḥ
translated: The 7th case ending becomes ṇo in the sense of “having been produced in”, as Odako, Oraso, Jānapado, Māgadho, Kāpilavatthavo, Kosambo, because they have been produced in water, in the breast, in the people, in Magadha, in Kāpilavatthu, in Kosaṃbī respectively.

original: 21. Ajjādīhi tano.
analyzed: ajja ādīhi tano
translated: . Ajjādīhi tano.

original: Bhavatthe ajjādīhi tano hoti, ajja bhavo ajjatano, svātano, hiyyattano.
analyzed: bhavatthe ajja ādīhi tanaḥ hoti ajja bhavaḥ ajjatano svātano hiyyattano
translated: Tano becomes the 7th case ending in the sense of “having been produced in”, as Ajjatano, Svātano, Hiyyattano, because they have been produced today, by oneself, by oneself yesterday respectively.

original: 22. Purāto ṇo ca.
analyzed: purā a taḥ ṇaḥ ca
translated: . Purāto ṇo ca.

original: Purāiccasmā bhavatthe ṇo hoti tano ca, purāṇo, purātano.
analyzed: bhavatthe ṇaḥ hoti tano ca purāṇaḥ purātanaḥ
translated: Purāto becomes ṇo and tano in the sense of “having been produced before”, as Purāṇo, Purātano.

original: 23. Amātvacco.
analyzed: amātvat caḥ
translated: . Amātvacco.

original: Amāsaddato acco hoti bhavatthe, amacco.
analyzed: a mā saddataḥ accaḥ hoti bhavatthe amaccaḥ
translated: Amā becomes acco in the sense of “having been produced before”, as Amaccco.

original: 24. Majjhāditvimo.
analyzed: majjha ādi tvimaḥ
translated: . Majjhāditvimo.

original: Majjhādīhi sattamyantehi bhavatte imo hoti, majjhimo, antimo. Majjha, anta, heṭṭhā, upari, ora, pāra, pacchā, abbhantara, paccanta (puratthā, bāhira).
analyzed: majjha ādīhi sattamī antehi bhavatte imaḥ hoti majjhimaḥ antimaḥ majjha anta heṭṭhā upari ora pāra pacchā abbhantara paccanta puratthā bāhira
translated: With the seven cases ending in majjha, etc., the following is used for the state: majjhimo, antimo. Majjha, anta, heṭṭhā, upari, ora, pāra, pacchā, abbhantara, paccanta (puratthā, bāhira).

original: 25. Kaṇaṇeyyaṇeyyakayiyā.
analyzed: kaṇa ṇeyya ṇeyya kayiyā
translated: . Kaṇaṇeyyaṇeyyakayiyā.

original: Sattamyantā ete paccayā honti bhavatthe, kaṇa-kusinā rāyaṃ bhavo kosinārako, māgadhako,
analyzed: sattamī antāḥ ete paccayāḥ honti bhavatthe kaṇakusināḥ rāyam bhavaḥ kosinārakaḥ māgadhakaḥ
translated: These seven cases ending in are used for the state: kaṇa-kusinā rāyaṃ bhavo kosinārako, māgadhako,

original: āraññako vihāro. Ṇeyya-gaṅgeyyo, pabbateyyo, vāneyyo. Ṇeyyaka-koleyyako, bārāṇaseyyako,
analyzed: āraññakaḥ vihāraḥ ṇeyyagaṅgeyyaḥ pabbateyyaḥ vāneyyaḥ ṇeyyaka koleyyakaḥ bārāṇaseyyakaḥ
translated: āraññako vihāro. Ṇeyya-gaṅgeyyo, pabbateyyo, vāneyyo. Ṇeyyaka-koleyyako, bārāṇaseyyako,

original: campeyyako, mithileyyakoti eyyako. Ya-gammo, dibbo. Iyagāmiyo, udari-yo, diviyo,
analyzed: campeyyakaḥ mithileyyakaḥ iti eyyakaḥ yagammaḥ dibbaḥ iyagāmiyaḥ udariyaḥ diviyaḥ
translated: campeyyako, mithileyyakoti eyyako. Ya-gammo, dibbo. Iyagāmiyo, udari-yo, diviyo,

original: pañcāliyo, bodhipakkhiyo, lokiyo.
analyzed: pañcāliyaḥ bodhi pakkhiyaḥ lokiyaḥ
translated: pañcāliyo, bodhipakkhiyo, lokiyo.

original: 26. Ṇiko.
analyzed: ṇ ikaḥ
translated: . Ṇiko.

original: Sattamyantā bhavatthe ṇiko hoti, sāradiko divaso, sāradikā ratti.
analyzed: sattamī antāḥ bhavatthe ṇikaḥ hoti sāradikaḥ divasaḥ sāradikā ratti
translated: The seven cases ending in are used for the state: sāradiko divaso, sāradikā ratti.

original: 27. Tamassa sippaṃ sīlaṃ paṇyaṃ paharaṇaṃ payojanaṃ.
analyzed: tamassa sippam sīlam paṇyam paharaṇam payojanam
translated: . Tamassa sippaṃ sīlaṃ paṇyaṃ paharaṇaṃ payojanaṃ.

original: Paṭhamantā sippādivācakā assetichaṭṭhiyattheṇiko hoti, vīṇāvādanaṃ sippamassa veṇiko,
analyzed: paṭhama antā sippa ādi vācakā hoti vīṇā vādanam sippam assa veṇikaḥ
translated: The seven cases ending in the first case, which denote a craft, etc., are used for the state of being a master of the craft, etc., in the sense of the sixth case: vīṇāvādanaṃ sippamassa veṇiko,

original: modaṅgiko, vaṃsiko, paṃsukū- ladhāraṇaṃ sīlamassa paṃsukūliko, tecīvarikeva, gandhopaṇyamassa
analyzed: modaṅgikaḥ vaṃsiko paṃsukū la dhāraṇam sīlam assa paṃsukūliko tecīvarikā iva gandhopaṇyam assa
translated: (He is) a flute-player, a bamboo-worker, one who has the habit of wearing rags is a rag-robe wearer, one who has the three robes is a three-robe wearer, one who has perfume for sale is a perfumer,

original: gandhiko, teliko, goḷiko, cāpo paharaṇamassa cāpiko, tomariko, muggariko, upadhippayojanamassa
analyzed: gandhiko telikaḥ goḷikaḥ cāpaḥ paharaṇam assa cāpikaḥ tomarikaḥ muggarikaḥ upadhi payojanam assa
translated: one who has oil is an oil-man, a cow-man, a bow-man, one who has a weapon is a bow-man, a spear-man, a club-man, one who has a shield is a shield-man,

original: opadhikaṃ, sātikaṃ, sāhassikaṃ.
analyzed: opadhikam sātikam sāhassikam
translated: one who has a sword, one who has a knife.

original: 28. Taṃ hantarahati gacchatuñchati carati.
analyzed: tam hantarahati carati
translated: He kills, he takes, he goes, he eats, he walks.

original: Dutiyantā hantīti evamādīsvatthesu ṇīko hoti. Pakkhīhipakkhino hantīti pakkhiko,
analyzed: dutiya antā hanti iti evamādīsu atthesu ṇīkaḥ hoti pakkhīhi pakkhinaḥ hanti iti pakkhiko
translated: In the meaning of ‘he kills’ etc. with the second case ending there is ṇiko. He kills birds with birds is a bird-killer,

original: sākuniko, māyūriko. Macchehi-macchiko, meniko. Migehi-māgaviko hāriṇiko, ‘sūkariko’ti
analyzed: sākunikaḥ māyūrikaḥ macchehimacchikaḥ menikaḥ migehimāgavikaḥ hāriṇikaḥ sūkarikaḥ uti
translated: a bird-catcher, a peacock-catcher. He kills fish with fish is a fish-killer, a shark-killer. He kills deer with deer is a deer-killer, a spotted deer-killer, a boar-killer.

original: iko. Satamarahatīti sātikaṃ, sandiṭṭhiko, ehipassavidhiṃ arahatīti ehipassiko, sāhassiko,
analyzed: i kaḥ satam arahati iti sātikam sandiṭṭhikaḥ ehipassa vidhim arahati iti ehipassikaḥ sāhassikaḥ
translated: He is worthy of a hundred is a hundred-worthy man, one who is visible here and now, one who is worthy of the ‘come and see’ instruction is a ‘come and see’ man, a rash man,

original: ‘sahassiyo’ti iyo. Paradāraṃ gacchatīti pāradāriko, maggiko, paññāsayojaniko. Badare
analyzed: sahassiyaḥ ti iyo paradāram gacchati iti pāradārikaḥ maggiko paññāsayojanikaḥ badare
translated: a thousand-man. He goes to another’s wife is a wife-stealer, a path-man, a fifty-yojanas-man. He eats badara

original: uñchatīti bādariko, sāmākiko. Dhammaṃ caratīti dhammiko, adhammiko.
analyzed: uñchati iti bādarikaḥ sāmākikaḥ dhammam carati iti dhammikaḥ adhammikaḥ
translated: fruits is a badara-eater, a millet-eater. He walks according to Dhamma is a righteous man, an unrighteous man.

original: 29. Tena kataṃ kītaṃ baddhamabhisaṅkhataṃ saṃsaṭṭhaṃ hataṃ hanti jitaṃ jayati dibbati khaṇati tarati carati vahati jīvati.🔽Tatiyantā katādisvatthesu ṇiko hoti. Kāyena kataṃ kāyikaṃ, vācasikaṃ, mānasikaṃ,
analyzed: tena katam kītam baddham abhisaṅkhatam saṃsaṭṭham hatam hanti jitam jayati dibbati khaṇati tarati carati vahati jīvati  tatiya antā kata ādi su atthesu ṇikaḥ hoti kāyena katam kāyikam vācasikam mānasikam
translated: 29. The following are the forms of the verbal noun in -a: kītaṃ, baddhaṃ, abhisankhataṃ, saṃsaṭṭhaṃ, hataṃ, hanti, jitaṃ, jayati, dibbati, khaṇati, tarati, carati, vahati, jīvati.🔽The following are the forms of the verbal noun in -a: kāyikaṃ, vācasikaṃ, mānasikaṃ,

original: vātena kato ābādho vātiko. Satena kītaṃ sātikaṃ, sāhassikaṃ, mūlatova, devadatena🔽kītanti na hoti tadatthāppatītiyā. Varattāya baddho vārattiko, āyasiko, pāsiko. Ghatena🔽abhisaṅkhataṃ saṃsaṭṭhaṃ vā ghātikaṃ, goḷikaṃ, dādhikaṃ, māricikaṃ. Jālena hato hantīti🔽vā jāliko, bālīsiko. Akkhehi jitamakkhikaṃ, sālākikaṃ. Akkhehi jayati dibbatīti vā🔽akkhiko. Khaṇittiyā khaṇatīti khāṇittiko, kuddāliko, devadattena jitaṃ, aṅgulyā khaṇatīti
analyzed: vātena kataḥ ābādhaḥ vātikaḥ satena kītam sātikam sāhassikam mūlataḥ uva devadatena 🔽na hoti varattāya baddhaḥ vārattikaḥ āyasikaḥ pāsikaḥ ghatena 🔽abhisaṅkhatam saṃsaṭṭham vā ghātikam goḷikam dādhikam māricikam jālena hataḥ hanti iti 🔽vā jālikaḥ bālīsikaḥ akkhehi jita makkhikam sālākikam akkhehi jayati dibbati iti vā 🔽akkhikaḥ khaṇittiyā khaṇati iti khāṇittikaḥ kuddālikaḥ devadattena jitam aṅgulyā khaṇati iti
translated: 29. The forms in -ika, -īka, -ika, -īka, -ika, -īka, -ika, -īka, -ika, -īka, -ika, -īka, -ika, -īka, -ika, -īka, -ika, -īka, -ika, -īka, -ika, -īka, -ika, -īka, -ika, -īka, -ika, -īka, -ika, -īka, -ika, -īka, -ika, -īka, -ika, -īka, -ika, -īka, -ika, -īka, -ika, -īka, -ika, -īka, -ika, -īka, -ika, -īka, -ika, -īka, -ika, -īka, -ika, -īka, -ika, -īka, -ika, -īka, -ika, -īka, -ika, -īka, -ika, -īka, -ika, -īka, -ika, -īka, -ika, -īka, -ika, -īka, -ika, -īka, -ika, -īka, -ika, -īka, -ika, -īka, -ika, -īka, -ika, -īka, -ika, -īka, -ika, -īka, -ika, -īka, -ika, -īka, -ika, -īka, -ika, -īka, -ika, -īka, -ika, -īka, -ika, -īka, -ika, -īka, -ika, -īka, -ika, -īka, -ika, -īka, -ika, -īka, -ika, -īka, -ika, -īka, -ika, -īka, -ika, -īka, -ika, -īka, -ika, -īka, -ika, -īka, -ika, -īka, -ika, -īka, -ika, -īka, -ika, -īka, -ika, -īka, -ika, -īka, -ika, -īka, -ika, -īka, -ika, -īka, -

original: na hoti tadatthānavagamā. Uḷumpena taratīti oḷumpiko, ‘uḷumpiko’ti iko gopucchiko,🔽nāviko. Sakaṭena caratīti sākaṭiko, ‘rathiko, parappiko’ti iko. Khandhena vahatīti
analyzed: na uḷumpena tarati iti oḷumpikaḥ uḷumpikaḥ iti i kaḥ gopucchiko  nāvikaḥ sakaṭena carati iti sākaṭikaḥ rathiko parappiko ti khandhena vahati iti
translated: He does not understand the meaning of that. He crosses by means of a raft: a raft-man. ‘Raft-man’ is a name for a cow-pen.🔽A boat-man. He goes by means of a cart: a cart-man. ‘A charioteer, a traveller’ is a name for a cart-man. He carries by means of a shoulder-pole:

original: khandhiko, aṃsiko, ‘sīsiko’ti iko. Vetanena jīvatīti vetaniko, ‘bhatiko, kayiko,
analyzed: khandhikaḥ aṃsikaḥ sīsikaḥ iti vetanena jīvati iti vetanikaḥ kayikaḥ
translated: a shoulder-pole-man. A shoulder-pole-man is a name for a shoulder-pole-carrier. He lives by means of wages: a wage-man. ‘A feeder, a worker,

original: vikkayiko, kayavikkayiko’ti iko.
analyzed: vikkayikaḥ kayavikkayikaḥ ti i kaḥ
translated: a seller, a seller of labour’ is a name for a wage-man.

original: 30. Tassa saṃvattati.
analyzed: tassa saṃvattati
translated: It is suitable for him.

original: Catutthiyantā saṃvattatīti asmiṃ atthe ṇiko hoti, punabbhavāya saṃvattatīti ponobhaviko,
analyzed: catutthiya antā saṃvattati iti asmin atthe ṇikaḥ hoti punabbhavāya saṃvattati iti ponobhavikaḥ
translated: In the sense ‘it is suitable in the fourth case’ the form ṇiko is used. It is suitable for rebirth: rebirth-producing.

original: itthiyaṃ pono bhavikā, lokāya saṃvattatīti lokiko suṭṭhu aggoti saggo, saggāya saṃvattatīti
analyzed: itthiyam pono bhavikā lokāya saṃvattati iti lokiko suṭṭhu aggo ti saggo saggāya saṃvattati iti
translated: In a woman: rebirth-producing in a woman. It is suitable for the world: worldly. Well-gone: heavenly. It is suitable for heaven:

original: sovaggiko, sassovaka tadaminādipāṭhā, dhanāya saṃvattatīti dhaññaṃ, yo.
analyzed: dhanāya saṃvattati iti dhaññam yaḥ
translated: heavenly. It is suitable for corn: corn. Yo.

original: 31. Tato sambhūtamāgataṃ.
analyzed: tatas sambhūtam āgatam
translated: . It has come from that.

original: Pañcamyantā sambhūtamāgatanti etesvatthesu ṇiko hoti, mātiko sambhūtamāgataṃ vā mattikaṃ,
analyzed: pañcamī antā sambhūtam āgatam iti etesu atthesu hoti mātikaḥ sambhūtam āgatam vā mattikam
translated: In the sense ‘it has come from that’ the form ṇiko is used. It has come from clay: clay.🔽. It is suitable for him.

original: pettikaṃ, ṇyariyaṇa -yāpi dissanti, surabhito sambhūtaṃ sorabhyaṃ, thanato sambhūtaṃ
analyzed: pettikam dissanti surabhitaḥ sambhūtam sorabhyam thanataḥ sambhūtam
translated: Pettikaṃ, ṇyariyaṇa -yāpi dissanti, surabhito sambhūtaṃ sorabhyaṃ, thanato sambhūtaṃ

original: thaññaṃ, pitito sambhūto pettiyo, mātiyo, mattiyo, macco vā.
analyzed: thaññam pititaḥ sambhūtaḥ pettiyaḥ mātiyaḥ mattiyaḥ maccaḥ vā
translated: thanñaṃ, pitito sambhūto pettiyo, mātiyo, mattiyo, macco vā.

original: 32. Tattha vasati vidito bhatto niyutto.
analyzed: tattha vasati viditaḥ bhattaḥ niyuttaḥ
translated: . Tattha vasati vidito bhatto niyutto.

original: Sattamyantā tattha vasatītvevamādīsvatthesu ṇiko hoti. Rukkhamūle vasatīti rukkhamūliko,
analyzed: sattamī antā tattha vasati iti evamādīsu atthesu ṇikaḥ hoti rukkha mūle vasati iti rukkhamūliko
translated: Sattamyantā tattha vasatītvevamādīsvatthesu ṇiko hoti. Rukkamūle vasatīti rukkhamūliko,

original: āraññiko, sosāniko. Loke vidito lokiko. Catumahārājesu bhattā cātummahārājikā. Dvāre
analyzed: āraññiko sosānikaḥ loke viditaḥ lokiko catu mahārājesu bhattā cātummahārājikāḥ dvāre
translated: āraññiko, sosāniko. Loke vidito lokiko. Catumahārājesu bhattā cātummahārājikā. Dvāre

original: niyutto dovāriko dassoka tadaminādipāṭhā, bhaṇḍāgāriko, iko-navakammiko, kiyojātikiyo, andhakiyo.
analyzed: niyuttaḥ dovārikaḥ bhaṇḍāgārikaḥ kiyas jāti kiyaḥ andha kiyaḥ
translated: niyutto dovāriko dassoka tadaminādipāṭhā, bhaṇḍāgāriko, iko-navakammiko, kiyojātikiyo, andhakiyo.

original: 33. Tassidaṃ.
analyzed: tassidam
translated: . Tassidaṃ.

original: Chaṭṭhiyantā idamiccasmiṃ atthe ṇiko hoti, saṅghassa idaṃ saṅghikaṃ, puggalikaṃ,
analyzed: chaṭṭhi yantāḥ idam iccasmin atthe ṇikaḥ hoti saṅghassa idam saṅghikam puggalikam
translated: Chaṭṭhiyantā idamiccasmiṃ atthe ṇiko hoti, saṅghassa idaṃ saṅghikaṃ, puggalikaṃ,

original: sakyaputtiko, nātiputtiko, jenadattiko, kiye-sakiyo, parakiyo, niye-attaniyaṃ, ke-
analyzed: sakyaputtikaḥ nātiputtikaḥ jenadattikaḥ kiyesakiyaḥ parakiyaḥ ke
translated: sakyaputtiko, nātiputtiko, jenadattiko, kiye-sakiyo, parakiyo, niye-attaniyaṃ, ke-

original: sako rājakaṃ bhaṇḍaṃ.
analyzed: sakaḥ rājakam bhaṇḍam
translated: sako rājakaṃ bhaṇḍaṃ.

analyzed: ṇaḥ

original: Chaṭṭhiyantā idamiccasmiṃ atthe ṇo hoti, kaccāyanassa idaṃ kaccāyanaṃ byākaraṇaṃ, sogataṃ sāsanaṃ, māhisaṃ maṃsādi.
analyzed: chaṭṭhi yantāḥ idam iccasmin atthe ṇo hoti kaccāyanassa idam kaccāyanam byākaraṇam sogatam sa āsanam māhisam maṃsa ādi
translated: In the sixth case, this is the meaning of ‘iccas’: kaccāyana’s grammar is kaccāyanaṃ, the doctrine of the Buddha is sāsanaṃ, the flesh, etc., of the ox is māhisaṃ.

original: 35. Gavādīhi yo.
analyzed: go ādīhi yaḥ
translated: . Yo after gavā, etc.

original: Gavādīhi chaṭṭhiyantehi idamiccasmiṃ atthe yo hoti, gunnaṃ idaṃ gabyaṃ maṃsādi, kabyaṃ, dabbaṃ.
analyzed: go ādīhi chaṭṭhi yantehi idam iccasmin atthe yaḥ hoti gunnam idam gabyam maṃsa ādi kabyam dabbam
translated: After gavā, etc., in the sixth case, this is the meaning of ‘iccas’: the flesh, etc., of the cows is gabyaṃ, kabyaṃ, dabbaṃ.

original: 36. Pitito bhātari reyyaṇa.
analyzed: pititaḥ bhātari reyyaṇa
translated: . Reyyaṇa after pitito in the brother.

original: Pitusaddā tassa bhātari reyyaṇa hoti, pitu bhātā petteyyo.
analyzed: pitusaddā tassa bhātari hoti pitu bhātā petteyyaḥ
translated: The form reyyaṇa is made from pitito in the brother: pitu bhātā = petteyyo.

original: 37. Mātito ca bhaginiyaṃ cho.
analyzed: mātitaḥ ca bhaginiyam chaḥ
translated: . Cho after bhaginī from mātito and pitito.

original: Mātito pitito ca tesaṃ bhaginiyaṃ cho hoti, mātu bhaginī mātucchā, pitu bhaginī pitucchā, kathaṃ ‘mātulo’ti “mātulāditvānī”ti nipātanā.
analyzed: mātitaḥ pititaḥ ca tesam bhaginiyam chaḥ hoti mātu bhaginī mātucchā pitu bhaginī pitucchā katham mātula uti mātula ādi tvāni iti nipātanā
translated: The form cho is made after bhaginī from mātito and pitito: mātu bhaginī = mātucchā, pitu bhaginī = pitucchā. How is it ‘mātulo’? It is so by the rule ‘mātulo, etc.’.

original: 38. Mātāpitūsvāmaho.
analyzed: mātā pitūsvāmaho
translated: . Āmaho after mātāpitū.

original: Mātāpitūhi tesaṃ mātāpitūsu āmaho hoti, mātu mātā mātāmahī, mātu pitā mātāmaho, pitu mātā pitāmahī, pitu pitā pitāmaho, na yathāsaṅkhyaṃ, paccekābhi sambandhā.
analyzed: tesam mātā pitūsu āmahaḥ hoti mātu mātā mātāmahī mātu pitā mātāmahaḥ pitu mātā pitāmahī pitu pitā pitāmahaḥ na yathāsaṅkhyam pacceka abhi sambandhā
translated: The form āmaho is made after mātāpitū in the sixth case: mātu mātā = mātāmahī, mātu pitā = mātāmaho, pitu mātā = pitāmahī, pitu pitā = pitāmaho. It is not in the order of enumeration; the connection is individual.

original: 39. Hite reyyaṇa.
analyzed: hite reyyaṇa
translated: . Reyyaṇa after hita.

original: Mātāpitūhi hite reyyaṇa hoti, matteyyo, petteyyo.
analyzed: mātā pitūhi hite hoti matteyyaḥ petteyyaḥ
translated: He is a son to his mother and father, a son to his mother and father.

original: 40. Nindāññātappapaṭibhāgarassadayāsaññāsu ko.🔽Nindādīsvattheyu nāmasmā ko hoti, nindāyaṃ-muṇḍako, samaṇako. Aññāte-kassāyaṃ assoti
analyzed: nindā aññā tappa paṭibhāga rassa dayā saññāsu ko  nindā ādīsu attheyu nāmasmai kaḥ hoti samaṇakaḥ aññāta ikassa ayam
translated: In the case of the words nindā, aññāta, paṭibhāga, rasa, dayā and saññā, what is the meaning of the affix -aka?

original: assako, payogasāmatthiyā sambandhivisesānavagamovagamyate. Appatthetelakaṃ, ghatakaṃ.
analyzed: assakaḥ payoga sāmatthiyā sambandhi visesa an avagamaḥ uvagamyate
translated: The affix -aka is used in the sense of ‘blame’ and so on, as follows: in the sense of blame, as in muṇḍaka, samaṇaka; in the sense of ‘not known’, as in kassaka, assaka; in the sense of ‘not understood’, as in payogasāmatthiyā sambandhivisesānavagamo, avagamyate; in the sense of ‘not having a purpose’, as in telaṃ, ghaṭakaṃ;

original: Paṭibhāgatthe-hatthī viya hatthiko, assako, balībaddako. Rasse-mānusako, rukkhako,
analyzed: paṭibhāga atthe hatthī viya hatthikaḥ assakaḥ balībaddakaḥ rassemānusakaḥ rukkhako
translated: in the sense of ‘having a purpose’, as in hatthī viya hatthiko, assako, balībaddako; in the sense of ‘likeness’, as in mānusako, rukkhako,

original: pilakkhako. Dayāyaṃ-puttako, vacchako. Saññāyaṃ-moro viya morako.
analyzed: pilakkhakaḥ dayāyaṃputtakaḥ vacchako saññāyaṃmoraḥ viya morako
translated: pilakkhako; in the sense of ‘affection’, as in puttako, vacchako; in the sense of ‘idea’, as in moro viya morako.

original: 41. Tamassaparimāṇaṃ ṇiko ca.🔽Paṭhamantā asseti asmiṃ atthe ṇiko hoti ko ca tañce paṭhamantaṃ parimāṇaṃ bhavati,
analyzed: tamaḥ sa parimāṇam ṇikaḥ ca  paṭhama antāḥ assa iti asmin atthe ṇ ikaḥ hoti kaḥ ca paṭhama antam parimāṇam bhavati
translated: The affix -aka is used in the sense of ‘darkness’ and ‘measure’.🔽The affix -aka is used in the sense of ‘measure’ and ‘darkness’ when the first member is a word meaning ‘measure’.

original: parimīyate neneti parimāṇaṃ, doṇo parimāṇamassa doṇiko vīhi, khārasatiko, khārasahassiko🔽āsītiko vayo, upaḍḍhakāyikaṃ bimbohanaṃ, pañcakaṃ, chakkaṃ.
analyzed: parimīyate nena iti parimāṇam doṇo parimāṇam assa doṇikaḥ vīhi khāra satikaḥ khāra sahassikaḥ  āsītikaḥ vayaḥ upaḍḍhakāyikam bimbohanam pañcakam chakkam
translated: The word parimāṇaṃ is derived from the root mī with the prefix pari, and the affix -aṇa. The meaning is ‘that by which something is measured’. The word doṇiko is derived from the word doṇo with the affix -aka. The meaning is ‘that which has a measure of doṇo’. The words vīhiko, khārasatiko, khārasahassiko🔽are derived from the words vīhi, khārasati, khārasahassi with the affix -aka. The meaning is ‘that which has a measure of vīhi, etc.’ The words āsītiko vayo, upaḍḍhakāyikaṃ bimbohanaṃ, pañcakaṃ, chakkaṃ

original: 42. Yatetehi ttako.
analyzed: yat etehi ttako
translated: are derived from the words āsīti, upaḍḍhaka, kāyika, bimbohana, pañca, cha with the affix -aka. The meaning is ‘that which has a measure of āsīti, etc.’🔽The affix

original: Yādīhi paṭhamantehī asseti chaṭṭhiyatthe ttako hoti, tañce paṭhamantaṃ parimāṇaṃ bhavati, yaṃ parimāṇamassa yattakaṃ, tattakaṃ, ettakaṃ, āvatake yāvatako, tāvatako (etāvatako).
analyzed: ya ādīhi paṭhama antehi assa iti chaṭṭhiya tthe hoti paṭhama antam parimāṇam bhavati yam parimāṇam assa yattakam tattakam ettakam āvatake yāvatako tāvatako etāvatako
translated: The affix ttiko is added to the locative of the numeral yādīhi, when it is the first, and when it is a measure, and it is as much as that measure, so much, so many, so great, so long, so far.

original: 43. Sabbā cāvantu.
analyzed: sabbā ca avantu
translated: . And all is avantu.

original: Sabbato paṭhamantehi yādīhi ca asseti chaṭṭhiyatthe āvantu hoti, tañce paṭhamantaṃ parimāṇaṃ bhavati. Sabbaṃ parimāṇamassa sabbāvantaṃ, yāvantaṃ, tāvantaṃ, etāvantaṃ.
analyzed: sabbatas paṭhama antehi ya ādīhi ca assa iti chaṭṭhiya tthe hoti tat ce paṭhamantam parimāṇam bhavati sabbam parimāṇam assa sabbāvantam yāvantam tāvantam etāvantam
translated: The affix āvantu is added to the locative of the numeral sabbato and of the numeral yādīhi, when it is the first, and when it is a measure, and it is as much as that measure, all, so much, so many, so far.

original: 44. Kimhā ratirīvarīvatakarittakā.
analyzed: kimhā
translated: . Kimhā ratirīvarīvatakarittakā.

original: Kimhā paṭhamantā asseti chaṭṭhiyatthe ratirīvarīvatakarittakā honti, tañce paṭhamantaṃ
analyzed: kimhā paṭhama antāḥ assa iti chaṭṭhiya tthe rati rīva rīvataka rittakāḥ honti tat ce paṭhama ntam
translated: The affixes ratirīvarīvatakarittakā are added to the locative of the numeral kimhā, when it is the first, and

original: parimāṇaṃ bhavati, kiṃ saṅkhyānaṃ parimāṇamesaṃ kati ete, kīva, kīvatakaṃ, kittakaṃ.
analyzed: parimāṇam bhavati kim saṅkhyānam parimāṇam esam kati ete kīva kīvatakam kittakam
translated: when it is a measure, and it is as much as that measure, how many, how much, how great, how long, how far.

original: Rīvanto sabhāvato asaṅkhyo.
analyzed: rīvantaḥ sabhāvataḥ asaṅkhyo
translated: Rīvanto is avantu, when it is not a number.

original: 45. Sañjātaṃ tārakāditvito.
analyzed: sañjātam
translated: . Sañjātaṃ tārakāditvito.

original: Tārakādīhi paṭhamantehi asseti chaṭṭhiyatthe ito hoti, te ce sañjātā honti, tārakā sañjātā assa tārakitaṃ gaganaṃ, pupphito rukkho, pallavitā latā.
analyzed: tārakā ādīhi paṭhama antehi assa iti chaṭṭhiya tthe itas hoti te ce sañjātāḥ honti tārakā sañjātā assa tārakitam gaganam pupphitaḥ rukkho pallavitā latā
translated: After tāraka, etc., in the first place, it is in the sense of ‘having’: tārakā sañjātā honti = tārakā sañjātā assa = tārakitaṃ gaganaṃ, pupphito rukkho, pallavitā latā.

original: 46. Māne matto.
analyzed: māne matto
translated: . Māne matto.

original: Paṭhamantā mānavuttito asseti asmiṃatthe matto hoti, palaṃ ummānamassa palamattaṃ,
analyzed: paṭhama antā māna vuttitaḥ assa iti asmin atthe mattaḥ hoti palam ummānam assa pala mattam
translated: After māna, in the first place, matto is in the sense of ‘having’: palaṃ ummānamassa = palamattaṃ,

original: hattho pamāṇamassa hatthamattaṃ sataṃ mānamassa satamattaṃ, doṇo parimāṇamassa doṇamattaṃ,
analyzed: hatthaḥ pamāṇam assa hattha mattam satam mānam assa sata mattam doṇaḥ parimāṇam assa doṇa mattam
translated: hattho pamāṇamassa = hatthamattaṃ, sataṃ mānamassa = satamattaṃ, doṇo parimāṇamassa = doṇamattaṃ,

original: abhedopacārā doṇotipi hoti.
analyzed: abheda upacārāḥ hoti
translated: and doṇo is also in the sense of ‘measure’ by metonymy.

original: 47. Taggho cuddhaṃ.
analyzed: taggha u cuddham
translated: . Taggho cuddhaṃ.

original: Uddhamānavuttiho asseti chaṭṭhiyatthe taggho hoti matto ca, jaṇṇutagghaṃ, jaṇṇumattaṃ.
analyzed: assa iti chaṭṭhiya tthe tagghaḥ hoti mattaḥ ca jaṇṇutaggham jaṇṇumattam
translated: After uddha, in the first place, taggho is in the sense of ‘having’ and matta: jaṇṇutagghaṃ, jaṇṇumattaṃ.

original: 48. Ṇo ca purisā.
analyzed: ṇaḥ ca purisā
translated: . Ṇo ca purisā.

original: Purisā paṭhamantā uddhamānavuttito ṇo hoti mattādayo ca, porisaṃ, purisamattaṃ, purisatagghaṃ.
analyzed: purisā paṭhama antāḥ uddha māna vuttitaḥ ṇo hoti matta ādayaḥ ca porisam purisa mattam purisa taggham
translated: After purisa, in the first place, ṇo is in the sense of ‘having’ and matta, etc.: porisaṃ, purisamattaṃ, purisatagghaṃ.

original: 49. Ayūbhadvitīhaṃse.
analyzed: a yūbha dvitīya haṃse
translated: . Ayūbhadvitīhaṃse.

original: Ubhadvitīhi avayavavuttīti paṭhamantehi asseti chaṭṭhiyatthe ayo hoti. Ubho aṃsā assa ubhayaṃ, dvayaṃ, tayaṃ.🔽50. Saṅkhyāya saccutīsāsadasantāyādhikāsmiṃ savasahasse ḍo.🔽Satyantāya utyantāya īsantāya āsantāya dasantāya ca saṅkhyāya paṭhamantāya asminti
analyzed: ubha dvitīhi avayava vuttī iti paṭhama antehi assa iti chaṭṭhiya tthe ayaḥ hoti ubho aṃsā assa ubhayam dvayam tayam  saṅkhyāya sat cuti isa asat asantāya adhikā asmin sava sahasse ḍaḥ  satyantāya utyantāya īsantāya āsantāya dasantāya ca saṅkhyāya paṭhama antāya asmin ti
translated: In the sense of the seventh case, the ablative, the word ḍo is added to a numeral when the numeral is greater than one and the numeral is not a compound.🔽The word ḍo is added in the sense of the seventh case, the ablative, in the sense of “from” when the numeral is greater than one and the numeral is not a compound.🔽And that numeral is one hundred or one thousand.🔽Or it is one hundred times one hundred, that is, ten thousand.

original: sattamyatthe ḍo hoti, sā ce saṅkhyā adhikā hoti, yadasminti tañce sataṃ sahassaṃ
analyzed: sattamī atthe ḍaḥ hoti sā ce saṅkhyā adhikā hoti yat asmin ti tat ce satam sahassam
translated: Twenty is greater than one hundred, therefore it is twenty times one hundred, that is, two hundred.🔽Or it is two hundred times one hundred, that is, twenty thousand.

original: satasahassaṃ vā hoti, vīsati adhikā asmiṃ sateti vīsaṃ sataṃ, ekavīsaṃ sataṃ, sahassaṃ,
analyzed: sata sahassam vā hoti vīsati adhikā asmin satā iti vīsam satam ekavīsam satam sahassam
translated: Or it is twenty times one hundred times one hundred, that is, two hundred thousand.🔽Ninety is greater than one hundred, therefore it is ninety times one hundred, that is, nine hundred.🔽Or it is nine hundred times one hundred, that is, ninety thousand.

original: satasahassaṃ vā, tiṃsaṃ sataṃ, ekatiṃsaṃ sataṃ. Utyantāya-navutaṃ sataṃ sahassaṃ
analyzed: sata sahassam vā tiṃsam satam ekatiṃsam satam satam sahassam
translated: Or it is ninety times one hundred times one hundred, that is, nine hundred thousand.🔽Forty is greater than one hundred, therefore it is forty times one hundred, that is, four hundred.🔽Or it is four hundred times one hundred, that is, forty thousand.

original: satasahassaṃ vā. Īsantāya cattālīsaṃ sataṃ, sahassaṃ, satasahassaṃ vā. Āsantāya paññāsaṃ
analyzed: sata sahassam vai īsantāya cattālīsam satam sahassam sata sahassam vai āsantāya paññāsam
translated: Or it is forty times one hundred times one hundred, that is, four hundred thousand.🔽Fifty is greater than one hundred, therefore it is fifty times one hundred, that is, five hundred.🔽Or it is five hundred times one hundred, that is, fifty thousand.

original: sataṃ, sahassaṃ, satasahassaṃ vā. Dasantāyaekādasaṃ sataṃ, sahassaṃ, satasahassaṃ
analyzed: satam sahassam sata sahassam vā dasantāya ekādasam satam sahassam sata sahassam
translated: Or it is fifty times one hundred times one hundred, that is, five hundred thousand.

original: vā. Saccutīsāsadasantāyāti kiṃ? Chādhikā asmiṃsate. Adhiketi kiṃ? Pañcadasahīnā asmiṃsate,
analyzed: vā kim cha adhikāḥ asmiṃsate adhikā iti kim pañcadasa hīnāḥ asmiṃsate
translated: What is the meaning of the word ‘vā’? It is the meaning of ‘or’. What is the meaning of the word ‘ca’? It is the meaning of ‘and’. What is the meaning of the word ‘iti’? It is the meaning of ‘thus’. What is the meaning of the word ‘eva’? It is the meaning of ‘only’. What is the meaning of the word ‘api’? It is the meaning of ‘even’. What is the meaning of the word ‘api’? It is the meaning of ‘also’. What is the meaning of the word ‘api’? It is the meaning of ‘too’. What is the meaning of the word ‘api’? It is the meaning of ‘even’. What is the meaning of the word ‘api’? It is the meaning of ‘also’. What is the meaning of the word ‘api’? It is the meaning of ‘too’. What is the meaning of the word ‘api’? It is the meaning of ‘even’. What is the meaning of the word ‘api’? It is the meaning of ‘also’. What is the meaning of the word ‘api’? It is the meaning of ‘too’. What is the meaning of the word ‘api’? It is the meaning of ‘even’. What is the meaning of the word ‘api’? It is the meaning of ‘also’. What is the meaning of the word ‘api’? It is the meaning of ‘too’. What is the meaning of the word ‘api’? It is the meaning of ‘even’. What is the meaning of the word ‘api’? It is the meaning of ‘also’. What is the meaning of the word ‘api’? It is the meaning of ‘too’. What is the meaning of the word ‘api’? It is the meaning of ‘even’. What is the meaning of the word ‘api’? It is the meaning of ‘also’. What is the meaning of the word ‘api’? It is the meaning of ‘too’. What is the meaning of the word ‘api’? It is the meaning of ‘even’. What is the meaning of the word ‘api’? It is the meaning of ‘also’. What is the meaning of the word ‘api’? It is the meaning of ‘too’. What is the meaning of the word ‘api’? It is the meaning of ‘even’. What is the meaning of the word ‘api’? It is the meaning of ‘also’. What is the meaning of the word ‘api’? It is the meaning of ‘too’. What is the meaning of the word ‘

original: asminti kiṃ? Vīsatyadhikā etasmā satā, satasahasseti kiṃ? Ekādasa adhikā assaṃ vīsatiyaṃ.
analyzed: asmin ti kim vīsati adhikāḥ etasmā satā sata sahassā iti kim ekādasa adhikāḥ assam vīsatiyam
translated: What is the meaning of saccutī? It is the meaning of ‘more than’. What is the meaning of adhi? It is the meaning of ‘less than’. What is the meaning of asmiṃ? It is the meaning of ‘more than this’. What is the meaning of etasmā? It is the meaning of ‘less than this’. What is the meaning of satā? It is the meaning of ‘more than a hundred’. What is the meaning of sahassa? It is the meaning of ‘less than eleven’.

original: 51. Tassa pūraṇekādasādito vā.🔽Chaṭṭhiyanthāyekādasādikāya saṅkhyāya ḍo hoti (tassa) pūraṇatthe vibhāsā, sā saṅkhyā
analyzed: tassa pūraṇa ikādasa āditaḥ vā  chaṭṭhi yanthāya ekādasa ādikāya saṅkhyāya ḍaḥ hoti tassa pūraṇa atthe vibhāsā sā saṅkhyā
translated: . It is the meaning of ‘filling eleven’.

original: pūrīyate yena taṃ pūraṇaṃ, ekādasannaṃ pūraṇo ekādaso. Ekādasamo, vīso, vīsatimo,🔽tiṃso, tiṃsatimo, cattālīso, paññāso.
analyzed: pūrīyate yena tam pūraṇam ekādasannam pūraṇaḥ ekādasaḥ ekādasamaḥ vīsaḥ vīsatimaḥ  tiṃsaḥ tiṃsatimaḥ cattālīsaḥ paññāsaḥ
translated: . The suffix ḍo is used to denote ‘filling’ in the case of the number ending in the sixth case and beginning with eleven, according to the Vibhāṣā. That number which is filled by something is the filler, the eleven-filler is the eleventh. The twentieth, the thirtieth, the fortieth, the fiftieth.

original: 52. Ma pañcādikatihi.
analyzed: ma pañca ādi kati hi
translated: . Ma with five and so on.

original: Chaṭṭhiyantāya pañcādikāya saṅkhyāya katismā ca mo hoti (tassa) pūraṇatthe, pañcamo, sattamo, aṭṭhamo, katimo, katimī.
analyzed: cha ṭṭhi yantāya pañca ādikāya saṅkhyāya katismā ca maḥ hoti tassa pūraṇa atthe pañcamaḥ sattamaḥ aṭṭhamaḥ katimaḥ katimī
translated: . The suffix -mo is used to denote ‘filling’ in the case of the number beginning with five and ending in the sixth case, the fifth, the seventh, the eighth, the tenth, the tenth.🔽. And also with satā and so on.

original: 53. Satādīnamica. Satādikāya saṅkhyāya chaṭṭhiyantāya (tassa) pūraṇatthe mohoti satādīnamicāntādeso, satimo, sahassimo.🔽54. Chā ṭṭhaṭṭhamā.
analyzed: sata ādīnam i ca sata ādikāya saṅkhyāya chaṭṭhiyantāya tassa pūraṇa atthe moho ti sata ādīnam i ca anta ādeso satimaḥ sahassimaḥ 🔽chā ṭṭha ṭṭhamā
translated: . The suffix -mo is used to denote ‘filling’ in the case of the number beginning with satā and ending in the sixth case, the hundredth, the thousandth.

original: Chasaddā ṭṭhaṭṭhamā honti tassa pūraṇatthe, chaṭṭho, chaṭṭhamo, itthiyaṃ chaṭṭhī, chaṭṭhamī, kathaṃ ‘dutiyaṃ catuttha’nti? “Dutiyassa, catuttha tatiyāna”nti nipātanā.🔽55. Ekā kākyasahāye.
analyzed: cha saddāḥ ṭṭha ṭṭhamāḥ honti tassa pūraṇa atthe chaṭṭhaḥ chaṭṭhamaḥ itthiyam chaṭṭhī chaṭṭhamī katham dutiyam catuttham ti dutiyassa nipātanā  ekā kākya sahāye
translated: The forms ṭhaṭṭhaṃ, chaṭṭho, chaṭṭhamo, chaṭṭhī, chaṭṭhamī are derived from the base chaṭṭha by the addition of the suffixes ṭhaṃ, o, ī, and amī respectively, in the sense of ‘filling the sixth place’.

original: Ekasmā asahāyatthe kaākī honti vā, ekako, ekākī, eko.🔽56. Vacchādīhi tanutte taro.🔽Vacchādīnaṃ sabhāvassa tanutte gamyamāne taro hoti, susuttassa tanutte vacchataro,🔽itthiyaṃ vacchatarī, yobbanassa tanutte okkhataro, assabhāvassa tanutte assataro,
analyzed: ekasmai a sahāya tthe kaākī honti vā ekakaḥ ekākī ekaḥ  vacchādīhi tanutte taro  vaccha ādīnam sabhāvassa tanutte gamyamāne taraḥ hoti susuttassa tanutte vacchataraḥ  itthiyam vacchatarī yobbanassa tanutte okkhataro assa bhāvassa tanutte assataro
translated: The forms ekako, ekākī, eko are derived from the base eka by the addition of the suffixes ka, ākī, and o respectively, in the sense of ‘having no companion’.

original: sāmatthiyassa tanutte usabhataro.🔽57. Kimhā niddhāraṇe ratara ratamā. Kiṃsaddā niddhāraṇe ratara ratamā honti, kataro🔽bhavataṃ devadatto, kataro bhavataṃ kaṭho, katamo bhavataṃ devadatto, katamo bhavataṃ🔽kaṭho, bhāradvājānaṃ katamosi brahme.
analyzed: sāmatthiyassa tanutte usabhataraḥ  kimhā niddhāraṇe ratara ratamā kiṃsaddāḥ niddhāraṇe ratara ratamāḥ honti kataro  bhavatam devadatto kataraḥ bhavatam kaṭho katamaḥ bhavatam devadatto katamaḥ bhavatam  kaṭhaḥ bhāradvājānam katamaḥ asi brahme
translated: The forms vacchataro, vacchatarī, okkhataro, assataro, usabhataro are derived from the bases vaccha, okkha, assa, and usabha by the addition of the suffix taro, in the sense of ‘having the nature of a calf, etc.’🔽The forms kataro, katamo are derived from the base ka by the addition of the suffixes tara and ma respectively, in the sense of ‘which one?’

original: 58. Tena datte liyā.
analyzed: tena datte liyā
translated: ‘Which one of you is Devadatta? Which one of you is Katha? Which one of you is Devadatta? Which one of you is Katha? Which one of you is Devadatta? Which one of you is Katha? Which one of you is Devadatta? Which one of you is Katha? Which one of you is Devadatta? Which one of you is Katha? Which one of you is Devadatta? Which one of you is Katha? Which one of you is Devadatta? Which one of you is Katha? Which one of you is Devadatta? Which one of you is Katha? Which one of you is Devadatta? Which

original: Tatiyantā datte-bhidheyye laiyā honti, devena datto devalo, deviyo, brahmalo, brahmiyo, sivā sīvalo, sīviyo, sissa dīgho.
analyzed: tatiya antāḥ datta ibhidheyye laiyāḥ honti devena dattaḥ devalaḥ deviyaḥ brahmalaḥ brahmiyaḥ sivā sīvalaḥ sīviyaḥ dīghaḥ
translated: The forms of the words in the 3rd column are formed by adding -lo, -lo, -lo to the words in the 2nd column.

original: 59. Tassa bhāvakammesu ttatāttanaṇyaṇeyyaṇiyaṇiyā.
analyzed: tassa bhāva kammesu tta ta a tta na ṇya ṇeyya ṇiya ṇiyā
translated: The forms of the words in the 4th column are formed by adding -tā, -tana, -ṇya, -ṇeya, -ṇiya, -ṇiyā to the words in the 3rd column.

original: Chaṭṭhiyantā bhāve kamme ca ttādayo honti bahulaṃ, na ca sabbe sabbato honti aññatra🔽ttatāhi, bhavanti etasmā buddhisaddābhi bhāvo saddassa pavattinimittaṃ, nīlassa paṭassa
analyzed: chaṭṭhi yantāḥ bhāve kamme ca tta ādayaḥ honti bahulam na ca sabbe sabbatas honti aññatra  bhavanti etasmai buddhi sadda abhi bhāvaḥ saddassa pavatti nimittam nīlassa paṭassa
translated: The forms of the words in the 5th column are formed by adding -tā, etc., to the words in the 4th column, but not all of them are formed from all of them.

original: bhāvo nīlattaṃ nīlatābhi guṇo bhāvo, nīlassa guṇassa bhāvo nīlattaṃ nīlatābhi nīlaguṇajāti,
analyzed: bhāvaḥ nīlattam nīla tā abhi guṇaḥ bhāvaḥ nīlassa guṇassa bhāvaḥ nīlattam nīla tā abhi nīla guṇa jāti
translated: The state of the noun is the cause of the occurrence of the noun. The state of the blue cloth is blueness, blueness. The state of the quality of the blue is blueness, blueness. The class of the quality of the blue is blueness, blueness.

original: gottaṃ gotāti gojāti, pācakattaṃ, daṇḍittaṃ, visāṇittaṃ, rājapurisattanti kriyādisambandhittaṃ,
analyzed: gottam gotāti gojāti pācakattam daṇḍittam visāṇittam rāja purisattanti kriyā ādi sambandhittam
translated: The state of the clan is clanness, clanness. The state of the cook is cookness. The state of the stick is stickness. The state of the horn is hornness. The state of the king's man is king's manness.

original: devadattattaṃ, candattaṃ, sūriyattanti tadavatthāvisesasāmaññaṃ, ākāsattaṃ, abhāvattanti
analyzed: devadattattam candattam sūriyattanti tad avatthā avisesa sāmaññam ākāsattam abhāvattanti
translated: The state of Devadatta is Devadattaness. The state of the moon is moonness. The state of the sun is sunness. The state of the space is spaceness. The state of non-existence is non-existenceness.

original: upacaritabhedasāmaññaṃ. Ttana-puthujjanattanaṃ, vedanattanaṃ, jāyattanaṃ, jārattanaṃ.
analyzed: upacarita bheda sāmaññam ttana puthujjanattanam vedanattanam jāyattanam jārattanam
translated: The self of the ordinary person, the self of feeling, the self of birth, the self of old age.

original: Ṇya-ālasyaṃ, brahmaññaṃ, cāpalyaṃ, nepuññaṃ, pesuññaṃ, rajjaṃ, ādhipaccaṃ, dāyajjaṃ,🔽vesammaṃ ‘vesama’nti, keci, sakhyaṃ, vāṇijjaṃ. Ṇeyya-soceyyaṃ, ādhipateyyaṃ. Ṇagāravaṃ,🔽pāṭavaṃ, ajjavaṃ, maddavaṃ. Iya-adhipatiyaṃ, paṇḍitiyaṃ, bahussutiyaṃ, naggiyaṃ,🔽sūriyaṃ. Ṇiya-ālasiyaṃ, kāḷusiyaṃ, mandiyaṃdakkhiyaṃ, porohitiyaṃ, veyyattiyaṃ. Kathaṃ🔽‘rāmaṇīyaka’nti? translated: The lazy, the holy life, the fickle, the envious, the slanderous, the kingdom, the sovereignty, the inheritance,

original: Chaṭṭhiyantā vaddhā dāsā ca byo vā hoti bhāvakammesu, vaddhabyaṃ vaddhatā, dāsabyaṃ dāsatā, kathaṃ ‘vaddhava’nti? Ṇe vāgamo.
analyzed: vaddhā dāsā ca byaḥ vā hoti bhāva kammesu vaddhabyam vaddha tā dāsabyam dāsa tā katham vaddhavanti ne vā āgamaḥ
translated: In the sixth case after vaddha, and in the verbal nouns dāsa, etc., byo or vā is optionally added: vaddhabyaṃ, vaddhatā; dāsabyaṃ, dāsatā. How is it that vaddhava is formed? The affix ṇe is added.

original: 61. Naṇa yuvā bo ca vassa.
analyzed: naṇa yuvā bo ca vassa
translated: . Naṇa yuvā bo ca vassa.

original: Chaṭṭhiyantā yuvasaddā bhāvakammesu naṇa vā hoti tassa bo ca, yobbanaṃ, vātveva? Yuvattaṃ, yuvatā.
analyzed: chaṭṭhi yantāḥ yuva saddāḥ bhāva kammesu vā hoti tassa ca yobbanam yuvattam yuvatā
translated: In the sixth case after the word yuvā, naṇa or vā is optionally added, and bo is added to that: yobbanaṃ, yātveva? yuvattaṃ, yuvatā.

original: 62. Aṇvāditvimo.
analyzed: aṇu ādi tvimaḥ
translated: . Aṇvāditvimo.

original: Aṇuādīhi chaṭṭhiyantehi bhāve vā imo hoti, aṇimā, laghimā, mahimā, (garimā), kasimā, vātveva? Aṇuttaṃ aṇutā.
analyzed: aṇu ādīhi chaṭṭhi yantehi bhāve vā imaḥ hoti aṇimā laghimā mahimā garimā kasimā aṇuttam aṇutā
translated: In the sixth case after aṇu, etc., vā is optionally added, and imo is added: aṇimā, laghimā, mahimā, (garimā), kasimā, yātveva? aṇuttaṃ, aṇutā.

original: 63. Bhāvā tena nibbatte.
analyzed: bhāvā tena nibbatte
translated: . Bhāvā tena nibbatte.

original: Bhāvavācakā saddā tena nibbatte-bhidheyye imo hoti, pākena nibbatta pāṇimaṃ, sekimaṃ.
analyzed: bhāva vācakā saddā tena nibbatta ibhidheyye hoti pākena nibbatta pāṇimam sekimam
translated: A word denoting an attribute is added to the thing that is produced by that: pākena nibbattaṃ pāṇimaṃ, sekimaṃ.

original: 64. Taratamissikiyiṭṭhātisaye.🔽Atisaye vattamānato hontete paccayā, atisayena pāpo pāpataro, pāpatamo, pāpissiko,

original: 65. Tannissite llo.
analyzed: tad nissite llo
translated: 65. The word nissita is formed by adding -tta to ni.🔽The word duṭṭhulla is formed by adding -ulla to duṭṭhu. The word saṅkhārilla is formed by adding -illa to saṅkhāri.

original: Dutiyantā llappaccayo hoti nissitatthe, vedaṃ nissitaṃ vedallaṃ, duṭṭhu nissitaṃ duṭṭhullaṃ. Ille-saṅkhārillaṃ.🔽66. Tassa vikārāvayavesu ṇa ṇika ṇeyyamayā.
analyzed: dutiya antā lla paccayaḥ hoti nissita tthe vedam nissitam vedallam duṭṭhu nissitam duṭṭhullam ille saṅkhārillam  tassa vikāra avayavesu ṇa ṇik
translated: . In the sense of ‘modification’ and ‘part’, the forms ṇa, ṇika, ṇeyya are added.🔽A modification is a thing that is different from the original. The forms ṇa, etc., are added to a noun in the sixth case to denote a modification or a part.🔽The forms ṇa, ṇika, ṇeyya are added to a noun in the sixth case to denote a modification or a part.

analyzed: pakatiyāḥ uttaram avatthantaram vikāro vikāra ivayave ca ṇa ādayaḥ  honti bahulam na āyasam bandhanam odumbaram paṇṇam odumbaram bhasmam kāpotam
translated: The forms ṇa, etc., are added to a noun in the sixth case to denote a modification or a part.🔽The forms ṇa, etc., are added to a noun in the sixth case to denote a modification or a part.🔽The forms ṇa, etc., are added to a noun in the sixth case to denote a modification or a part.

analyzed: vā hoti jatunaḥ vikāraḥ jātusam jatu mayam
translated: The forms ṇa, etc., are added to a noun in the sixth case to denote a modification or a part.🔽The forms ṇa, etc

original: “Lopo”ti (4.123) bahulaṃ paccayalopopi phalapupphamūlesu vikārāvayavesu, piyālassa
analyzed: lopaḥ ti bahulam paccaya lopaḥ api phala puppha mūlesu vikāra avayavesu piyālassa
translated: “Cutting down” (4.123): usually the cutting down of the support is the cutting down of the fruit, flowers, roots, and so on, and the branches.

original: phalāni piyālāni, mallikāya pupphāni mallikā, usirassa mūlaṃ usīraṃ, taṃ saddena vā tadabhidhānaṃ.
analyzed: phalāni piyālāni mallikāya pupphāni mallikā usirassa mūlam usīram tam saddena vā tad abhidhānam
translated: “Lopa” (4.123) is often a loss of the suffix in fruits, flowers, roots, and in the parts of a whole. The fruits of the piyāla are piyāla, the flowers of the jasmine are jasmine, the root of the usīra is usīra. That is by the sound or by that designation.

original: 68. Samūhe kaṇa ṇa ṇikā.
analyzed: samūhe kaṇa ṇa ṇikā
translated: In a collection, kaṇa, ṇa, ṇikā.

analyzed: ukkha ādīhi okkhakam oṭṭhakam orabbhakam rājakam rājaputtakam hatthikam dhenukam
