original: Ṇa-kākaṃ, bhikkhaṃ. Acittā ṇika-āpūpikaṃ, saṃkulikaṃ.
analyzed: ṇakākam bhikkham acittāḥ saṃkulikam
translated: ṇa-kāka, bhikkha. Acittā ṇika-āpūpika, saṃkulika.

original: 69. Janādīhi tā.
analyzed: jana adīhi tā
translated: . Tā with janā, etc.

original: Janādīhi chaṭṭhiyantehi samūhe tā hoti. Janatā, gajatā, bandhutā, gāmatā, sahāyatā,
analyzed: jana ādīhi samūhe tā hoti jana tā gaja tā bandhu tā gāma tā sahāya tā
translated: Tā is used in the sixth case in a collection with janā, etc. Janatā, gajatā, bandhutā, gāmatā, sahāyatā,

original: nāgaratā. Tāntā sabhāvato itthiliṅgā, ‘madanīya’nti karaṇe-dhikaraṇe vā anīyena siddhaṃ.
analyzed: itthiliṅgāḥ siddham
translated: nāgaratā. Tā is feminine in gender by nature. ‘Madanīya’ is formed by the suffix -iya in the instrumental or locative case.

original: ‘Dhūmāyitatta’nti ktāntā nāmadhātuto ktena siddhaṃ.
analyzed: dhūmāyi tattanti kta antāḥ nāma dhātutaḥ ktena siddham
translated: ‘Dhūmāyitatta’ is formed by the suffix -tta in the name base, with the suffix -ka.🔽. Iyo in the sense of ‘beneficial’.

original: 70. Iyo hite.
analyzed: iyaḥ hite
translated: 70. Mother, for my welfare.

original: Chaṭṭhiyantā hite iyo hoti. Upādāniyaṃ, aññatrāpi samānodare sayito sodariyo.🔽71. Cakkhvādito sso.
analyzed: chaṭṭhi yantā hite iyaḥ hoti upādāniyam aññatra api samāna udare sayitaḥ sodariyaḥ  cakkhu āditaḥ ssaḥ
translated: The sixth-case form of hita has the form iyo. Upādāniyaṃ, aññatrāpi samānodare sayito sodariyo.🔽The sixth-case form of cakkhādito has the form sso.

original: Chaṭṭhiyantehi cakkhuādīhi hite sso hoti, cakkhussaṃ, āyussaṃ.🔽72. Ṇyo tattha sādhu.
analyzed: chaṭṭhi yantehi cakkhu ādīhi hite ssaḥ hoti cakkhussam āyussam  ṇyo tattha sādhu
translated: The sixth-case form of cakkhu, etc., has the form sso when it means “good for the eye, etc.”: cakkhussaṃ, āyussaṃ.🔽The seventh-case form of tattha sādhū has the form ṇyo. Sabbho, pārisajjo. Sādhū means “skillful,” “suitable,” “good.” Elsewhere too: rathaṃ vahatīti racchā.

original: Sattamyantā tattha sādhūti asmiṃ atthe ṇyo hoti. Sabbho, pārisajjo. Sādhūti kusalo yoggo hito vā. Aññatrāpi rathaṃ vahatīti racchā.🔽73. Kammā niya ññā.
analyzed: sattamī antā tattha sādhu iti asmin atthe ṇyaḥ hoti sabbho pārisajjaḥ sādhu iti kusalaḥ yoggaḥ hitaḥ vai aññatra api ratham vahati iti racchā  kammā niyaḥ ññā
translated: The seventh-case form of kammā has the form niya when it means “good for work, etc.”🔽The seventh-case form of kammā has the form ñña when it means “good for work, etc.”: kamme sādhu kammaniyaṃ, kammaññaṃ.

original: Sattamyantā kammasaddā tattha sādhūbhi asmiṃ atthe niya ññā honti. Kamme sādhu kammaniyaṃ, kammaññaṃ.🔽74. Kathāditviko.
analyzed: sattamī antā kamma saddā tattha sādhūbhi asmin atthe niya ññā honti kamme sādhu kammaniyam kammaññam  kathā āditvikaḥ
translated: The seventh-case form of kathā, etc., has the form ika when it means “good for kathā, etc.”

original: Kathādīhi sattamyantehi tattha sādhūti asmiṃ atthe iko hoti. Kathiko, dhammakathiko, saṅgāmiko pavāsiko, upavāsiko.🔽75. Pathādīhi ṇeyyo.
analyzed: kathā ādīhi sattamī antehi tattha sādhu iti asmin atthe i kaḥ hoti kathikaḥ dhamma kathiko saṅgāmiko pavāsiko upavāsiko  patha ādīhi ṇeyyaḥ
translated: The seventh-case form of kathā, etc., has the form ika when it means “good for kathā, etc.”: kathiko, dhammakathiko, saṅgāmiko, pavāsiko, upavāsiko.🔽The seventh-case form of pathā, etc., has the form ṇeyya when it means “good for pathā, etc.”

original: Pathādīhi sattamyantehi tattha sādhūti asmiṃ atthe ṇe-yyo hoti, pātheyyaṃ sāpateyyaṃ (ātitheyyaṃ).
analyzed: patha ādīhi sattamī antehi tattha sādhu iti asmin atthe ṇeyyaḥ hoti pātheyyam sāpateyyam ātitheyyam
translated: The seventh-case form of pathā, etc., has the form ṇeyya when it means “good for pathā, etc.”: pātheyyaṃ, sāpateyyaṃ (ātitheyyaṃ).

original: 76. Dakkhiṇāyārahe.
analyzed: dakkhiṇāya arahe
translated: 2. Worthy of offerings.

original: Dakkhiṇāsaddato arahatthe ṇeyyo hoti, dakkhiṇaṃ arahatīti dakkhiṇeyyo.
analyzed: dakkhiṇā saddataḥ arahatthe ṇeyyaḥ hoti dakkhiṇam arahati iti dakkhiṇeyyaḥ
translated: The suffix ṇeyya is used in the sense of “worthy of” in the word dakkhiṇeyya, which is derived from dakkhiṇā + sadda + ṇeyya.

original: 77. Rāyo tumantā.
analyzed: rāyaḥ tumantā
translated: 3. The word tumanta.

original: Tumantato arahatthe rāyo hoti. Ghātetāyaṃ vā ghātetuṃ, jāpetāyaṃ vā jāpetuṃ, pabbājetāyaṃ vā pabbājetuṃ.
analyzed: tum antataḥ arahatthe rāyaḥ hoti ghāteta ayam vā ghātetum jāpeta ayam vā jāpetum pabbājeta ayam vā pabbājetum
translated: The suffix rā is used in the sense of “worthy of” in the word ghāterā, which is derived from ghātetuṃ + rā, or in the word jāperā, which is derived from jāpetuṃ + rā, or in the word pabbājerā, which is derived from pabbājetuṃ + rā.

original: 78. Tametthassatthīti mantu.
analyzed: tam etthassatthi iti mantu
translated: 4. The word mantu.

original: Paṭhamantā ettha assa atthīti etesvatthesu mantu hoti. Gāvo ettha dese, assa vā purisassa
analyzed: ettha assa atthi iti etesu atthesu mantu hoti gāvaḥ ettha dese assa vā purisassa
translated: The suffix mantu is used in the sense of “there is” in the words gomā, which is derived from go + ettha + mantu, and purisā, which is derived from purisa + ettha + mantu.

original: santīti gomā. Atthīti vattamānakālopādānato bhūtāhi bhavissantīhi vā gohi na gomā.
analyzed: santi iti gomā atthi iti vattamāna kāla upādānataḥ bhūtāhi bhavissantīhi vā gohi na gomā
translated: The word gomā is not used in the sense of “there are” in the past or future, because the suffix is used in the sense of the present.🔽How is it that the word gomā is used in the sense of “there was” and “there will be”?

original: Kathaṃ ‘gomā āsi, gomā bhavissatī’ti? Tadāpi vattamānāhiyeva gohi gomā, āsi bhavissatīti🔽padantarā kālantaraṃ, itikaraṇato visayaniyamo –🔽Pahūte ca pasaṃsāyaṃ, nindāyañcātisāyane;
analyzed: katham gomā āsi gomā bhavissati iti tadā api gohi gomā āsi bhavissati iti  pad antarā kāla antaram iti karaṇataḥ  pahūte ca pasaṃsāyam nindāyan ca atisāyane
translated: The word gomā is used in the sense of “there are” in the past and future, because the suffix is used in the sense of the present.

original: Niccayoge ca saṃsagge, hontime mantuādayo.
analyzed: nicca yoge ca saṃsagge honti ime mantu ādayaḥ
translated: The word mantu is used in the sense of “there is” in the words pahūterā, which is derived from pahūta + ettha + mantu, pasaṃsāyā, which is derived from pasaṃsā + ettha + mantu, nindāyā, which is derived from nindā + ettha + mantu, atīsāyanā, which is derived from atīsāyana + ettha + mantu, niccayogā, which is derived from niccayoga + ettha + mantu, and saṃsagge, which is derived from saṃsagga + ettha + mantu.

original: Go assoti jātisaddānaṃ dabbābhidhānasāmatthiyā mantvādayo na honti, tathā guṇasaddānaṃ
analyzed: go assa iti jāti saddānam dabba abhidhāna sāmatthiyā mantu ādayaḥ na honti tathā guṇa saddānam
translated: The words mantvā, etc., are not formed from the words go, etc., and the words guṇa, etc., because of the impossibility of the denotation of the base.

original: ‘seto paṭo’ti, yesantu guṇasaddānaṃ dabbābhidhānasāmatthiyaṃ natthi, tehi honteva
analyzed: paṭaḥ iti yesantu guṇa saddānam dabba abhidhāna sāmatthiyam na atthi tehi hontā iva
translated: ‘A white cloth’—but those words which are formed from the words guṇa, etc., which have the possibility of the denotation of the base, are

original: ‘buddhimā, rūpavā, rasavā, gandhavā, phassavā, saddavā, rasī, rasiko, rūpī, rūpiko,
analyzed: buddhimā rūpavā rasavā gandhavā phassavā saddavā rasī rasikaḥ rūpī rūpikaḥ
translated: ‘Intelligent, beautiful, tasty, fragrant, touchable, sonorous, sweet, sweet-natured, beautiful, beautiful-natured,

original: gandhī, gandhiko’ti.
analyzed: gandhī
translated: fragrant, fragrant-natured.’

original: 79. Vantvāvaṇṇā.
analyzed: vantvā avaṇṇā
translated: . Vantvāvaṇṇā.

original: Paṭhamantato avaṇṇantā mantvātthe vantu hoti. Sīlavā, paññavā, avaṇṇāti kiṃ? Satimā bandhumā.
analyzed: paṭhama antataḥ a vaṇṇantā hoti sīlavā paññavā a vaṇṇāti kim satimā bandhumā
translated: When the word is formed from the word avaṇṇa, the word vantu is formed. ‘Virtuous, wise’—what is the exception? ‘Mindful, kinsman.’

original: 80. Daṇḍāditvikaī vā.
analyzed: daṇḍa ādi tvika ī vā
translated: . Daṇḍāditvikaī vā.

original: Daṇḍādīhi ika ī honti vā mantvātthe. Bahulaṃ vidhānā kutoci dve honti, kutocekamekaṃva
analyzed: daṇḍa ādīhi i kaḥ ī honti vā mantu ātthe bahulam vidhānā kutoci dve honti kutoci ikam ekam iva
translated: The words ika and ī are formed from the words daṇḍa, etc., or not, when the word is formed. Because of the rule in many places, sometimes two are formed, sometimes only one is formed.

original: daṇḍiko daṇḍī daṇḍavā, gandhiko gandhī gandhavā, rūpiko rūpī rūpavā. (28) “Uttamīṇeva
analyzed: daṇḍikaḥ daṇḍī daṇḍavā gandhikaḥ gandhī gandhavā rūpikaḥ rūpī rūpavā uttamīṇā iva
translated: ‘Daṇḍiko, daṇḍī, daṇḍavā, gandhiko, gandhī, gandhavā, rūpiko, rūpī, rūpavā.’ “Uttamīṇeva

original: dhanā iko”, dhaniko, dhanī dhanavā añño. (29) “Asannihite atthā”, atthiko atthī,
analyzed: dhanā ikaḥ dhanikaḥ dhanī dhanavā aññaḥ asannihite atthā atthikaḥ atthī
translated: dhanā iko,” ‘dhaniko, dhanī, dhanavā’ is another. “Asannihite atthā,” ‘atthiko, atthī,

original: aññatra atthavā. (30) “Tadantā ca”, puññatthiko, puññatthī, (31) “vaṇṇantā īyeva”
analyzed: aññatra atthavā tad antā ca puññatthikaḥ puññatthī vaṇṇa ntā īyā iva
translated: except in the sense of meaning. (30) “Tadantā ca”, one who is desirous of merit, one who is desirous of merit, (31) “vaṇṇantā īyeva”

original: brahmavaṇṇī, devavaṇṇī, (32) “hatthadantehi jātiyaṃ”, hatthī, dantī, aññatra hatthavā
analyzed: brahma vaṇṇī deva vaṇṇī hattha dantehi jātiyam hatthī dantī aññatra hatthavā
translated: one who has the appearance of a brahma, one who has the appearance of a god, () “hatthadantehi jātiyaṃ”, an elephant, one who has tusks, except in the sense of an elephant

original: dantavā. (33) “Vaṇṇato brahmacārimhi”, vaṇṇī brahmacārī, vaṇṇavā añño. (34) “Pokkharādito
analyzed: dantavā vaṇṇataḥ brahmacārimhi vaṇṇī brahmacārī vaṇṇavā aññaḥ pokkhara āditaḥ
translated: having tusks. () “Vaṇṇato brahmacārimhi”, one who has the appearance of a celibate, a celibate, another who has the appearance. () “Pokkharādito

original: dese”, pokkharaṇī, uppalinī, kumudinī, bhisinī, muḷālinī, sālukinī, kvacādesepi padumipi
analyzed: dese pokkharaṇī uppalinī kumudinī bhisinī muḷālinī sālukinī kva ca ādese pi padumipi
translated: dese”, a lotus pond, a blue lotus pond, a white lotus pond, a red lotus pond, a pond with blue and white lotuses, a pond with white lotuses, a pond with red and white lotuses, a pond with lotuses,

original: paduminī paṇṇaṃ. Aññatra pokkharavā hatthī, (35) “nāvāyiko”, nāviko. (36) “Sukhadukkhā
analyzed: paduminī paṇṇam aññatra pokkharavā hatthī nāvāyikaḥ nāvikaḥ sukha dukkhā
translated: a pond with blue, red and white lotuses, a leaf. Except in the sense of a lotus pond, an elephant, () “nāvāyiko”, a boatman. () “Sukhadukkhā

original: ī”, sukhī, dukkhī. (37) “Sikhādīhi vā”, sikhī, sikhāvā, mālī, mālāvā, sīlī, sīlavā,
analyzed: ī sukhī dukkhī sikhā ādīhi vā sikhī sikhāvā mālī mālāvā sīlī sīlavā
translated: ī”, one who is happy, one who is unhappy. () “Sikhādīhi vā”, one who has a crest, one who has a crest, one who has a garland, one who has a garland, one who is virtuous, one who is virtuous,

original: balī, balavā. (38) “Balā bāhūrupubbā ca”, bāhubalī, ūrubalī.
analyzed: balī balavā balā ca bāhu balī ūru balī
translated: one who is strong, one who is strong. () “Balā bāhūrupubbā ca”, one who is strong in arms, one who is strong in thighs.

original: 81. Tapādīhi ssī. Tapādito mantvatthe vā ssī hoti. Tapassī, yasassī, tejassī, manassī, payassī. Vātveva? Yasavā.
analyzed: tapa ādīhi ssī tapa ādeḥ mantu atthe vā ssī hoti tapassī yasassī tejassī manassī payassī vā atvā iva yasavā
translated: . Tapādīhi ssī. Tapādito mantvatthe vā ssī hoti. An ascetic, one who has fame, one who has splendour, one who has mind, one who has milk. Except in the sense of having? One who has fame.

original: 82. Mukhādito ro. Mukhādīhi mantvatthero hoti. Mukharo, susiro, ūsaro, madhuro, kharo, kuñjaro, nagaraṃ, (39) “dantassu ca unnabhadante”, danturo.
analyzed: mukha āditaḥ raḥ mukha ādīhi mantu attheraḥ hoti mukharaḥ susiraḥ ūsaraḥ madhuraḥ kharaḥ kuñjaraḥ nagaram dantassu ca unnabha dante danturaḥ
translated: From the face, etc., the -ro affix. From the face, etc., the -ro affix is added to the word for the elder. Mukharo, susiro, ūsaro, madhuro, kharo, kuñjaro, nagaraṃ, “dantassu ca unnabhadante”, danturo.

original: 83. Tundyādīhi bho.
analyzed: tundī ādīhi bho
translated: . From the throat, etc., the -bho affix.

original: Tundiādīhi mantvatthe bho vā hoti. Tundibho, vaṭibho, valibho. Vātveva? Tundimā.
analyzed: tundi ādīhi mantu atthe bho vā hoti tundibhaḥ vaṭibhaḥ valibhaḥ vā atvā iva tundimā
translated: From the throat, etc., the -bho affix is added to the word for the elder. Tundibho, vaṭibho, valibho. Vātveva? Tundimā.

original: 84. Saddhāditvā.
analyzed: saddhā t itvā
translated: . From faith, etc., the -ea affix.

original: Saddhādīhi mantvatthea hoti vā. Saddho, pañño, itthiyaṃ saddhā. Vātveva? Paññavā.
analyzed: saddhā ādīhi hoti vā saddhaḥ paññaḥ itthiyam saddhā vā iva paññavā
translated: From faith, etc., the -ea affix is added to the word for the elder, or not. Saddho, pañño, itthiyaṃ saddhā. Vātveva? Paññavā.

original: 85. Ṇo tapā.
analyzed: ṇaḥ tapā
translated: . The -ṇo affix after tapā.

original: Tapā ṇo hoti mantvatthe. Tāpaso, itthiyaṃ tāpasī.
analyzed: tapā naḥ hoti mantu atthe tāpasaḥ itthiyam tāpasī
translated: The -ṇo affix is added after tapā in the sense of the elder. Tāpaso, itthiyaṃ tāpasī.

original: 86. Ālvabhijjhādīhi.
analyzed: ālu abhijjha ādīhi
translated: . From greed, etc., the -lu affix.

original: Abhijjhādīhi ālu hoti mantvatthe, abhijjhālu, sītālu, dhajālu, dayālu. Vātveva? Dayāvā.
analyzed: ālu hoti mantu atthe abhijjhālu sītālu dhajālu dayālu vātvā iva dayāvā
translated: From greed, etc., the -lu affix is added in the sense of the elder. Abhijjhālu, sītālu, dhajālu, dayālu. Vātveva? Dayāvā.

original: 87. Picchāditvilo.
analyzed: piccha ādi tu ilaḥ
translated: . From phlegm, etc., the -lo affix.

original: Picchādīhi ilo hoti vā mantvatthe. Picchilo picchavā, phenilo phenavā, jaṭilo jaṭāvā. Kathaṃ ‘vācālo’ti? Nindāyamilassādilope “paro kvacī”ti (1-27).
analyzed: piccha ādīhi ilaḥ hoti vā mantu atthe picchilaḥ picchavā phenilaḥ phenavā jaṭilaḥ jaṭāvā katham vācālaḥ iti paraḥ kvaci iti
translated: From phlegm, etc., the -lo affix is added in the sense of the elder, or not. Picchilo picchavā, phenilo phenavā, jaṭilo jaṭāvā. Kathaṃ ‘vācālo’? Nindāyamilassādilope “paro kvacī”ti (-).

original: 88. Sīlādito vo.
analyzed: sīla āditaḥ vaḥ
translated: . From virtue, etc., the -vo affix.

original: Sīlādīhi vo hoti vā mantvatthe. Sīlavo sīlavā, kesavo kesavā, (40) “aṇṇā niccaṃ” aṇṇavo. (41) Gāṇḍī rājīhi saññāyaṃ” gāṇḍīvaṃ dhanu, rājīvaṃ paṅkajaṃ.
analyzed: sīla ādīhi vaḥ hoti vā mantu atthe sīlavaḥ sīlavā kesavaḥ kesavā aṇṇā niccam aṇṇavaḥ gāṇḍī rājīhi saññāyam gāṇḍīvam dhanu rājīvam paṅkajam
translated: Sīla, etc., have the meaning of ‘virtue’ in sīlavā, sīlavā, kesavā, kesavā.🔽Aṇṇavo has the meaning of ‘constant’ in aṇṇā niccaṃ.

original: 89. Māyā medhāhi vī.
analyzed: māyā medhā hi vī
translated: Gāṇḍīva has the meaning of ‘bow’ in gāṇḍīvaṃ dhanu, and rājīva has the meaning of ‘lotus’ in rājīvaṃ paṅkajaṃ.

original: Etehi dvīhi vī hoti mantvatthe. Māyāvī, medhāvī.
analyzed: etehi dvīhi hoti mantu atthe māyāvī medhāvī
translated: Vī has the meaning of ‘skill’ in māyāvī, medhāvī.🔽Issare, āmyuvāmī.

original: 90. Sissare āmyuvāmī. Sasaddā āmyuvāmī honti issare-bhidhāyye mantvatthe. Samassatthīti sāmī, suvāmī.
analyzed: sissare āmi uvāmī sa saddāḥ āmi uvāmī honti issara abhidhāyye mantu atthe samassatthī iti sāmī suvāmī
translated: Issare, āmyuvāmī are added to the words of address in the sense of ‘lord’. Sāmī, suvāmī.🔽Lakkhī, ṇo a ca.

original: 91. Lakkhyā ṇo a ca. Lakkhīsaddā ṇo hoti mantvatthe a cāntassa. Ṇakārovayavo, lakkhaṇo.
analyzed: lakkhyā ṇo a ca lakkhī saddāḥ ṇo hoti mantu atthe a ca antassa ṇakāra uvayavaḥ lakkhaṇaḥ
translated: Lakkhī has the meaning of ‘mark’ in ṇo and a ca. Ṇakārovayavo, lakkhaṇo.

original: 92. Aṅgā no kalyāṇe.
analyzed: aṅga naḥ kalyāṇe
translated: Aṅga, no kalyāṇe.

original: Kalyāṇe gamyamāne aṅgasmā no hoti mantvatthe. Aṅganā.
analyzed: kalyāṇe gamyamāne aṅgasmai naḥ mantvatthe aṅganā
translated: Aṅga has the meaning of ‘limb’ in no and kalyāṇe. Aṅganā.

original: 93. So lomā.
analyzed: saḥ lomā
translated: Soma, lomā.

original: Lomā so hoti mantvatthe. Lomaso, itthiyaṃ, lomasā.
analyzed: lomā saḥ hoti mantu atthe lomasaḥ itthiyam lomasā
translated: Soma has the meaning of ‘hair’ in lomā. Lomaso, itthiyaṃ, lomasā.

original: 94. Imiyā.
analyzed: imiyā
translated: Imi, iyā.

original: Mantvatthe ima iyā honti bahulaṃ. Puttimo, kittimo, puttiyo, kappiyo, jaṭiyo, hānabhāgiyo, seniyo.
analyzed: mantu atthe ime iyāḥ honti bahulam puttimaḥ kittimaḥ puttiyaḥ kappiyaḥ jaṭiyaḥ hānabhāgiyaḥ seniyaḥ
translated: Imi and iyā have the meaning of ‘this’ in mantvatthe. Puttimo, kittimo, puttiyo, kappiyo, jaṭiyo, hānabhāgiyo, seniyo.

original: 95. To pañcamyā. Pañcamyantā bahulaṃ to hoti vā. Gāmato āgacchati gāmasmā āgacchati, corato bhāyati corehi bhāyati, satthato parihīno satthā parihīno.
analyzed: taḥ pañcamyā pañcamī antā bahulam taḥ hoti vā gāmataḥ āgacchati gāmasmai āgacchati corataḥ bhāyati corehi bhāyati satthataḥ parihīnaḥ satthā parihīnaḥ
translated: 95. To with the fifth case. To is often used with the fifth case. He comes from the village = gāmato āgacchati. He comes from the village = gāmasmā āgacchati. He is afraid of the thief = corato bhāyati. He is afraid of thieves = corehi bhāyati. He is deprived of the teacher = satthato parihīno. He is deprived of the teacher = satthā parihīno.

original: 96. Ito-tetto kuto.
analyzed: itaḥ ta it taḥ kutaḥ
translated: . Ito-tetto kuto.

original: Tomhi imassa ṭi nipaccate, etassa ṭa eta, kiṃsaddassa kuttañca. Ito imasmā, ato etto etasmā, kuto kasmā.
analyzed: tomhi imassa ṭi nipaccate etassa ṭaḥ eta kiṃsaddassa kuttan ca itas imasmai atas ettas etasmai kutas kasmai
translated: Tomhi imassa ṭi nipaccate, etassa ṭa eta, kiṃsaddassa kuttañca. From this = imasmā. From that = etasmā. From where = kasmā.

original: 97. Abhyādīhi. Abhiādīhi to hoti. Abhito, parito, pacchato heṭṭhato.
analyzed: abhyādīhi abhiādīhi to hoti abhitas paritas pacchatas heṭṭhatas
translated: . Abhyādīhi. Abhiādīhi to hoti. From here = abhito. From all around = parito. From behind = pacchato. From below = heṭṭhato.

original: 98. Ādyādīhi. Ādippabhutīhi to vā hoti, ādo ādito, majjhato antato, piṭṭhito, passato, mukhato, yatodakaṃ tadādittaṃ, yaṃ udakaṃ tadevādittanti attho.
analyzed: ādi ādīhi ādi ppabhutīhi to vā hoti ādaḥ āditaḥ majjhataḥ antataḥ piṭṭhitaḥ passataḥ mukhataḥ yataḥ udakam tat ādittam yam udakam tat eva ādittam ti attho
translated: . Ādyādīhi. Ādippabhutīhi to vā hoti. From the beginning = ādo ādito. From the middle = majjhato. From the end = antato. From the back = piṭṭhito. From the front = passato. From the mouth = mukhato. From where the water is, from there the fire is = yatodakaṃ tadādittaṃ. The meaning is: from where the water is, from there the fire is.

original: 99. Sabbādito sattamyā trattā. Sabbādīhi sattamyantehi tratthā vā honti. Sabbatra sabba. Sabbasmiṃ, yatra yattha yasmiṃ. Bahulādhikārā na tumhāmhehi.
analyzed: sabba ādeḥ sattamyā sabba ādīhi sattamī antehi vā honti sabbatra sabba sabbasmin yatra yattha yasmin bahula adhikārāḥ na tumha amhehi
translated: . Sabbādito sattamyā trattā. Sabbādīhi sattamyantehi trattā vā honti. Everywhere = sabbatra. All = sabba. In all = sabbasmiṃ. Where = yattha. In which = yasmiṃ. Because of the general rule about bahula, not tumhāmhehi.

original: 100. Katthettha kutrātra kvehidha.
analyzed: katthā itthā kutra atra kva ihidha
translated: . Katthettha kutrātra kvehidha.

original: Etesaddā nipaccante. Kasmiṃ kattha, kutra, kva, etasmiṃ, ettha, atra, asmiṃ iha, idha.
analyzed: nipaccante kasmin kattha kutra kva etasmin ettha atra asmin iha idha
translated: Etesaddā nipaccante. Kasmiṃ kattha, kutra, kva, etasmiṃ, ettha, atra, asmiṃ iha, idha.

original: 101. Dhi sabbā vā. Sattamyantato sabbasmā dhi vā hoti. Sabbadhi, sabbattha.
analyzed: dhi sabbā vā sattamī antataḥ sabbasmā dhi vā hoti sabbadhi sabbattha
translated: . Dhi sabbā vā. Sattamyantato sabbasmā dhi vā hoti. Sabbadhi, sabbattha.

original: 102. Yā hiṃ. Sattamyantato yato hiṃ vā hoti. Yahiṃ yatra.
analyzed: yā hiṃ sattamī antatas yatas hiṃ vā yatra
translated: . Yā hiṃ. Sattamyantato yato hiṃ vā hoti. Yahiṃ yatra.

original: 103. Tā haṃ ca.
analyzed: tāḥ haṃ ca
translated: . Tā haṃ ca.

original: Sattamyantato tato vā haṃ hoti hiṃ ca. Tahaṃ, tahiṃ, tatra.
analyzed: tatas vā haṃ hoti him ca tahaṃ tahim tatra
translated: Sattamyantato tato vā haṃ hoti hiṃ ca. Tahaṃ, tahiṃ, tatra.

original: 104. Kuhiṃ kahaṃ.
analyzed: kuhim kaham
translated: . Kuhiṃ kahaṃ.

original: Kiṃsaddā sattamyantā hiṃ haṃ nipaccante kissa kukā ca. Kuhiṃ, kahaṃ. Kathaṃ ‘kuhiñcana’nti? ‘Canaṃ’ iti nipātantaraṃ ‘kuhiñcī’ti ettha cisaddo viya.
analyzed: kiṃsaddā sattamī antāḥ hiṃ haṃ nipaccante kissa kukā ca kuhim kaham katham kuhiṃcana iti canaṃ iti nipāta antaram kuhiñci iti ettha ci saddaḥ viya
translated: Kiṃsaddā sattamyantā hiṃ haṃ nipaccante kissa kukā ca. Kuhiṃ, kahaṃ. Kathaṃ ‘kuhiñcana’nti? ‘Canaṃ’ iti nipātantaraṃ ‘kuhiñcī’ti ettha cisaddo viya.

original: 105. Sabbekaññayatehi kāle dā. Etehi sattamyantehi kāle dā hoti. Sabbasmiṃ kāle sabbadā, ekadā, aññadā, yadā, tadā. Kāleti kiṃ? Sabbattha dese.
analyzed: sabba ekañña yatehi kāle dā etehi sattamī antehi kāle dā hoti sabbasmin kāle sabbadā ekadā aññadā yadā tadā kāla iti kim sabbattha dese
translated: . Sabbekaññayatehi kāle dā. Etehi sattamyantehi kāle dā hoti. Sabbasmiṃ kāle sabbadā, ekadā, aññadā, yadā, tadā. Kāleti kiṃ? Sabbattha dese.

original: 106. Kadā kudā sadā dhunedāni.
analyzed: kadā kudā sadā dhuna idāni
translated: . Kadā kudā sadā dhunedāni.

original: Ete saddā nipaccante. Kasmiṃ kāle kadā, kudā, sabbasmiṃ kāle sadā, imasmiṃ kāle adhunā, idāni.
analyzed: ete saddāḥ nipaccante kasmim kāle kadā kudā sabbasmim kāle sadā imasmim kāle adhunā idāni
translated: These words are declined. In what time? When, when? In all time, always. In this time, now, at present.

original: 107. Ajja sajjvaparajjvetarahi karahā.
analyzed: ajja karahā
translated: Today, tomorrow, the day after, now.

original: Etesaddā nipaccante. Pakatippaccayo ādeso kālavisesoti sabbametaṃ nipātanā labbhati,
analyzed: ete saddāḥ nipaccante pakati paccayaḥ ādesaḥ kāla visesaḥ iti sabbam etam nipātanā labbhati
translated: These words are declined. The natural case-ending, the prefix, and the particular time are all declined.

original: imassa ṭo jjo jāhani nipaccate, asmiṃ ahani ajja. Samānassa sabhāvo jju cāhani, samāne
analyzed: imassa ṭaḥ jjaḥ jā ahani nipaccate asmim ahani ajja samānassa sabhāvaḥ ca ahani samāne
translated: The ending -o is declined in the locative case. On this day, today. The nature of the same, -jju, on the same day, on the same day.

original: ahani sajju. Aparasmā jju, aparasmiṃ ahani aparajju. Imasseto kāle rahi ca, imasmiṃ
analyzed: ahani sajju aparasmā jju aparasmin ahani aparajju imassa itas kāle ca imasmin
translated: From the other, on the other day, the day after. In this time, now.

original: kāle etarahi. Kiṃsaddassa ko raha cānajjatane, kasmiṃ kāle karaha.
analyzed: kāle etarahi kiṃsaddassa kaḥ raha ca anajjatane kasmin kāle karaha
translated: In what time? In all time.

original: 108. Sabbādīhi payāre thā.
analyzed: sabba ādīhi payāre thā
translated: With sabba, etc., thā.

original: Sāmaññassa bhedako viseso pakāro, tattha vattamānehi sabbādīhi thā hoti. Sabbena pakārena sabbathā, yathā, tathā.
analyzed: sāmaññassa bhedakaḥ visesaḥ pakāraḥ tattha vattamānehi sabba ādīhi thā hoti sabbena pakārena sabbathā yathā tathā
translated: The particular is the difference of the general. The mode is the manner. There, with the present, etc., thā is used. In every way, in every manner, as, so.

original: 109. Kathamitthaṃ.
analyzed: katham ittham
translated: How is it here?

original: Ete saddā nipaccante pakāre. Kimimehi thaṃ paccayo, kaita ca tesaṃ yathākkamaṃ, kathaṃ, itthaṃ.
analyzed: ete saddāḥ nipaccante pakāre kim imehi tham paccayaḥ ca tesam yathākkamam katham ittham
translated: These are the syllables. What is the condition for these? And what are they respectively? How? Thus.

original: 110. Dhā saṅkhyāhi.
analyzed: dhāḥ saṅkhyāhi
translated: . The verbal-noun ending is added to numerals.

original: Saṅkhyāvācīhi pakāre dhā parā hoti. Dvīhi pakārehi, dve vā pakāre karoti dvidhā karoti,
analyzed: saṅkhyā avāci pakāre dhā parā hoti dvīhi pakārehi dve vā pakāre karoti dvidhā karoti
translated: The verbal-noun ending is added to numerals. He makes two ways from two syllables, he makes two ways,

original: bahudhā karoti, ekaṃ rāsiṃ pañcappakāraṃ karoti pañcadhā karoti, pañcappakāramekappakāraṃ
analyzed: bahudhā karoti ekam rāsim pañca ppakāram karoti pañcadhā karoti pañca ppakāram eka ppakāram
translated: he makes many ways, he makes one heap fivefold, he makes five ways, he makes five ways one way,

original: karoti ekadhā karoti.
analyzed: karoti ekadhā karoti
translated: he makes one way.

original: 111. Vekā jjhaṃ.
analyzed: vekāḥ jjhaṃ
translated: . One by one.

original: Ekasmā pakare jjhaṃ vā hoti. Ekajjhaṃ karoti, ekadhā, karoti.
analyzed: ekasmai pakare vā hoti ekajjham karoti ekadhā karoti
translated: The syllable jjha is added to one syllable. He makes one by one, he makes one way.

original: 112. Dvitīhedhā.
analyzed: dvitīya idhā
translated: . In two ways.

original: Dvitīhi pakāre edhā vā hoti. Dvedhā, tedhā, dvidhā, tidhā.
analyzed: pakāre edhā vā dvedhā tedhā dvidhā tidhā
translated: The syllable edha is added to two syllables. In two ways, in three ways, in two ways, in three ways.

original: 113. Tabbati jātiyo.🔽Pakāravati taṃsāmaññavācakā saddā jātiyo hoti, paṭujātiyo, mudujātiyo.
analyzed: tabbati jātiyaḥ  pakāravati saddāḥ jātiyaḥ hoti paṭu jātiyaḥ mudu jātiyaḥ
translated: . The class is added to that.

original: 114. Vārasaṅkhyāya kkhattuṃ.
analyzed: vāra saṅkhyāya kkhattum
translated: The words expressing the same meaning as the syllables are the class. The class of one, the class of the soft.

original: Vārasambandhiniyā saṅkhyāya kkhattuṃ hoti. Dve vāre bhuñjati dvikkhattuṃ divasassa bhuñjati. Vāraggahaṇaṃ kiṃ? Pañca bhuñjati. Saṅkhyāyāti kiṃ? Pahūte vāre bhuñjati.
analyzed: vāra sambandhiniyā saṅkhyāya hoti dve vāre bhuñjati dvi khattum divasassa bhuñjati vāra ggahaṇam kim pañca bhuñjati saṅkhyāya ati kim pahūte vāre bhuñjati
translated: The instrumental case of the numeral in apposition to a word for “time” has the form kkhattuṃ. He eats two times, he eats twice a day. What is the purpose of mentioning “time”? He eats five times. What is the purpose of mentioning “numeral”? He eats many times.

original: 115. Katimhā.
analyzed: katimhā
translated: . Katimhā.

original: Vārasambandhiniyā katisaṅkhyāya kkhattuṃ hoti, kati vāre, bhuñjathi, katikkhattuṃ bhuñjati.
analyzed: vāra sambandhiniyā kati saṅkhyāya kkhattum hoti kati vāre katikkhattum bhuñjati
translated: The instrumental case of the numeral in apposition to a word for “time” has the form kkhattuṃ. He eats at five times, he eats five times.

original: 116. Bahumhā dhā ca paccāsattiyaṃ.
analyzed: bahumhā dhā ca paccāsattiyam
translated: . Bahumhā dhā ca paccāsattiyaṃ.

original: Vārasambandhiniyā bahusaṅkhyāya dhā hoti kkhatthuṃ ca, vārānañce paccāsatti hoti, bahudhā divasassa bhuñjati bahukkhattuṃ bhuñjati. Paccāsattiyanti kiṃ? Bahuvāre māsassa bhuñjati.
analyzed: vāra sambandhiniyā bahu saṅkhyāya dhā hoti kkhatthum ca paccāsatti hoti bahudhā divasassa bhuñjati bahu kkhattum bhuñjati kim bahu vāre māsassa bhuñjati
translated: The instrumental case of the numeral in apposition to a word for “time” has the form dhā, and there is the affix paccāsatti, when there is a numeral meaning “many.” He eats many times a day, he eats much. What is the purpose of mentioning “paccāsatti”? He eats many times a month.

original: 117. Sakiṃ vā.
analyzed: sakim vā
translated: . Sakiṃ vā.

original: Ekaṃ vāramiccasmiṃ atthe sakinti vā nipaccate. Ekavāraṃ bhuñjati sakiṃ bhuñjati, vāti kiṃ? Ekakkhattuṃ bhuñjati.🔽118. So vīcchappakāresu.
analyzed: ekam vāram iccasmin atthe vā nipaccate eka vāram bhuñjati sakim bhuñjati vā ati kim eka khattum bhuñjati 🔽saḥ vīccha pakāresu
translated: The word sakinti is substituted for ekaṃ vāramiccasmiṃ atthe. He eats once, he eats at one time. What is the purpose of mentioning “once”? He eats at one time.

original: Vīcchāyaṃ pakāre ca so hoti bahulaṃ. Vīcchāyaṃ-khaṇḍaso, bilaso. Pakāre-puthuso, sabbaso.
analyzed: pakāre ca saḥ hoti bahulam bilasaḥ pakāreputhusaḥ sabbaso
translated: He is often in Vīcchā and Pakāra. In Vīcchā, in pieces, in fragments. In Pakāra, separately, entirely.

original: 119. Abhūtatabbhāve karāsabhūyoge vikārā cī.
analyzed: a bhūta tad bhāve kara asa bhū yoge vikārā cī
translated: . In the non-existence of what is, in the non-existence of what is not, in the change of what is, there is cī.

original: Avatthāvato-vatthantarenābhūtassa tāyāvatthāya bhāvekarāsabhūhi sambandhe sati vikāravācakā
analyzed: tāya avatthāya sambandhe sati vikāra vācakā
translated: When there is a connection with the non-existence of what is, with the non-existence of what is not, with the change of what is,

original: cī hoti, adhavalaṃ dhavalaṃ karoti dhavalī karoti, adhavalo dhavalo siyā dhavalī🔽siyā, adhavalo dhavalo bhavati dhavalī bhavati. Abhūta tabbhāveti kiṃ? Ghaṭaṃ karoti,
analyzed: adhavalam dhavalam karoti dhavalī karoti adhavalaḥ dhavalaḥ siyāḥ dhavalī  siyāḥ adhavalaḥ dhavalaḥ bhavati dhavalī bhavati kim ghaṭam karoti
translated: cī is used to express the change. He makes white what is not white, he makes it white. He may be not white, he may be white.🔽He may be not white, he may be white. He may become not white, he may become white. What is non-existence of what is? He makes a pot.

original: dadhi atthi, ghaṭo bhavati. Karāsabhūyogeti kiṃ? Adhavalodhavalo jāyate. Vikārāti
analyzed: dadhi atthi ghaṭaḥ bhavati kim adhavalaḥ dhavalaḥ jāyate
translated: There is curd. He becomes a pot. What is non-existence of what is not? Not white, white, is born. What is change?

original: kiṃ? Pakatiyā māhotu, suvaṇṇaṃ kuṇḍalaṃ karoti.
analyzed: kim suvaṇṇam kuṇḍalam karoti
translated: What? Make it big by nature. He makes a golden earring.

original: 120. Dissantaññepi paccayā.
analyzed: dissantaññe pi paccayā
translated: . Even in what is seen, there are conditions.

original: Vuttato-ññepi paccayā dissanti vuttāvuttatthesu. Vividhā mātaro vimātaro, tāsaṃ puttā
analyzed: paccayāḥ dissanti vutta avutta tthesu vividhāḥ mātaraḥ vimātaraḥ tāsam puttā
translated: Even in what is seen, conditions are seen in the meanings of what is said and what is not said. Various mothers, non-mothers. Their sons,

original: vemātikā-rikaṇa. Pathaṃ gacchatīti pathāvino-āvī. Issā assa atthīti issukī-ukī. Dhuraṃ
analyzed: vemātikārikaṇa patham gacchati iti pathāvi noāvī issā assa atthi iti dhuram
translated: the one who is a mother’s brother is a maternal uncle. The one who goes by a path is a wayfarer. The one who has envy is an envious person.

original: vahatīti dhorayho- yhaṇa.
analyzed: vahati iti dhoḥ ayhaḥ yha ṇa
translated: The word vemātikā-rikaṇa is derived from the root √mañj (to enjoy) with the prefix ve (away) and the suffix -ātikā (a feminine noun-forming suffix). The word pathāvino-āvī is derived from the root √vī (to go) with the prefix paṭhaṃ (along the path) and the suffix -āvino (a masculine noun-forming suffix). The word issukī-ukī is derived from the root √suk (to be happy) with the prefix i (not) and the suffix -ukī (a feminine noun-forming suffix). The word dhorayho-yhaṇa is derived from the root √vah (to carry) with the prefix dhuraṃ (a load) and the suffix -ayhaṇa (a masculine noun-forming suffix).

original: 121. Aññasmiṃ.
analyzed: aññasmin
translated: . In the sense of another.

original: Vuttato-ññasmimpi atthe vuttappaccayā dissanti. Magadhānaṃ issaro māgadho-dhaṇā. Kāsīti sahassaṃ, tamagghatīti kāsiyo iyo.
analyzed: vutta toññasmim pi atthe vutta paccayāḥ dissanti magadhānam issaraḥ māgadhodhaṇā kāsīti sahassam tamagghati iti
translated: From what has been said, it is also seen that suffixes are used in the sense of another. The word māgadho-dhaṇā is derived from the root √dhā (to hold) with the prefix māgadhaṃ (Magadha) and the suffix -o (a masculine noun-forming suffix). The word kāsiyo iyo is derived from the root √kās (to be worth) with the prefix kāsi (a thousand) and the suffix -o (a masculine noun-forming suffix).

original: 122. Sakatthe.
analyzed: sa ka tthe
translated: . In the sense of a vehicle.

original: Sakatthepi paccayā dissanti. Hīnako, potako, kiccayaṃ.
analyzed: saka atthe pi paccayāḥ dissanti hīnakaḥ potakaḥ
translated: It is also seen that suffixes are used in the sense of a vehicle. The words hīnako, potako, kiccayaṃ are derived from the roots √hī (to be low), √pat (to fall), and √kṛ (to do) respectively with the suffix -ko (a masculine noun-forming suffix).

original: 123. Lopo.
analyzed: lopaḥ
translated: . Omission.

original: Paccayānaṃ lopopi dissati. Buddhe ratanaṃ paṇītaṃ, cakkhuṃ suññaṃ attena vā attariyena vāti bhāvappaccayalopo.
analyzed: paccayānam lopaḥ api dissati buddhe ratanam paṇītam cakkhum suññam attena vā attariyena vā ti bhāva ppaccaya lopo
translated: It is also seen that suffixes are omitted. The words buddhe ratanaṃ paṇītaṃ, cakkhuṃ suññaṃ attena vā attariyena vā are examples of the omission of the suffix -a (a masculine noun-forming suffix).

original: 124. Sarānamādissāyuvaṇṇassāeo ṇānubandhe.
analyzed: sara anam ādi ssa yu vaṇ ṇassā eaḥ ṇa anubandhe
translated: . The suffixes āeo ṇānubandhe are added to the words beginning with sarānam.

original: Sarānamādibhūtā ye akārivaṇṇuvaṇṇā, tesaṃ āeo honti yathākkamaṃṇānubandhe. Rāghavo, venateyyo, meniko, oḷumpiko, dobhaggaṃ. Ṇānubandheti kiṃ? Purātano.🔽125. Saṃyoge kvaci.
analyzed: sarānama ādi bhūtāḥ ye tesam honti yathā kkamaṃ ṇa anubandhe rāghavaḥ venateyyaḥ menikaḥ oḷumpikaḥ dobhaggam kim purātanaḥ 🔽saṃyoge kvaci
translated: The suffixes āeo are added to the words beginning with sarānam, which are formed by the roots akāri (to do) and vaṇṇu (to praise) respectively, in the order, with the suffix ṇānubandhe. The

original: Sarānamādibhūtā ye ayuvaṇṇā, tesaṃ āeo honti kvacideva saṃyogavisaye ṇānubandhe. Decco, koṇḍañño. Kvacīti kiṃ? Kattikeyyo.
analyzed: sarā nama ādi bhūtāḥ ye tesam honti kvacid eva saṃyoga visaye ṇa anubandhe kvaci iti kim kattikeyyaḥ
translated: The ā, e, o are for those ayus and vaṇṇas which are the beginning of a word, and in some instances for those which follow a ṇ. Decco, koṇḍañño. In some instances what? Kattikeyyo.

original: 126. Majjhe.
analyzed: majjhe
translated: . In the middle.

original: Majjhe vattamānānampi ayuvaṇṇānaṃ ā e o honti kvaci. Aḍḍhateyyo, vāseṭṭho.🔽127. Kosajjājjava pārisajja sohajja maddavārissāsabhājaññatheyya bāhusaccā.🔽Etesaddā nipaccanteṇānubandhe. Kusī tassa bhāvokosajjaṃ, ujuno bhāvo ajjavaṃ, parisāsu
analyzed: majjhe vattamānānam pi ayuvaṇṇānam ā e o honti kvaci aḍḍhateyyaḥ vāseṭṭhaḥ  kosajja ajjava pārisajja sohajja bāhusaccā  ete saddāḥ nipad anteṇa anubandhe kusī tassa bhāvaḥ ukosajjam ujunaḥ bhāvaḥ ajjavam parisāsu
translated: The ā, e, o are for those ayus and vaṇṇas which occur in the middle of a word, in some instances. Aḍḍhateyyo, vāseṭṭho.

original: sādhu pārisajjo, suhadayova suhajjo, tassa pana bhāvo sohajjaṃ, muduno bhāvo maddavaṃ,🔽isino idaṃ bhāvo vā ārissaṃ, usabhassa idaṃ bhāvo vā āsabhaṃ, ājānīyassa bhāvo so🔽eva vā ājaññaṃ, thenassa bhāvo kammaṃ vā theyyaṃ, bahussatassa bhāvo bāhusaccaṃ,🔽etesu yamalakkhaṇikaṃ, taṃ nipātanā.
analyzed: sādhu pārisajjaḥ su hadayaḥ uva su hajjaḥ tassa pana bhāvaḥ sohajjam mudunaḥ bhāvaḥ maddavam  isinaḥ idam bhāvaḥ vai ārissam usabhassa idam bhāvaḥ vai āsabham ājānīyassa bhāvaḥ saḥ  eva vai ājaññam thenassa bhāvaḥ kammam vā theyyam bahussatassa bhāvaḥ bāhusaccam  etesu yama lakkhaṇikam tam nipātanā
translated: . Sloth, straightforwardness, sociability, kindness, softness, austerity, leadership, generosity, and erudition.

original: 128. Manādīnaṃ saka.
analyzed: mana ā dīnam saka
translated: These words are declined with the ṇ affix. Kusī = kusī = kusī = kusī = kusī = kusī = kusī = kusī = kusī = kusī = kusī = kusī = kusī = kusī = kusī = kusī = kusī = kusī = kusī = kusī = kusī = kusī = kusī = kusī = kusī = kusī = kusī = kusī = kusī = kusī = kusī = kusī = kusī = kusī = kusī = kusī = kusī = kusī = kusī = kusī = kusī = kusī = kusī = kusī = kusī = kusī = kusī = kusī = kusī = kusī = kusī = kusī = kusī = kusī = kusī = kusī = kusī = kusī = kusī = kusī = kusī = kusī = kusī = kusī = kusī = kusī = kusī = kusī = kusī = kusī = kusī = kusī = kusī = kusī = kusī = kusī = kusī = kusī = kusī = kusī = kusī = kusī = kusī = kusī = kusī = kusī = kusī = kusī = kusī = kusī = kusī = kusī = kusī = kusī = kusī = kusī = kusī = kusī = kusī = kusī = kusī = kusī = kusī = kusī = kusī = kusī = kusī = kusī = kusī = kusī = kusī = kusī = kusī = kusī = kusī = kusī = kusī = kusī = kusī = kusī = kusī = kusī = kusī = kusī =

original: Manādīnaṃ saka hoti ṇānubandhe. Manasi bhavaṃ mānasaṃ, dummanaso bhāvo domanassaṃ, somanassaṃ.
analyzed: man ādīnam saka hoti ṇa anubandhe manasi bhavam mānasam dummanasaḥ bhāvaḥ domanassam somanassam
translated: The affix saka is added to man, etc., when the meaning is ‘one’s own’. The state of being in the mind is mānasaṃ; the state of being of one who is not glad is domanassaṃ; the state of being of one who is glad is somanassaṃ.

original: 129. Uvaṇṇassāvaṅa sare.
analyzed: u va ṇ nassā avaṅa sare
translated: The affix -avaṅa is added to uvaṇṇa.

original: Sarādo ṇānubandhe uvaṇṇassāvaṅa hoti. Rāghavo, jambavaṃ.🔽130. Yamhi gossa ca.
analyzed: ṇa anubandhe hoti rāghavaḥ jambavam  yamhi gossa ca
translated: The affix -avaṅa is added to sarādo when the meaning is ‘one’s own’. Rāghavo, jambavaṃ.

original: Yakārādo paccaye gossuvaṇṇassa ca avaṅa hoti. Gabyaṃ, bhātabyo.
analyzed: yakāra ādaḥ paccaye gossuvaṇṇassa ca avaṅa hoti gabyam bhātabyaḥ
translated: The affix -avaṅa is added to gossa when the meaning is ‘one’s own’. Gabyaṃ, bhātabyo.

original: 131. Lopo-vaṇṇivaṇṇānaṃ.
translated: The affix -avaṅa is elided in the case of avaṇṇa and vaṇṇa.

original: Yakārādo paccaye avaṇṇivaṇṇānaṃ lopo hoti. Dāyajjaṃ, kāruññaṃ, ādhipaccaṃ, deppaṃ. Bahulaṃvidhānā kvaci na hoti kiccayaṃ.
analyzed: yakāra ādaḥ paccaye a vaṇṇi vaṇṇānam lopaḥ hoti dāyajjam kāruññam ādhipaccam deppam bahulam vidhānā kvaci na hoti kiccayam
translated: The affix -avaṅa is elided in the case of avaṇṇa and vaṇṇa. Dāyajjaṃ, kāruññaṃ, ādhipaccaṃ, deppaṃ. The rule does not apply in the case of kiccayaṃ, because of the general principle of the bahula.

original: 132. Rānubandhe-nta sarādissa.
analyzed: ra anubandha inta sa ra ādissa
translated: The affix -avaṅa is elided in the case of rānubandha and -nta.

original: Anto saro ādimhi yassāvayavassa, tassa lopo hoti rānubandhe. Kittakaṃ, petteyyaṃ.🔽133. Kisamahatamime kasa mahā.
analyzed: antaḥ sa raḥ ādimhi yassa avayavassa tassa lopaḥ hoti ra anubandhe kittakam petteyyam  mahā
translated: The affix -avaṅa is elided in the case of rānubandha and -nta. Kittakaṃ, petteyyaṃ.🔽The affixes -kasa and -mahā are added to kisa and mahā respectively.

original: Kisassa mahato ime kasamahā honti yathākkamaṃ, kasimā, mahimā.🔽134. Āyussāyasa mantumhi.
analyzed: kisassa mahataḥ ime kasamahāḥ honti yathākkamam kasimā mahimā  āyuḥ sa āyasa mantumhi
translated: The affixes -kasa and -mahā are added to kisa and mahā respectively. Kasimā, mahimā.🔽The affix -āyasā is added to āyu in the sense of ‘life’.

original: Āyussa āyasādeso hoti mantumhi. Āyasmā.
analyzed: āyussa āyasa ādesaḥ hoti mantumhi
translated: The affix -āyasā is added to āyu in the sense of ‘life’. Āyasmā.

original: 135. Jo vuddhassiyiṭṭhesu.
analyzed: jaḥ vuddhassiyiṭṭhesu
translated: The affix -ī is added to vuddha, ssu, and yiṭṭha.

original: Vuddhassa jo hoti iyaiṭṭhesu, jeyyo, jeṭṭho.🔽136. Bāḷhantikapasatthānaṃ sādha neda sā.
analyzed: vuddhassa jaḥ hoti iyaiṭṭhesu jeyyaḥ jeṭṭhaḥ  sādha na idam sā
translated: Jo is used in the sense of ‘younger’ in the words jeyyo, jeṭṭho.

original: Iyaiṭṭhesu bāḷhantikapasatthānaṃ sādha neda sā honti yathākkamaṃ. Sādhiyo, sādhiṭṭho, nediyo, nediṭṭho, seyyo, seṭṭho.🔽137. Kaṇakanāppayuvānaṃ.
analyzed: iyaiṭṭhesu honti yathākkamam sādhiyaḥ sādhiṭṭhaḥ nediyaḥ nediṭṭhaḥ seyyaḥ seṭṭhaḥ  kaṇaka nāppa yuvānam
translated: Sādhiyo, sādhiṭṭho, nediyo, nediṭṭho, seyyo, seṭṭho are formed by adding the suffixes -iya, -ittha, -iya, -ittha, -eyya, -ettha respectively to the words sādha, sādha, neda, neda, seyya, seyya.🔽Kaṇiyo, kaniṭṭho are formed by adding the suffixes -iya, -ittha respectively to the words kaṇa, kaṇa.

original: Iyaiṭṭhesu appayuvānaṃ kaṇa kanā honti yathākkamaṃ. Kaṇiyo kaṇiṭṭho, kaniyo kaniṭṭho.
analyzed: iyaiṭṭhesu appayuvānam kaṇa kanā honti yathākkamam kaṇiyaḥ kaṇiṭṭhaḥ kaniyaḥ kaniṭṭhaḥ
translated: Kaṇiyo, kaniṭṭho are formed by adding the suffixes -iya, -ittha respectively to the words kaṇa, kaṇa.

original: 138. Lopo vī mantu vantūnaṃ.
analyzed: lopaḥ mantu vantu ūnam
translated: Lopo vī mantu vantūnaṃ.

original: Vī mantu vantūnaṃ lopo hoti iyaiṭṭhesu. Atisayena medhāvī medhiyo, medhiṭṭho, atisayena satimā satiyo, satiṭṭho, atisayena guṇavā guṇiyo, guṇiṭṭho.
analyzed: vī mantu vantūnam lopaḥ hoti iyaiṭṭhesu atisayena medhāvī medhiyaḥ medhiṭṭhaḥ atisayena satimā satiyaḥ satiṭṭhaḥ atisayena guṇavā guṇiyaḥ guṇiṭṭhaḥ
translated: The elision of vī, mantu, and vantū takes place in the sense of ‘younger’. Medhiyo, medhiṭṭho, satiyo, satiṭṭho, guṇiyo, guṇiṭṭho are formed by adding the suffixes -iya, -ittha respectively to the words medhāvī, medhāvī, satimā, satimā, guṇavā, guṇavā.

original: 139. Ḍe satissa tissa.
analyzed: ḍe sa tissa tissa
translated: Ḍe satissa tissa.

original: Ḍepare satyantassa tikārassa lopo hoti, vīsaṃ sataṃ, tiṃsaṃ sataṃ.
analyzed: ḍe pare sati antassa tikārassa lopaḥ hoti vīsam satam tiṃsam satam
translated: The elision of the ti of satti takes place when followed by ḍe. Vīsasaṃ sataṃ, tiṃsaṃ sataṃ.

original: 140. Etasseṭa ttake.
analyzed: etassa iṭa ttake
translated: Etasseṭa ttake.

original: Ttake pare etassa eṭa hoti. Ettakaṃ.
analyzed: ttake pare etassa e ṭa hoti e ttakam
translated: The elision of the e of ettha takes place when followed by ttaka. Ettakaṃ.

original: 141. Ṇikassiyo vā.
analyzed: ṇikassiyaḥ vā
translated: Ṇikassiyo vā.

original: Ṇikassa vā iyo hoti, sakyaputtiyo, sakyaputtiko.
analyzed: ṇikassa vā iyaḥ hoti sakyaputtiyaḥ sakyaputtikaḥ
translated: The elision of ṇikassa takes place, and iya is added. Sakyaputtiyo, sakyaputtiko.

original: 142. Adhātussa kā-syādito ghe-ssi.🔽Ghe pare adhātussa yo kakāro, tato pubbassa akārassa bahulaṃ i hoti sace gho na syādito🔽paro hoti. Bālikā, kārikā, adhātussāti kiṃ? Sakā, keti kiṃ? Nandanā, asyāditoti kiṃ?🔽Bahuparibbājakā mathurā, bahucammikāti kakārena syādino byavahitattā siddhaṃ, gheti
analyzed: a dhātuḥ sa kā asya ā t itaḥ ghessi  ghe pare a dhātussa yaḥ kakāraḥ tatas pubbassa akārassa bahulam i hoti sace ghaḥ na syāt itas  paraḥ hoti bālikā kārikā sakā kā iti kim nandanā kim  bahu paribbājakā mathurā bahu cammikā iti kakārena sya ādinaḥ byavahita ttā siddham gha iti
translated: In the absence of a syllable, i for a before gha, etc.

original: kiṃ? Bālako, assāti kiṃ? Bahukattukā sālā.
analyzed: kim bālakaḥ assa ati kim bahu kattukā sālā
translated: After gha, etc., i is generally substituted for a before it, if gha, etc., is not followed by a syllable. Bālikā, kārikā. In the absence of a syllable: what? Sakā, keti. What? Nandanā. Followed by a syllable: what? Bāhuparibbājakā, mathurā. Bahucammikā: the substitution of i for a is established by the rule of kakāra, because it is separated by syādī. In the absence of a syllable: what? Bālako. Followed by a syllable: what? Bahukattukā, sālā.

original: Iti moggallāne byākaraṇe vuttiyaṃ
analyzed: iti moggallāne byākaraṇe vuttiyam
translated: Thus in the Moggallāna Grammar, in the commentary,

original: Ṇādikaṇḍo catuttho.
analyzed: ṇa ādi kaṇḍaḥ catutthaḥ
translated: The fourth chapter is finished.

original: 5. Pañcamo kaṇḍo (khādi)
analyzed: pañcamaḥ kaṇḍaḥ kha ādi
translated: The fifth chapter (khādi)

original: 1. Tija mānehi kha sā khamā vīmaṃsāsu.
analyzed: tija mānehi kha sā khamā vīmaṃsāsu
translated: Tija mānehi kha sā khamā vīmaṃsāsu.

original: Khantiyaṃ tijā vīmaṃsāyaṃ mānā ca khasappaccayā honti yathākkamaṃ, titikkhā, vīmaṃsā, titikkhati, vīmaṃsati. Khamāvīmaṃsā, sūti kiṃ? Tejanaṃ, tejo, tejayati, mānanaṃ, mānomāneti.
analyzed: khantiyam tijā vīmaṃsā ayam mānā ca khasa ppaccayāḥ honti yathākkamam titikkhā vīmaṃsā titikkhati vīmaṃsati khamā vīmaṃsā sūti kim tejanam tejaḥ tejayati mānanam mānomānā iti
translated: In patience, in the three, in māna, and in kha, the suffixes sā, khamā, and vīmaṃsā are added, respectively. Titikkhā, vīmaṃsā. Titikkhati, vīmaṃsati. Khamāvīmaṃsā. Sūti kiṃ? Tejanaṃ, tejati, tejayati. Mānanaṃ, māna, māneti.

original: 2. Kitā tikicchāsaṃsayesu cho.
analyzed: kitā tikicchā saṃsayesu chaḥ
translated: . Kitā tikicchāsaṃsayesu cho.

original: Tikicchāyaṃ saṃsaye ca vattamānā kitā cho hoti. Tikicchā, vicikicchā, tikicchati, vicikicchati. Aññatra niketo, saṃketo, ketanaṃ, keto, ketayati.
analyzed: tikicchā ayam saṃsaye ca vattamānā kitā cho hoti tikicchā vicikicchā tikicchati vicikicchati aññatra niketo saṃketo ketanam keto ketayati
translated: In the sense of ‘curing’ and ‘doubting’ the forms are kitā and cho respectively. Curing, doubting, he cures, he doubts. Except: a dwelling, a sign, a banner, a flag, he causes to be made.

original: 3. Nindāyaṃ gupa badhā bassa bho ca.
analyzed: ninda ayam gupa badhā bassa bho ca
translated: In the sense of ‘blame’ the forms are gupa and bho respectively.

original: Nindāyaṃ vattamānehi gupa badhehi cho hoti bassa bho ca. Jigucchā, bībhacchā, jigucchati, bībhacchati, aññatra gopanaṃ, gopo, gopeti, badhako.
analyzed: ninda ayam vattamānehi gupa badhehi chaḥ hoti bassa bho ca jigucchā bībhacchā jigucchati bībhacchati aññatra gopanam gopaḥ gopeti badhakaḥ
translated: In the sense of ‘blame’ the forms are gupa and bho respectively. Disgust, fear, he is disgusted, he is afraid, except: concealment, a concealer, he conceals, a killer.

original: 4. Tuṃsmā lopo cicchāyaṃ te.🔽Tumantato icchāyamatthe te khasachā honti bahulaṃ, lopo ca tuṃpaccayassa hoti sutattā,🔽bubhukkhā, jigīsāṃ, jighacchā, bubhukkhati, jigīsati jighacchati. Idha kasmā na hoti🔽‘bhottumicchatī’ti? Padantarenābhidhānā. Tuṃsmāti kiṃ? Bhojanamicchati. Icchāyanti
analyzed: tum smāḥ lopaḥ cicchāyam te  tum antatas icchā ayam atthe te kha sa chā honti bahulam lopaḥ ca tum paccayassa hoti su ta ttā  bubhukkhā jigīsām jighacchā bubhukkhati jigīsati jighacchati idha kasmai na hoti  bhottum icchati iti kim bhojanam icchati icchāyanti
translated: In the sense of ‘desire’ the forms are te and cho respectively.

original: kiṃ? Bhuñjituṃ gacchati. Kathaṃ ‘kūlaṃ vipati satī’ti? Yathā kūlaṃ patitu micchatīti
analyzed: kim bhuñjitum gacchati katham kūlam vipati satī iti yathā kūlam patitu m icchati iti
translated: In the sense of ‘desire’ the forms are te and cho respectively. Hunger, desire to eat, hunger, he is hungry, he desires to eat, he is hungry. Why is it not so here in ‘bhottumicchati’? Because of the expression by means of the word ending. Tuṃsmāti kiṃ? Bhojanamicchati. Icchāyanti kiṃ? Bhuñjituṃ gacchati. Kathaṃ ‘kūlaṃ vipati satī’ti? Yathā kūlaṃ patitu micchatīti

original: vākyaṃ hoti, evaṃ vuttipi hossati. Vākyameva carahi kathaṃ hoti? Lokassa tathā vacanicchāya.
analyzed: vākyam hoti evam vutti pi vākyam eva carahi katham hoti lokassa tathā vacanicchāya
translated: and so too is the usage. But how is it that the expression is so? Because of the desire to speak thus in the world.

original: 5. Īyo kammā.
analyzed: īyaḥ kammā
translated: . The desire-suffix īyo is used.

original: Icchākammato icchāyamatthe īyappaccayo hoti. Puttamicchati putthīyati. Kammāti kiṃ?
analyzed: icchā kammato icchā ayam atthe īyap paccayaḥ hoti puttam icchati putthīyati kamma ati kim
translated: The desire-suffix īyo is used in the sense of desire when there is desire. He desires a son, he desires a daughter. Why ‘kammato’?

original: Asinecchati. Idha kasmā na hoti ‘raññoputtamicchatī’ti? Sāpekkhattā, na hi aññamapekkhamāno
analyzed: asinā icchati idha kasmā na hoti rañño puttam icchati iti sa apekkha ttā na hi aññam apekkhamāno
translated: He desires a knife. Why is it not so here: ‘He desires the king’s son’? Because of the presence of expectation, for one who is expecting another

original: aññena sahekatthibhāvamanubhavituṃ sakkoti. Idhāpi carahi na siyā ‘attano putta micchatī’ti?
analyzed: aññena saha ikatthi bhāvam anubhavitum sakkoti idha api carahi na siyā micchati iti
translated: cannot experience the state of having the same object as another. But here too, how could it not be so: ‘He desires his own son’?

original: Nevettha bhavitabbaṃ, na hi bhavati ‘attano puttīyatī’ti, kathaṃ carahi puttassa
analyzed: na iva ittha bhavitabbam na hi bhavati attanaḥ puttīyati iti katham carahi puttassa
translated: It must be so here, for it is not so: ‘He desires his own daughter’. But how is it known that the son

original: attaniyatā-vagamyate? Aññassāsutattā icchāya ca tabbisayattā.🔽6. Upamānācāre.
analyzed: atta niyatā avagamyate aññassa a suta ttā icchāya ca  upamāna ācāre
translated: is his own? Because of the hearing of another and because of the object of the desire.

original: Kammato upamānā ācāratthe īyo hoti. Puttami-vā-carati puttīyati māṇavakaṃ, upamānāti kiṃ? Puttamācarati.🔽7. Ādhārā.
analyzed: kammataḥ upamānāḥ ācāra atthe īyaḥ hoti puttam iva ācarati puttīyati māṇavakam kim puttam ācarati 🔽ādhārā
translated: . The desire-suffix īyo is used in the sense of conduct when there is desire. He conducts himself like a son, he conducts himself like a daughter, he conducts himself like a youth. Why ‘upamānā’? He conducts himself as a son.

original: Ādhāratū-pamānā ācāratthe īyo yoti. Kuṭiyamivā-carati kuṭīyatī pāsāde, pāsādīyati kuṭiyaṃ bhikkhu.
analyzed: ādhāra tu upamānāḥ ācāra atthe īyaḥ yoti kuṭiyam iva ācarati kuṭīyatī pāsāde pāsādīyati kuṭiyam bhikkhu
translated: The words ādhāratū-pamānā ācāratthe īyo yo are the words of the commentary. He behaves like a hut, he hut-s, he hut-s in a palace, he palace-s in a hut.

original: 8. Kattutāyo.
analyzed: kattu tāyaḥ
translated: . The words kattutāyo are the words of the commentary.

original: Kattutū-pamānā ācāratthe āyo hoti. Pabbato ivācarati pabbatāyati.
analyzed: kattu tu upamānāḥ ācāra atthe āyaḥ hoti pabbataḥ iva ācarati pabbatāyati
translated: The words kattutū-pamānā ācāratthe āyo hoti are the words of the commentary. He behaves like a mountain, he mountain-s.

original: 9. Ycatthe.
analyzed: y catthe
translated: . The words ycatthe are the words of the commentary.

original: Kattuto abhūtatabbhāve āyo hoti bahulaṃ. Bhusāyati, paṭapaṭāyati, lohitāyati, kattutotveva? (Abhusaṃ) bhusaṃ karotīhi, iha kasmā na hoti ‘bhusī bhavatī’ti? Vuttatthatāya.
analyzed: kattutaḥ a bhūta tad bhāve āyaḥ hoti bahulam bhusāyati paṭapaṭāyati lohitāyati kattutaḥ tu eva abhusam bhusam karoti ihi iha kasmā na hoti bhusī bhavati iti vutta ttha tāya
translated: The words kattuto abhūtatabbhāve āyo hoti bahulaṃ are the words of the commentary. He shines, he shines forth, he glows, he glows forth. In the case of the words kattutāyo, how is it that here in the expression abhusaṃ bhusaṃ karotīti the form bhusī bhavatī is not used? Because it is already stated.

original: 10. Saddādīni karoti.
analyzed: karoti
translated: . The words saddādīni karoti are the words of the commentary.

original: Saddādīhi dutiyantehi karotīti asmiṃ atthe āyo hoti. Saddāyati, verāyati, kalahāyati, dhūpāyati.
analyzed: sadda ādīhi dutiya ntehi karoti iti asmin atthe āyaḥ hoti saddāyati verāyati kalahāyati dhūpāyati
translated: The words saddādīhi dutiyantehi karotīti asmiṃ atthe āyo hoti are the words of the commentary. He makes a sound, he makes a quarrel, he makes a dispute, he makes smoke.

original: 11. Numotva-sso.
analyzed: num o tvas so
translated: . The words numotva-sso are the words of the commentary.

original: Namoiccasmā karotīti asmiṃ atthe asso hoti. Namassati tathāgtaṃ.
analyzed: namoiccasma karoti iti asmin atthe assaḥ hoti namassati tathāgtam
translated: The words namoiccasmā karotīti asmiṃ atthe asso hoti are the words of the commentary. He pays homage to the Enlightened One.

original: 12. Dhātvatthe nāmasmi.
analyzed: dhātvatthe nām asmi
translated: . The words dhātvatthe nāmasmi are the words of the commentary.

original: Nāmasmā dhātvatthe bahulamihoti. Hatthinā atikkamati atihatthayati, vīṇāya upagāyati
analyzed: dhātvatthe hatthinā atikkamati atihatthayati vīṇāya upagāyati
translated: The words nāmasmā dhātvatthe bahulamihoti are the words of the commentary. He goes beyond the elephant, he goes beyond the lute.

original: upavīṇayati, daḷhaṃ karoti vinayaṃ daḷhayati, visuddhā hoti ratti visuddhayati, kusalaṃ
analyzed: upavīṇayati daḷham karoti vinayam daḷhayati visuddhā hoti kusalam
translated: he makes it firm, he makes the Monastic Law firm, the night is purified, he purifies the skillful

original: pucchati kusalayati.
analyzed: pucchati kusalayati
translated: He causes to be played on the lute, he makes firm, he makes firm the Discipline, he purifies the night, he asks about what is skillful, he makes skillful.

original: 13. Saccādīhāpi.
analyzed: sat cādi iha api
translated: . Saccā, etc., here too.

original: Saccādīhi dhātvatthe āpi hoti. Saccāpeti, atthāpeti, vedāpeti, sukkhāpeti, sukhāpeti, dukkhāpeti.
analyzed: sacca ādīhi dhātu atthe āpi hoti saccāpeti atthāpeti vedāpeti sukkhāpeti sukhāpeti dukkhāpeti
translated: Saccā, etc., are also added to the noun-stems of the dhātu. He causes to be told, he causes to be understood, he causes to be known, he causes to be dried up, he causes to be happy, he causes to be unhappy.

original: 14. Kriyatthā.
analyzed: kriyatthā
translated: . The meaning of action.

original: Ayamadhikāro āsatthaparisamattiyā. Kriyā attho yassa so kriyattho dhātu.
analyzed: ayam adhikāraḥ āsattha parisamattiyā kriyā atthaḥ yassa saḥ kriyatthaḥ dhātu
translated: This section is completed by the addition of the meaning of action. That which has the meaning of action is a dhātu of the meaning of action.

original: 15. Curādito ṇi.
analyzed: curā t itaḥ ṇi
translated: . Ṇi from curā, etc.

original: Curādīhi kriyatthehi sakatthe ṇi paro hoti bahulaṃ. Ṇakāro vuddhyattho, evamaññatrāpi, corayati, lāḷayati, kathaṃ ‘rajjaṃ kāretī’ti? Yogavibhāgato.
analyzed: curā ādīhi kriyatthehi saka tthe ṇi paraḥ hoti bahulam ṇakāraḥ evam aññatra api corayati lāḷayati katham rajjam kāreti iti yoga vibhāgato
translated: Ṇi is added to the noun-stems of the meaning of action beginning with curā, etc., in the sense of the thing itself. The ṇ is for the meaning of increase, so too elsewhere, he steals, he delights. How is it that ‘he causes the kingdom to be ruled’? Because of the division of the yogas.

original: 16. Payojakabyāpāre ṇāpi ca.
analyzed: payojaka byāpāre ca
translated: . And also ṇā in the sense of the instigator’s function.

original: Kattāraṃ yo payojayati, tassa byāpāre kriyatthā ṇiṇāpī honti bahulaṃ, kāreti, kārāpeti.
analyzed: kattāram yaḥ upayojayati tassa byāpāre honti bahulam kāreti kārāpeti
translated: When one causes the doer to act, the ṇi and ṇā are added in the sense of the instigator’s function. He causes to be done, he causes to be done by another.

original: Nanu ca kattāpi karaṇādīnaṃ payojakoti taṃbyāpārepi ṇiṇāpī pāpuṇanti? Payojakaggahaṇasāmatthiyā
analyzed: nanu ca kattā api karaṇa ādīnam payojakaḥ iti tad byāpāre pi pāpuṇanti payojaka ggahaṇa sāmatthiyā
translated: But is it not the case that the doer is also the instigator of the instrument, etc., and that therefore the ṇi and ṇā apply to the instigator’s function? Because of the capability of the word ‘instigator’ being taken.

original: na bhavissanti curādīhi visuṃ vacanasāmatthiyā ca. Ato bhiyyo ṇāpiyeva, ṇiyevuvaṇṇato, dvayamevaññehi.🔽17. Kyo bhāvakammesva-parokkhesu māna nta tyādīsu. Bhāvakammavihitesu parokkhāvajjitesu
analyzed: na bhavissanti curā ādīhi visum vacana sāmatthiyā ca atas bhiyyas dvaya mevaññehi  kyaḥ bhāva kammesu aparokkhesu māna nta tyādīsu bhāva kamma vihitesu parokkha avajjitesu
translated: After that, only ṇā, ṇi, and ṇe are found.🔽Kyo is found in the verbs of existence and action, in the verbs of the past tense, and in the verbs of the future tense.🔽In the verbs of existence and action, in the verbs of the past tense, and in the verbs of the future tense, and in other verbs, kṛ is used to express the meaning of action.

original: mānantatyādīsu paresu kyo hoti kriyatthā. Ntaggahaṇamuttaratthaṃ, kakāro avuddhyattho
analyzed: māna nta tya ādīsu paresu kyaḥ hoti a nta ggahaṇam uttarattham kakāraḥ
translated: The affix nta is used for the future tense. The prefix ka expresses the meaning of non-understanding.

original: evamuttaratrāpi. Ṭhīyamānaṃ, ṭhīyate, sūyamānaṃ, sūyate, aparokkhesu mānantatyādīsūti
analyzed: evam uttaratra api ṭhīyamānam ṭhīyate sūyamānam sūyate aparokkhesu
translated: The same applies to the following. Ṭhīyamānaṃ, ṭhīyate, sūyamānaṃ, sūyate. In the verbs of the past tense, and in the verbs of the future tense, and in other verbs.

original: kiṃ? Babhūva devadattena, bibhida kusulo. Bhijjate kusulo sayamevāti ‘bhijjate’ti🔽savanā kammatā-vagamyate, ‘sayamevā’ti savanato kattutā, kattutāvacanicchāyantu ‘bhindati
analyzed: kim babhūva devadattena bibhida kusulaḥ bhijjate kusulaḥ sayam eva ati bhijjata iti  savanā kamma tā avagamyate sayam eva ati bhindati
translated: What? Babhūva devadattena, bibhida kusalo. Bhijjate kusalo sayameva. Thus, ‘bhijjate’.

original: kusulo attāna’nti bhavati, evamaññampi yathāgamamanugantabbaṃ. ‘Aparokkhesu mānantatyādīsū’ti
analyzed: kusulaḥ bhavati evam aññam pi yathāgamam anugantabbam aparokkhesu mā ananta tyā ādīsu iti
translated: The action of hearing is understood. ‘Sayameva’ means the action of the agent. However, if the desire for the action of the agent is expressed, ‘bhindati kusalo attāna’ becomes. The same should be understood in other cases according to the text. ‘In the verbs of the past tense, and in the verbs of the future tense, and in other verbs’.

original: ayamadhikāro ā ‘tanāditvo’ti 5.26. Apica ete kyādayo tyādīsu parabhūtesu kattukammabhāva🔽vihitesu kyalādīnaṃ vidhānato tesveva viññāyantīti akammakehi dhātūhi kattubhāvesu,
analyzed: ayam adhikāraḥ api ca ete kiya ādayaḥ tya ādīsu para bhūtesu kattu kamma bhāva  vihitesu kyal ādīnam vidhānato tesu eva viññāyanti iti akammakehi dhātūhi kattu bhāvesu
translated: This is the scope of the words ‘from the beginning’.🔽Moreover, these kyi etc. are known only in the case of verbs which have a nominative case subject,🔽because they are prescribed in the case of verbs which have a nominative case subject or an accusative case object,

original: sakammakehi kattukammesu, kammāvacanicchāyaṃ bhāve ca bhavantīti veditabbā. Yassa🔽pana dhātussa kiriyā kammamapekkhate, so sakammako, yassa tu kiriyā kattumattamapekkhate,
analyzed: sa kammakehi kattu kammesu kamma a vacani chāyam bhāve ca bhavanti iti veditabbā yassa  pana dhātussa kiriyā kammam apekkhate so sa kammakaḥ yassa tu kiriyā kattumattam apekkhate
translated: and in the case of verbs which have an accusative case object or an objective case object.🔽But that verb whose action requires an object is one which has an accusative case object,

original: svākammakoti ñātabbaṃ.
analyzed: svākammakā iti ñātabbam
translated: and that verb whose action requires only an agent is one which has a nominative case subject.

original: 18. Kattari lo.
analyzed: kattari laḥ
translated: . In the nominative case.

original: Kriyatthato aparokkhesu kattuvihitamāna ntatyādīsu lo hoti. Lakāro, “ñilasse”ti 5-163 visesanattho. Pacamāno, pacanto, pacati.
analyzed: kriya tthataḥ aparokkhesu laḥ hoti lakāraḥ ñ ilassa iti visesana tthaḥ pacamānaḥ pacantaḥ pacati
translated: In the case of the nominative case subject in the verbs ‘to cook’ etc. where the action is not remote, lo is substituted for the final vowel. The letter la is for the purpose of distinguishing (the substitution of lo from that of lo in the next rule). Pacamāno, pacanto, pacati.

original: 19. Maṃ ca rudhādīnaṃ.
analyzed: mam ca
translated: . And ma is substituted for the final vowel of rudh etc.

original: Rudhādito kattuvihitamānanta tyādīsu lo hoti maṃ ca antasarā paro. Makāro-nubandho, akāro uccāraṇattho. Rundhamāno, rundhanto, rundhati.
analyzed: rudh ādeḥ tya ādīsu laḥ hoti mam ca paraḥ makāraḥ anubandhaḥ akāraḥ uccāraṇa atthaḥ rundhamānaḥ rundhantaḥ rundhati
translated: In the case of the nominative case subject in the verbs ‘to cover’ etc. where the action is not remote, lo is substituted for the final vowel, and ma is substituted for the final vowel of the first syllable. The letter ma is for the purpose of continuing the substitution, the letter a is for the purpose of pronunciation. Rundhamāno, rundhanto, rundhati.

original: 20. Ṇiṇāpyāpīhi vā.
analyzed: vā
translated: . Or by ṇiṇāpīpī.

original: Ṇiṇāpyāpīhi kattuvihitamānanta tyādīsu lo hoti vibhāsā, orayanto, corento, kārayanto,
analyzed: tya ādīsu laḥ hoti vibhāsā orayantaḥ corentaḥ kārayantaḥ
translated: The forms orayanto, corento, kārayanto,

original: kārento, kārāpayanto, kārāpento, saccāpayanto, saccāpento, corayati, coreti, kārayati,🔽kāreti, kārāpayati, kārāpeti, saccāpayati, saccāpeti. Vavatthitavibhāsattho-yaṃ vāsaddo,
analyzed: kārentaḥ kārāpayantaḥ kārāpentaḥ saccāpayantaḥ saccāpentaḥ corayati coreti kārayati  kāreti kārāpayati kārāpeti saccāpayati saccāpeti vavatthita vibhāsa atthaḥ yam vā saddaḥ
translated: kārento, kārāpayanto, kārāpento, saccāpayanto, saccāpento, corayati, coreti, kārayati,🔽kāreti, kārāpayati, kārāpeti, saccāpayati, saccāpeti, are formed by the addition of the augment lo.

original: tena māne niccaṃ, corayamāno, kārayamāno, kārāpayamāno, saccāpayamāno.🔽21. Divādīhi yaka.
analyzed: tena māne niccam corayamāno kārayamāno kārāpayamāno saccāpayamāno  divā dīhi yaka
translated: The forms corayamāno, kārayamāno, kārāpayamāno, saccāpayamāno, are formed by the addition of the augment lo, the word vās being understood in the sense of ‘the augment vavatthitavibhāsa’.🔽. The augment yaka is added to the roots beginning with di.

original: Divādīhi lavisaye yaka hoti. Dibbanto, dibbati.
analyzed: diva ādīhi la visaye ya ka hoti dibbantaḥ dibbati
translated: The forms dibbanto, dibbati, are formed by the addition of the augment yaka to the root di.

original: 22. Tudādīhi ko.
analyzed: tud ādi ī hi kaḥ
translated: . The augment ko is added to the roots beginning with tu.

original: Tudādīhi lavisaye ko hoti. Tudamāno, tudanto, tudati.
analyzed: tud ādīhi la visaye kaḥ hoti tudamānaḥ tudantaḥ tudati
translated: The forms tudamāno, tudanto, tudati, are formed by the addition of the augment ko to the root tu.

original: 23. Jyādīhi knā.
analyzed: jyā ādīhi knā
translated: . The augment knā is added to the roots beginning with ji.

original: Jiādīhi lavisaye knā hoti. Jinanto, jināti. Kathaṃ ‘jayanto’ jayatī, ti? Bhūvādipāṭhā.🔽24. Kyādīhi kṇā.
analyzed: la visaye hoti jinantaḥ jināti katham jayantaḥ jayati iti bhūva ādi pāṭhā  kya ādi hi kṇā
translated: The forms jinanto, jināti, are formed by the addition of the augment knā to the root ji. How is it that the forms jayanto, jayati, are formed? The words bhūvādi are understood here.🔽. The augment kṇā is added to the roots beginning with ki.

original: Kīādīhi lavisaye kṇā hoti. Kiṇanto, kiṇāti.🔽25. Svādīhi kṇo.
analyzed: kī ādīhi la visaye hoti kiṇantaḥ kiṇāti 🔽svādīhi kṇo
translated: The forms kiṇanto, kiṇāti, are formed by the addition of the augment kṇā to the root ki.🔽. The augment kṇo is added to the roots beginning with svā.

original: Suādīhi lavisaye kṇo hoti. Suṇamāno, suṇanto, suṇoti. Kathaṃ suṇātīti? Kyādipāṭhā.
analyzed: su ādīhi la visaye kṇaḥ hoti suṇamānaḥ suṇantaḥ suṇoti katham suṇāti iti kya ādi pāṭhā
translated: The k is added to su and the other words in the sense of the passive. Listening, hearing, he hears. How does he hear? The k is added by the rule beginning with “kyā.”🔽

original: 26. Tanāditvo.
analyzed: tan ā t itvaḥ
translated: The k-form is used in the sense of the object of the verb with the prepositions su and so on. He hears, he is hearing, he hears. How does he hear? The k-form is used with the prepositions kyā and so on.

original: Tanādito lavisaye o hoti. Tanoti.🔽27. Bhāvakammesu tabbā-nīyā.🔽Tabbaanīyā kriyatthā pare bhāvakammesu bahulaṃ bhavanti. Kattabbaṃ, karaṇīyaṃ, kattabbo
analyzed: tan ādeḥ la visaye o hoti tanoti  bhāva kammesu tabbānīyā  tabba anīyā kriyatthā pare bhāva kammesu bahulam bhavanti kattabbam karaṇīyam kattabbaḥ
translated: . The t-form is used with the prepositions tan and so on. He stretches.🔽. The o-form is used in the sense of the object of the verb with the prepositions tan and so on. He stretches.🔽. The tabbā-nīya forms are used in the sense of the object of the verb in the passive voice. What should be done, what should be made, what should be done,

original: kaṭo, karaṇīyo. Bahulādhikārā karaṇādīsupi bhavanti, sinānīyaṃ cuṇṇaṃ, dānīyo brāhmaṇo,
analyzed: kaṭaḥ karaṇīyaḥ bahula adhikārā karaṇa ādīsupi bhavanti sinānīyam cuṇṇam dānīyaḥ brāhmaṇaḥ
translated: what should be made, what should be done. Because of the general statement, they are also used in the sense of the object of the verb in the active voice: bathing powder, a brahmin who should be given,

original: sammāvattanīyo guru, pavacanīyo upajjhāyo, upaṭṭhānīyo sisso.🔽28. Ghyaṇa.
analyzed: sammāvattanīyaḥ guru pavacanīyaḥ upajjhāyaḥ upaṭṭhānīyaḥ sisso  ghi aṇa
translated: a teacher who should be properly attended to, a preceptor who should be spoken to, a pupil who should be attended to.

original: Bhāvakammesu kriyatthā paro ghyaṇa hoti bahulaṃ. Vākyaṃ, kāriyaṃ, ceyyaṃ, jeyyaṃ.🔽29. Āsse ca.
analyzed: bhāva kammesu hoti bahulam vākyam kāriyam ceyyam jeyyam  āsse ca
translated: . The ghyaṇa form is used in the sense of the object of the verb in the passive voice. The sentence, what should be done, what should be done, what should be conquered.

original: Ātoghyaṇa hoti bhāvakammesu, āssa e ca. Deyyaṃ.🔽30. Vadādīhi yo.
analyzed: hoti bhāva kammesu ca deyyam  vad ādīhi yaḥ
translated: . The e form is used in the sense of the object of the verb in the passive voice. What should be given.

original: Vadādīhi kriyatthehi yo hoti bahulaṃ bhāvakammesu. Vajjaṃ, majjaṃ, gammaṃ. (42) “Bhujānne”, bhojjo odano, bhojjā yāgu, bhoggamaññaṃ.
analyzed: vad ādīhi kriyatthehi yaḥ hoti bahulam bhāva kammesu vajjam majjam gammam bhuja anne bhojjaḥ odanaḥ bhojjā yāgu
translated: . The yo form is used in the sense of the object of the verb in the passive voice with the verbs vadā and so on. What should be seen, what should be drunk, what should be gone.

original: 31. Kicca ghacca bhacca bhabba leyyā.
analyzed: kicca ghacca bhacca bhabba leyyā
translated: 31. Kicca, ghacca, bhacca, bhabba, leyyā.

original: Ete saddā yappaccayantā nipaccante.
analyzed: ete saddāḥ yat paccayantāḥ nipaccante
translated: These words, when they are the reason for the affixation of a y, are affixed.

original: 32. Guhādīhi yaka.
analyzed: guhā ādīhi yaka
translated: . Yaka after guhādīhi, etc.

original: Gutādīhi kriyattehi bhāvakammesu yaka hoti. Guyhaṃ, duyhaṃ, sisso. Siddhā evete tabbādayo
analyzed: guta ādīhi bhāva kammesu hoti guyham duyham sisso siddhāḥ eva ete tabba ādayaḥ
translated: Yaka is after the verbs beginning with guh, etc., in the sense of the state of being done. Guhyam, duyham, sissu. These tabbā, etc., are established.

original: pesātisaggapattakālesupi gamyamānesu sāmaññenavidhānato, tvayā khalu kaṭo kattabbo,
analyzed: gamyamānesu sāmaññena vidhānataḥ tvayā khalu kaṭaḥ kattabbo
translated: Even when pesā, etc., are being used, they are established by the general rule, because of the time of the addition of the affix -ttak. “The cart must be made by you,

original: karaṇīyo, kāriyo, kicco, evaṃ tvayā kaṭo kattabbo, bhotā kaṭo kattabbo, bhoto hi
analyzed: karaṇīyaḥ kāriyaḥ kicco evam tvayā kaṭaḥ kattabbaḥ bhotā kaṭaḥ kattabbaḥ bhotaḥ hi
translated: must be done, must be carried out, must be done by you in this way, must be made by you, because the time has come for you

original: patto kālo kaṭakaraṇe. Evaṃ uddhamohuttikepi vattamānato pesādīsu siddhā eva. Tathā
analyzed: pattaḥ kālaḥ kaṭa karaṇe evam vattamānato pesa ādīsu siddhāḥ eva tathā
translated: to make the cart.” In the same way, in the case of uddhaṃmuhuttato, etc., they are established in pesā, etc. So too,

original: arahe kattari sattivisiṭṭhe ca patīyamāne āvassakādhamīṇatāvisiṭṭhe ca bhāvādo siddhā,
analyzed: arahe kattari satti visiṭṭhe ca patīyamāne āvassaka adhamīṇa tā visiṭṭhe ca bhāva ādaḥ siddhā
translated: in the case of the agent, when the state of being done is distinguished by the instrument, they are established in āvassakādhamīṇatā,

original: uddhaṃmuhuttato-bhotā kaṭo kattabbo, bhotā rajjaṃ kattabbaṃ. Bhavaṃ araho, bhotā
analyzed: kaṭaḥ kattabbaḥ bhotā rajjam kattabbam bhavam araho bhotā
translated: “The cart must be made by you, the kingdom must be ruled by you. You are worthy, by you

original: sāro vahitabbo, bhavaṃ sakko, bhotā avassaṃ kaṭo kattabbo, bhotā nikkho dātabbo.
analyzed: sāraḥ vahitabbaḥ bhavam sakkaḥ bhotā avassam kaṭaḥ kattabbaḥ bhotā nikkhaḥ dātabbaḥ
translated: the heartwood must be carried, you are able, by you the cart must be made in the rainy season, by you the gift must be given.”

original: 33. Kattari ltuṇakā.
analyzed: kattari ltuṇakā
translated: . Ltuṇak after kattari.

original: Kattari kārake kriyatthā ltuṇakā honti bahulaṃ. Paṭhitā, pāṭhako. Bahulamitveva?🔽Pādehi harīyatīti pādahā-rako, gale cuppateti galecopako. Siddhova ltu, arahe sīlasādhudhammesu🔽ca sāmaññavihitattā, bhavaṃ khalu kaññāya pariggahitā, bhavametaṃ arahati. Sīlādīsu-khalvapi🔽upādātā kumārake, gantā khelaṃ, muṇḍayitāro sāviṭṭhāyanā vadhuṃ katapariggahaṃ.🔽34. Āvī.🔽Kriyatthā āvī hoti bahulaṃ kattari. Bhayadassāvī. Appavisayataññāpanatthaṃ bhinnayogakaraṇaṃ, sāmaññavihitattā sīlā dīsu ca hoteva.🔽35. Āsiṃsāyamako.
analyzed: kattari kārake kriyatthāḥ ltuṇakāḥ honti bahulam paṭhitā pāṭhakaḥ bahulam iti eva  pādehi harīyati iti pāda hārakaḥ gale cuppata iti galecopakaḥ siddho va a rahe sīla sādhu dhammesu  ca sāmañña vihita ttā bhavam khalu kaññāya pariggahitā bhavam etam arahati  upādātā kumārake gantā khelam muṇḍayitāraḥ sāviṭṭhāyanāḥ vadhum kata pariggaham  āvī  kriyatthā āvī hoti bahulam kattari bhaya dassāvī bhinna yoga karaṇam sāmañña vihita ttā sīlā dīsu ca hotā iva  āsiṃsāyamakaḥ
